Rick,

I worked for 11 hours today and when I stepped outside, the sun was 
setting and something was seriously going on because the sky in the west 
was the richest shade of peach I have ever seen and I just stood there 
like a dope with my mouth gaping wide open at the intense view.  Every 
cloud in the sky had highlights of peach on one side and I decided that 
it was well worth the wait.

sky rave '95

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun  1 02:27:16 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id CAA28308; Thu, 1 Jun 1995 02:27:16 -0700

	id CAA05507; Thu, 1 Jun 1995 02:26:18 -0700
Message-Id: <199506010926.CAA05507@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: SPAZ GG Party got busted...
Date: Thu, 01 Jun 95 02:26:18 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Or at least, it seemed like it was getting busted...

In case anybody was thinking of checking this party out, I thought i'd
let you know....

Yeah, so we were like major wussies, so we ran for some random dark
path through the woods as soon as we saw the flashlights and heard 'em
say "ok, everybody stay put". "Yeah Right" says I as we run over
bramble and under bush.

It was a very cool party location though; dark n' spooky woods and 
overgrowth gave a nice windbreak, making it completely uneccessary for
us to dress like antartic explorers. 

I kinda figured something was going to happen given the park-ranger car
i saw around midnight, and what with the location too close to the
great hwy parking lot.

Thanks to SPAZ for the party, hope all is well and that the cops
weren't unreasonable in busting the party. After we ran away, the 
music started again, and a large assembly of squad cars began to appear
on the great hwy parking lot near the party site. Looked like there
were about as many cops as there were ravers at the party. :-)

In the future, a designated sacrifical raver virgin (gets free E!
secondary virginity acceptable) should be given the task of placating
the police in order to let the party continue.... "Oh I just love the
texture on your baton.... please club me over the head with it some
more! And you're such a good listener too!" :->

PS: while all this was going on (say midnight-2AM) there were people
partying on the beach around campfires, despite signs that explicitly
stated "no fires" (and doesn't the beach close at 10PM??). Seems like
raving in the woods is somehow worse than an illegal campfire or
loitering on the beach.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Subject: Re: Bro & Sis Line Up (another long response)

     I meant to post the msg below to the group rather than just directly 
     to Brian D. re:  his msg a couple of weeks ago asking "If anyone had a 
     good time at 1015?".  After reading Tracy's msg, I thought I should 
     dig it up to reiterate how we wear different masks (sometimes 
     unconsciously) and how it can be deceiving to people.  Heck, last week 
     Friday, I wore my Pollyanna-ish flouncy white shirt directly from work 
     to 1015 and Mo' Funk (or whatever that was) and then to the End-Up.  
     Some people looked at me in amazement to this ol' gal getting down and 
     some came up to me telling me that I didn't look like a raver.  Yet, 
     here I was schmoozing with the regulars.  What's up with that, they 
     wanted to know?  The bottom line, I told them was not what you were 
     wearing on the outside but what was going on inside.  Then your true 
     light will shine.  
     
     Hugs and kisses,
     Diane
     ----
     Brian,
     
     I'm sorry you had a bad time at 1015.  Yes, there were lots of 
     different folks at the gig but by 2-3pm many of the "clubbers" had 
     left and the regulars were going off.  True, this was the first time I 
     was at Brothers & Sisters, but I've gone out enough to know faces in 
     the scene and they were there.  Also, could it have been a result of 
     netters getting a freebie?  Hey, look I even made it there ;)
     
     Regardless, if we rave (for me at least), isn't part of it about 
     accepting everyone for where they're at and appreciating the 
     individual way they get off through music and dance?  Again, for me 
     it's the acceptance that leads us to connectedness.  So whatever you 
     wear and how old you are shouldn't make a difference.  I always feel 
     that if I come with a positive vibe and project it, more will come to 
     you.
     
     I know my brother (a "retired" old-time raver) and I go through 
     discussions about keeping the scene underground.  He's all for it and 
     I have mixed feelings.  Yet he and I were amused the other day when I 
     told him that driving back from Basics, we got some strange looks from 
     people at a gas station/market because "a small Asian Woman wearing a 
     black leather jacket (wannabe tough chick) driving a spanking new 
     _family_ car (yuppie-$$) w/a crashed out hippie (peace, love & rasta) 
     and a tall black man (potentially threatening to red necks)" was such 
     a cross section, that they couldn't figure out what brought us 
     together.  Where else would you get this?  Antioch, Fairfield or 
     wherever we were was probably as amused as us 8) [Hey, I know I'll 
     probably get flamed for my descriptions but 1) they're meant 
     tongue-in-cheek; and 2) think about it...how do we look at others if 
     we didn't know eachother and we were passing on the street?  Now, 
     think about how differently we react when we know the person or their 
     vibe...]
     
     And _YES_, I did invite some friends of mine who have always been 
     curious about raves but didn't know how to get to one.  From what I've 
     heard about Brothers & Sisters, it would be a good middle-ground place 
     to introduce them so I had a couple of them come out this weekend.  If 
     you multiply this by a few, then there'd be a good percentage of 
     newbies to either infuse the scene w/more energy or to drive it 
     underground.
     
     Hope the rest of your weekend was better.
     
     Diane


______________________________ Reply Separator

Subject: Brothers & Sisters Line Up
Author:  ameba@netcom.com at beluga-mail
Date:    5/30/95 5:25 PM


Thanks to all who came down to Brothers and Sisters last week.

This week's line-up is:  Tracy
Spun
Jan Cooley
As usual anyone from SF Raves gets in free on our guest list.
Just tell the girl at the door that you are from SF Raves and it will 
be all good.
Thanks for all the support, hope to see you all this Friday at 1015.
And to all of those that are worried about the vibe for one reason or 
another. The club always gets better when the bar closes because 
shortly after that the gold room closes, since that seems to be the 
one that apalls certain individuals.  

I think that we all need to drop out pre-conceived notions that 
because someone is wearing a suit or dressed nice means that there is 
something wrong with them.  I have been the resident dj for Brothers 
and Sisters, formally Soundsystem for six months now.  I must admit, 
at first I thought they were dorks but after meeting a few of them I 
discovered that alot of them are cool people that have never 
experienced a good groove.  There are several so called "suits" that 
come to Brothers and Sisters regularly that are really good people 
just trying to unwind with their friends.  I think that it is about 
time that we drop the negitive stereotypes and start communicating.  
That way rather than judging people based on what they look like, 
take the time to find out what they are about, you may be surprised, 
there are a lot of subversive individuals out there you just have to 
get past fear and introduce yourself.
If we want our scene to grow and maintain diversisty we need to start 
being less closed-minded and judgemental of people that we have never 
met.  There are good people and bad people.  Anyway, what were you 
like before you discovered the House Movement?  Sometimes we all seem 
to forget our past.

Just a few kind words.

dj Tracy, Brothers and Sisters

and what they wear, their color or whatever really is unimportant 
-------------------------------------
E-mail: ameba@netcom.com           !   boredom makes
Date: 05/30/95                                   !   you do crazy   
Time: 16:27:08                                 !    things
     
salutations
-------------------------------------

Subject: The Roots
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I hardly go out to anything anymore, last night was a very positive exception.
I went to see the hip-hop group the Roots @ DNA.
All I can say is that the place was bumpin', and the crowd was more positive
than I had come to expect.

One thing that I noticed, right off, were the multitude of colors present in the audience.  Amazing, and everybody was all about getting a groove on, smoking some green, and listening to a slammin set!  
Kinda reminded me of the old days of rave.  Kinda reminds me that the only way this thing we call rave will survive in any relevant form is thru diversity.

People I saw: DJ Mark Farina, DJ Josh, Ron C. of Nitty Gritty, Adria.
Fights arguments disturbances: ZERO
Diversity: 100%
Music:  I thought people playing real instruments were passe.  I've now been informed ;).

Style: 100% hip-hop freestyle in da booty wit no vaseline!

Ain't seen such fine sistahs of all colors from all over in a long time.  

Late,
John

Message-Id: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950601154908.7705B-100000@aldebaran.oac.uci.edu>

On Wed, 31 May 1995, Rocky Mullin wrote:

> 	'big name dj's'
> 	'money backing'
> 
> 	be careful.....
> 

Yeah...I want to take this thing slowly and carfully.  I realize that to 
accomplish what I want accomplished at this rave (a great event with 
hopefully a big soundsystem and a lot of people just enjoying the vibe of 
the forrest and the music) that I cannot afford it all myself.  I decided 
a while ago that I wil NOT charge anything for this event.  NOTHING will 
make me change my mind about that.  However if I can get some people to 
put up some money up front and then give whatever I get in donations back 
then hopefully this thing will really thump.  Like I said in my previous 
post, this guy as far as I know, does not plan on getting any of his 
money back, he just wants to see a good rave go off (which seems to be 
directly in line with me views).  Also I hope that all the DJs will do it 
for free since I will not pay any of them....not enuff $$$, besides the 
whole essence of this is to return to the forrest and not have to worry 
about the pressures of society and money.  So if I can get some big name 
DJs who will do it for free I would really appreciate it (hopefully some 
of these numbers I got will work out), if not, there is nothing wrong 
with new talent.   Unknowns are somtimes better, the only prob is it 
won't attract as many people...

does anybody have any comments, criticizms, or praise for this idea?  I 
am perfectly welcome to take ANY advice constructively as long as it 
doesn't have the words "fuck" and "yourself" in it.  8-)  Oh well, I 
guess I better go.  

	-Christian

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun  1 15:59:45 1995

From: "Andrew B. Lawson" <lawson@nature.Berkeley.EDU>

Subject: Wonderful weekend
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950601154631.17972A-100000@golden.Berkeley.EDU>

I just wanted to thank everyone for a wonderful weekend!  It was one of 
the best I've had in quite some time.  Stompy on Friday night was slow 
getting going (or maybe I just got there early), but after a few hours it 
went off!  There was a great core crowd of very positive people that made 
it impossible not to smile.  The sound system was great, excellent 
visuals and great music.  Best of all it was at the Townsend.  This is a 
great space...I wish it were used more often.  
	Sunset on Sunday was no less than perfect.  Great weather, music 
and friends.  It was great to see some very familiar faces, and get some 
great hugs (thanks Brian).  After washing off the dust from all 
that dancing at sunset we headed over to Spundae.  A clubby crowd, but an 
absolutely wonderful time.
	Thanks again to everyone that put on these parties and everyone 
that went to them and made them so special.  I have a great feeling about 
this summer... 

big smiles,
Andrew

I think DJs should be eager and willing to:

 o work for free
 o carry speakers and amplifiers
 o help set up and clean up
 o behave like caring, considerate human beings while engaged in the above

DJs that won't do the above, I would disconsider as a matter of principle.
But that's just my opinion =)

see ya
ethan

At  3:55 PM 6/1/95 -0700, Christian Barton wrote:
Unknowns are somtimes better, the only prob is it
>won't attract as many people...
>
>does anybody have any comments, criticizms, or praise for this idea?  I
>am perfectly welcome to take ANY advice constructively as long as it
>doesn't have the words "fuck" and "yourself" in it.  8-)  Oh well, I
>guess I better go.
>
>        -Christian

Christian -

If the forest is as you have descibed it (and I believe you fully) and you
get a sound system and all the works up there, I don't think you'll have
any problem getting people to go.  Whether you have huge name DJs or
locally known DJs.  You are going to attract ravers that will want to be
outside for a couple days.  That in itself will filter out those that say,
"Hell man, I hate so-in-so and he's spinning."  Or the raver that say, "I
can't believe they're going to have three days of outdoor raving for free
and there isn't one DJ I want to hear.  Fuck that!"

My point is, I don't think you're going to have to "hire" a big name DJ to
pull in the people.  If anything it's as much who's helping to put it
together as it is who's spinning.  Plus this would be such a great
opportunity to mix so many different raving communities.  Right there is a
problem in finding a DJ universally known to Southern California and SF and
Davis and wherever else people would be coming from.  One community's spin
God is another community's unknown.  Capice'?

Gotta go!

Tony

Yes herbal extasy is weaker then it's sythetic counterpart.  Which is all 
fine and good if you have never taken the genuine article because your 
body does not know what to expect.  Herbal E is for people who people who 
have never taken MDMA; it's kind of like the idea that gurana (in 
large amounts) used to put me off my nut until I started taking speed 
then it was like no buzz at all.  Personally a good strong cup of coffee 
and a few big bong hits is the same as E anyway so whats th epoint?

On Sat, 27 May 1995, Amy Titherington wrote:

> Someone gave me some herbal ecstasy (I don't think I'd want to pay $20 
> for it).  I took the whole package (just to be safe), and drank a lot of 
> water (which was recommended).  I definately felt it, but it certainly 
> didn't feel anything like the genuine artifact. It made me feel very 
> awake and energetic, and it seemed to heighten tactile sensation a 
> little bit.  It was kind of interesting, but I don't think I'd become a 
> regular customer.  It's a little overpriced.  
> 
>

In the July issue of Playboy there was this short blurb 

(From "Playboy After Hours" 7/95 issue)

                             WILD OATS

Looks like a young mover and shaker at Quaker Oats knows a thing or two about 
acid trance. Packages of Instant Quaker Oatmeal now sport bits of pop trive on 
such subjects as hip-hop, rave, fanzines and grunge. One demanding 
multiple-choice question asked kids: "What's the difference between house 
music and rave music?" Fortunately for the parents, the answer was listed on 
the same packet: "House music is generally 120 beats per minute, rave is 132 
beats per minute."


I thought it was kinda funny.


-Sean

-SeanC@scruznet.com
 "House Music All Night Long"

       90.3 (SF)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

two friends of mine took the herbal e found in pill form (i believe like they
have at the natural foods store in upper haight) and went to epcot center in
florida. they said the recommended dose of 8 pills was fine, but then they
decided to take more (total intake 15) and it was way too much of whatever it
is. they were stomache sick for 2 or three days and while at the epcot center
went through all these head trips. now these are people who get along fine
with mdma and even some bastard cousins of it. so...

are busy dying."

"There are three mental states that interest me....
These are: one, amnesia;
two, euphoria;
three, ecstasy.....
Amnesia is not knowing who one is 
and wanting desperately to find out.
Euphoria is not knowing who one is 
and not caring.
Ecstasy is knowing exactly who one is-
and still not caring."

          -Amanda from the Tom Robbins book 
            Another Roadside Attraction

in GG Pk last July or August where the police showed up and told 
everyone to go down on the beach.  (Unfortunately, this was my early 
rave days so I don't remember whose party it was.)  But once they set up 
the sound system there, the party went off until 5 or 6am, with no 
further hassles from the cops.  Does anyone remember this?

here i am, late at night in the lab, watching those columns drip drip 
drip 

well no, really i'm sitting here in front of the computer.  duh!

right now dj minor minor is on kalx doing some fun stuff.  at the moment, 
it's a slightly disturbing "ambient" selection which i am enjoying very much.

the janitor just wandered in and wanted to know what was making that 
weird noise.  he thought it was the computer and then he saw the radio.  
right now he's mopping the floor, which is very very very dirty.

if anybody's listening and reading, you can call 510-643-KALX (or maybe 
642-KALX..uh..sorry) and say hello to dj minor minor, who is also 
involved with Dust of friday night and rude club staff (or whatever) 
fame.  this party is the only one i know of in quite some time that 
actually booked darcy (dar-cee?  DRC?) who plays kinda hard techno, i'm 
told...but then..i wouldn't know because i haven't heard her play since 
last spring at a New Moon party.

well, i guess you can tell i'm a little bored because those columns are 
taking such a long long long time to drip drip drip.

It's a shame the party got busted, but it was inevitable. With the thick 
trees, the Lincoln side was completely silent. Unfortunately, only about 
ten feet of those trees were between us and the Highway. With all the 
cops going up and down hassling the people on the beach, there wasn't a 
chance. It's a shame as it's a beautiful spot. Several years back, we were 
at the very same spot with the Cacophony folks for a game of tag. The 
moon was full but still, the only real light was from the green light 
sticks strung up randomly in the trees. Probably the eeriest and most 
adrenaline-drenched night I've ever experienced in SF. Anyway, the slight 
familiarity with the terrain certainly didn't hurt when the rangers 
showed up ;) Next time someone tries this spot, I'm bringing light sticks.

So what's the deal with the amplified noise curfew anyway? I can 
understand if it's disturbing residents, but the only thing the SPAZ 
party was sonically disturbing was a hundred feet of highway. That grove 
is a haven for drinking and cruising anyway, music or not. At least with 
the music, the rangers would know where we were in case something 
happened. It's funny how public land can only be enjoyed in *approved* ways.

jmar!

I had a brief vision of the sound shutting down and everyone waiting silent 
while the rangers tried in vain to hunt us down. Perhaps a decoy with a 
boombox next time?

Not that this is a big deal or anything, but I posted a note yesterday to
come say hi to me in the ambient room at Liquid Groove this Saturday....Well
I got a call last night informing me that there isn't going to be an ambient
space there.  The space that the show is taking place in is a big warehouse
with no side rooms.  We did a socalled "ambient" space there before, by
walling off a section with thin plywood we found lying around the room.  It
sucked hard core, because the music had to be as loud or louder than the
main room so the concept of ambient went out the window.  So, bable bable
bable.... Don't look for me in the ambient space to say hi, but if for some
reason you run into me (not that any of you have ever met me or know what I
look like), say hi.  Sorry to take up a band width with seemingly useless
information.

Have fun this weekend.

Rick

        lilred@primenet.com, maxsmith@netcom.com, meclay@netcom.com,
        mjpfister@ucdavis.edu, nrg@ultima.org, piedra@rohan.sdsu.edu,

        ufreel00@mcl.ucsb.edu, sfraves@hyperreal.com, socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Subject: Re: Glade....errr...Mile High
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950601154908.7705B-100000@aldebaran.oac.uci.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.950602105700.1546B-100000@dale.ucdavis.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> > 	be careful.....

> with new talent.   Unknowns are somtimes better, the only prob is it 
> won't attract as many people...

imho, fewer people is bonus. that is, you definately get a better sense 
of "family" when you're not surrounded by 3,000 people. i like going to 
giant raves (ie Narnia in so.cal.) but i feel like smaller raves (ie 
friends n family with a couple hundred folks) is more conducive to a 
high "hugs-factor". 
big name djs are big crowd-drawers, but i know there are plenty of 
underworked, under-rated, ambitious djs out there who are equally 
talented and would spin with three times as much enthusiasm as some 
dude who typically pulls in $300 for a set. plus, my experience has lead 
me to believe that they have really lost the point of the rave 
scene...and somehow have acquired this condescending attitude...

thanks for listening.
jase

> Ocean Beach and just about every beach within 30 miles of SF is a bust.
> The Beaches are off limits after 10pm. 
> 


	Actually, if you set up the speakers right against the dunes 
facing toward the water you can't hear it from the highway. I've been to 
several bust free parties where the sound was set up this way. One of 
them even went well into the morning. I also went to an ocean beach party 
(was it Ananda?) where the sound was set up in the middle of the beach 
facing toward the cliffhouse. The cops came but I think it took them at 
least till daylight. Ah yes, that 10pm law doesn't apply to ocean beach 
thank god. 

					peace,
					-x

some report it as agony or depression.  perhaps that is why knowing
exactly who one is is not more popular.  (my deskside dictionary gives
the primary definition of "care" as "mental distress and grief";
"attention or solicitude" is only the 2ndary definition...)  confronted
with this knowledge, one is faced with the choice to accept or deny.
typically the latter is humanly easiest.

				-steve

your 
> body does not know what to expect.  Herbal E is for people who 
people who 
> have never taken MDMA; it's kind of like the idea that gurana (in 
> large amounts) used to put me off my nut until I started taking 
speed 
> then it was like no buzz at all.  Personally a good strong cup of 
coffee 
> and a few big bong hits is the same as E anyway so whats th 
epoint?
> 
Having done the herbal E thing I was most disappointed. However I 
have 
heard that it can really potentiate a real E trip. Can anyone 
verify/debunk this(from actual experience please...)

                                          Black Adder

        You should try moving to montreal where i am! :) Hopefully not for
long though....There really IS a chemical 'problem' that people go through
during the winter and it's tied in with wanting to 'hibernate' plus lack of
daylight. From what i've read), sunlight directly causes the pineal gland
to _stop_ the release of a hormone, melatonin, which affects mood and
supposedly retards sexual activity. (!) (thus when spring comes, the sun
follows, so do the hormones, thus spring fever..)  Then again i read this
in one of those time-life books...
        brad

From: ascend@ix.netcom.com (Gregory Sandler)
Subject: Thanx-(from Beautiful People)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello everyone!,
	This is Greg, (so you know who's writing this!) First I have to 
say thank you to all the people who came out last night. You guys were 
beautiful people! I can't even count the number of times my body went 
numb because of the vibe! All of us with Beautiful People were very, 
very happy to see everyone having such a great time! We also have to 
thank the dj's for a night of intense, beautiful music!!!! They were all 
so good!!! And thanx to the crowd, for letting them take you to higher 
levels!! I still can't get over the vibe last night!!!!!!! Special thanx 
to Randy for a beautiful chill/ambient room!! And the next special thanx 
goes to Michael Clay, for the wonderful visuals!! :)
	We put soooo much time into that party, and if you were there 
you could probably figure out why, and for what! It took us two whole 
days of busting ass, to set up that party! And it was well worth it!!! 
Also, we wanted to thank you guys for not destroying the location. We 
didn't see one tag! However I did spend the entire morning scraping gum, 
and stickers off the floor! But I didn't really mind, I was on 
afterglow!!!!! 
	We want to apologize for the over-crowding! What happened was 
that we reached a certain capacity, and then didn't let anyone else in. 
But some dishonest people broke into the party, via a different room, 
and entered the party without us counting them. So we had about 50-75 
people that got in after we stopped letting anyone in. That is why it 
was overcrowded! 
	Then we ended up with a line of I think around 150 people, that 
dispite our encouragement to go home, wanted to wait in line to get in! 
So, what were we supposed to do? The party was packed, 150 people 
outside waiting to get in, and people sneaking in some other way. Gee, 
talk about crowd control! So, for the line we let one person in every 
time one person would leave. And because they had to wait forever to get 
in, we cut the price of admission down to $5, (not $10.) So everyone was 
happy, and that is what matters!!!!! So, sorry about the wait, and we 
hope that everyone had the best time in the world!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
	In total, to everyone who came down for Beautiful People, you 
people were soooooo beautiful!!!!! Thanx!!!!! We'll see you soon!!!
	In fact, we are doing a party with MESS and Cloud Factory. That 
is this Sat., free and outdoors!!!! See you there!!!

Peace, love, and harmony to all beautiful people!!!!!

Greg


We love you!!!

Hi all, I've been thinking: all you DJ's out there, has anyone ever thought of
mixing together rock records with a danceable beat? I think it'd be sooo cool
if someone were to take advantage of all those beautiful guitar licks, vocals,
and drumbeats that are out there on vinyl... not that I'm not already a techno 
and house fan already--the music's great--but I just wonder if anyone had ever
or does mix in non-dance records...actually, perhaps I'm just being naive, and
it goes on all the time...hmmm let me know if I'm on target here.  I'm sort of
thinking along the lines of what U2 did recently, when they let DJs remix
songs from Achtung Baby...
Love to you all (extra doses to all the great vibers at Beautiful People!)
Timothy

While hanging out with  some friends at the beach after a rave a 
discussion of peterpan and raving came up.
We thought peterpan was pretty trippy and thought he was pretty ravey, by 
how he encouraged others to have happy thoughts so they can fly.  Also, 
thought it was pretty cool the way he never got older (excluding that 
hook movie).  
Anybody out there feel like they are flying when your raving, and I don't 
really mean physically although if you have experienced this, it would be 
interesting to hear.  Also wondering if others feel that raving keeps you 
from getting older (captain crunch).  Once again this doesn't 
neccessarily mean physically.
This also led to a discussion on raving in the future with the 
possibility of raving in an anti-gravity room.  I thought it would be 
great for ambient music, wasn't so sure about the rest.


peter

  (5.67b/IDA-1.5 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>); Mon, 5 Jun 1995 03:25:42 +1000

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 5 Jun 1994 10:25:40 +1000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
Subject: MDMA/Alien Factory review
Cc: ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Alien Factory LIVE - MDMA-2
---------------------------

WOW!!  The promoters actually came through,  and I picked up the tickets
to MDMA-2.   The tickets are something to behold.   They are laminated
Mag stripe cards like ATM cards with the Alien Factory promotion artwork
on the card.    Cost of the ticket was $54 from Central records.

So,   as Sat evening approacheth,   I get word that this one was going
to be way out of the city which was a 2 hour train ride to Richmond
(Not California).

We arrive at the train station only to learn that it's going to be a
2 KM walk to the rave.

Long before we saw it,  we heard it...   "Happy Hardcore" was booming
into the cloudy night.

The line was short,  and got in very quickly.   As we approached
security they were keeping the tickets - BUMMER!!   What a great
souvenir they would make.

This place was HUGE...   No estimate of the number of people that showed
up,   but I estimate about 7000 people.   There was no chill room to
speak of,  but the people doing the lasers let us keep our stuff
backstage.

About 15 minutes later,   Alien Factory were starting up,  and played
some of the most wicked sick trance I've heard in a long time.

I was somewhat disappointed that their set was only 45 minutes long,
but what they DID okay was really great.

After  Alien Factory's set,   Paul Holden took to the turn tables and
laid down some incredible Happy Hardcore

I went off BIG TIME,  dispite that I also went out to Energy on Friday
evening as well....   I saw MANY people there who said they saw me at
"The happiest people...",  and "Smerf Village".

At one point,  I was dancing so hard literally trancing out,  that one
girl pulled me up on the stage to dance with the group.    Holy shit!!
The view from the stage,  mixed with the lasers made for some of the
most unforgettable visuals I'll experience in a long time.   To look out
there at the thousands of smiling faces was something to behold.

The energy at this rave was like nothing I've ever seen.   Here I was,
at Sydney's BIGGEST RAVE of the year,   literally going insane....

As usual,   the same happy hardcore songs were played.   I swear,  there
aren't that many Happy Hardcore songs out there,   I keep hearing them
over and over....

A little later on,   I went out to get some water,   and when I pulled
out my money to check if I had enough,   one of the security guards led
me away from the group and demanded that I show them the contents of my
wallet.   I asked what they were looking for,   but they said I had a
"baggie" - I convinced them that they were wrong.

Back to dancing...  As I returned,   people walked up to me,  shaking my
hand,  saying they have never seen anyone so old "Get off" like I was
doing.   They would say...  You're fuckin SICK!!!   As I approached the
front,   people led me up to the stage,  where there were about 3 or 4
people dancing.    Even the security guards were smiling and looking at
me dancing up there.... A couple of girls grabbed my hands and we danced
around up there on the stage like there was no tommorrow.   Even the
sound crew joined in,   as well as a few security guards..   It was
simply incredible...

The lasers,  mixed in with the smoke machines,   made for some eye
popping visual.

As dawn approached,  the crowd still stayed the same....   energy level
somewhat increased at this point.   But as late morning approached,
people were leaving,   and the last DJ spun some housey trancey stuff.
he DJ (Mr. Groove) was from the UK.

It eventually ended,  and we made it to the train station OK,   and
headed back into town....

This was the BIGGEST rave I've ever been to in my life...   What a way
to end my Australian trip..

I leave for the Bay Area on Monday,  and as I'm typing this up now,
before I leave for the USA,  I want to get in this report.    I also
went to recovery,  danced until about 2 am.

I eventually got home,   typed in this report and got it up there to
the net....

Cheers

Thank you to all you wonderful people for joining me at Liquid Groove. I
had a glorious time talkning to people and dancing with everyone.
Because I was responsible for sound I had to be very sober. Thank god I
was because the power went out twice. But being quick on my feet and
having the awsome SIMON as the dj, recovery was quick and smooth.

If anyone ever has the chance to talk to DUTCH at a party. Do so. He's
been in a real good mood lately and is looking very healthy.

All the DJ's just PHUCKED IT UP last night.

Great music from KEN, SCOTT, DUTCH, SIMON, and KARISMA my budddy. I hope
to see all of you at COME-UNITY. I can't miss SIMON and MARKIE in one
night at such a great place.

Well I just finished breaking down. I haven't slept for 39 hours but
It's such a georgeous day I'm thinking about going out and flying my
kite here at the river here in sac.

LOVE TO ALL  :() Andrew----------------------------------SOUNDGOD@iccse.com

Although my stay at Wicked was brief, I'd have to say the  beat, visuals and
general mood on the floor was some of the vest vibes I've had in a while. 
I went out with a few friends (1st. timers) and since Antioch was a tad out
of the way Wicked seemed to be the next best thing...
I learned never take 1st time ravers to a 21 and up rave. 
Maybe it's just me, I've been in the scene since late 92' and I guess the
term Rave has a whole different meaning to the new generation.  While I was
grooving on the sound and vibes (I was the one in all black & the Cuban
Gaints B-ball cap) they seemed to be interested in the people & things around
them... 
        But I had a G-r-r-r-r-eat time...

Smile o meter:

      Hugs:  (plenty O this a time)                9Smiles
    Vibes:  (never slowed a beat)                 8Smiles
    Space: (A tad bit croweded at times)     6Smiles
PLUR factor: (i've seen a lot more at other raves)
                      6.5Smiles

Overall: a sound 7.  Good tunes, good fun, pretty decent trip too
=)

Adam.

 Since the weather has gotten warmer , I've decided to start the
"SFRaves South Bay Lunch" again.

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules. At special times,
we've met at a restaurant ( no boom-box , tho' .... ).

 It's every Wednesday , depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I hope to see you folks there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFRaves South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

>
>Hi all, I've been thinking: all you DJ's out there, has anyone ever thought of
>mixing together rock records with a danceable beat? I think it'd be sooo cool
>if someone were to take advantage of all those beautiful guitar licks, vocals,
>and drumbeats that are out there on vinyl... not that I'm not already a techno 
>and house fan already--the music's great--but I just wonder if anyone had ever
>or does mix in non-dance records...actually, perhaps I'm just being naive, and
>it goes on all the time...hmmm let me know if I'm on target here.  I'm sort of
>thinking along the lines of what U2 did recently, when they let DJs remix
>songs from Achtung Baby...
>Love to you all (extra doses to all the great vibers at Beautiful People!)
>Timothy

My old roommate dj Rigatony sometimes mixes some old Led Zepplin tunes with
house music.  He says it's a little difficult because the timing on rock
tunes isn't perfect like computer generated house music.  It sounded really
cool though.  I've also heard him spinning ambient and using two copies of
"Riders on the Storm" (I think that the name of it) by the Doors, and having
them perfectly sinked up, except for one is just barly slower than the
other.  He uses his finger to push the slower one til it's even with the
other then lets it slowly fall back.  The effect is a totally trippy flange
sound that is produced although the sound is not in ethier record.  I'm sure
my description doesn't do much to really describe the amazing sound this
technique produces, but I know atleast the dj's know what I'm talking about.
If I'm not clear enough, ask a dj to show you sometime.  Later.

Rick

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jun  5 09:40:30 1995

From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199506051642.JAA10330@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Who went to Wicked???
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I went to Wicked.

In fact if some of you did go you might have seen me.
I was the "door diva" from 11:30 to about 3:30

(For those of you who don't know, the door diva does the "guest list"
as in who is on and who is not :)

This was the first Wicked back at King Street after a long hiatus.
It seemed to me that the security was a lot mellower, they seem to remember
me from "the bad old days" (The crew had a major confrontation with this
security team in the DJ booth at Townsend about a year ago that almost came
to blows) The head guys said something to me like "It's been a long time" I 
said "Yeah, long enough to forget the past and start a fresh".  Suffice it to
say that we had a rather good party which was more or less uneventful.  
I'm sure some people who did not have proper ID were turned away but it is a
fact of like that you have to have _some_ form of ID to go to clubs in San
Francisco,  this is not true of undergrounds or renegades and there eill be
plenty of them this summer as well.

Anyway, I must say that this Wicked was definitely heading back in the
direction that the parties should be going, lots of smiles, lots of
freaky people, lots of good music and a good amount of Vibe, although
this is generally a function of the attendees so we do need to work on that.
The DJ line-up was 

		Chaulky-	He played some really good stuff, I enjoyed
				his set, still I would like to see him
				in a slot other than opening which is
				a hard slot to fill, still he got the job done
				which was to get the crowd moving.

		Spun-		Jason play a good moving set but didn't seem
				to get into the groove that I know he's capable
				of.  I was working a lot during this time so
				I didn't get to hear most of it.

		Markie-		The man of the hour for this party, he got the
				crowd moving and the Vibe flowing, It was nice
				to experience the Trade Marked Wicked Locomotive
				The type of set that urges you to "get on board"
				This train is headed "out".  And Markie, the
				engineer at the helm drove us in a good way.  
				It felt good.

		Emma-		The first time I ever heard her.  She's an
				excellent DJ, though she doesn't seem to have
				mixing abilities that we are use too at a wicked
				still this might have been an off night but
				the Music that she did play as FULL ON!  She 
				worked the crown and continued where markie
				left off.



All in all I believe this is a step in the right direction for Wicked as
a whole.  The next party will be July 8, hopefully summer will be in full
effect here :)

Just a short note to say thank you to all those that put on Beautiful People.  The Dj's had me dancing longer than I had for a LONG LONG time.  And the Vibe..
people were SO friendly.  Met all sorts of wonderful people :)  My only  complaint, and it isn't much of one, is that the chill room didn't have pillows or anything comfortable to sit on except for the cold hard ground.

Went to Wicked on Saturday night.  Haven't been to a Wicked in a LONG time because of some unpleasant experiences that I had had.  Well, deciding to give Wicked a second chance was the best decision i could have made.  The music was going off!  I loved the intimate space.  The visuals had my brain reeling.  But by far, what made this party for me were the people.  I couldn't tell you how many times ppl just came up, sat down and started talking to me.  How many smiles ppl gave me.  By the time i left the party (~7am) I was on a natural high.  I went to sleep with a smile and woke up with a smile.  Thanks to all those who made it a wonderful night (Bruce, Kimberly, Allison, Christina, Amy, etc.) and thanks to the Wicked crew.  I WILL be at your next party :)

Peace - Love - Unity - Respect
They are more than just words


--
Jorge Montoya
fx277@kanga.ins.cwru.edu

On May 30,  4:27pm, ameba@netcom.com wrote:
> This week's line-up is:  Tracy
>                          Spun
>                          Jan Cooley

I was there with a friend last Friday & had a -great- time.  We
showed up a little early (11:30 or so) and all that was open at the
time was the front room, so we hung out until the music started in
the middle room & basement.  The basement was frantic -- I pulled a
lot of energy from the people in that room.

Then we headed upstairs to the middle room (sorry, I don't know their
proper names :-) ) and I hit on a natural high just dancing around.
It was several hours later when I finally took a break & walked
around a bit -- my clothes looked like I had been hit by a water
cannon :-)

One minor nit to pick..

> As usual anyone from SF Raves gets in free on our guest list.  Just
> tell the girl at the door that you are from SF Raves and it will be
> all good.

This did not work -at all-.  They had no idea what I was talking
about.  If this is supposed to work, someone needs to educate the
door staff (or just put SFRaves on the paper guest list).  They
said it was a "nice try".  :-)

It was only my 3rd time ever to 1015 and already I recognize a number
of faces from previous weeks.  I didn't meet any SFRavers (that I
know of) but hope to bump into people next time.  If you see me
there, come say 'hi'.  [A picture is in my home page so you can
recognize me :-) ]

Kudos to AJ, Kevin, Brian, and the guy doing the visuals, they were
COOL.  Also the unnamed asian-woman-in-black-atop-the-amp whose
energy kept me going for hours..

Until next week,
Allan

>Where is the closet place to Downtown S.F. that I can hear this station on
>Fri. Nights??  I cant seem to get it to come in on my radio.
>Where is it coming from? Does anyone have the phone # for 89.7?
>
>If I cant get it to come in.. I was hoping someone could please tape the show
>for me Fri 10pm-2am............................................

I get 89.7 (KFJC, Los Altos Hills CA, Foothill Jr College) in Glen Park
(well, actually Sunnyside, which is near Glen Park). The farther south
you go in the city, the better the reception is. Basically, you have
to get away from KPOO (89.5, SF??) in order to get KFJC.

Also, I have a better than average preamp/tuner and I also have
amplified antenna. This may have something to do with my ability to
hear KFJC in SF; sometimes I can only get it in mono. Other times
I have to use the high-frequency blend button to get it in stereo
w/o too much noise....

And no, I can't promise that I'll be around on fri evening from 10-2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

I gotta say that Beautiful People was one of the absolute best times I've 
had in a long time now.  the vibe was at an incredible all time high.  I 
can't even remember the last time I saw so many happy people.  I guess 
the smile policy was strongly enforced at the door.  Although by the time 
I got there I had missed DRC's set, I saw the end of Graeme and he played 
some pretty cool fast acid stuff.  Then Trent came on and just blew 
everyone away.  An amazing set.The records were all so completely tweaky 
with some of the strangest and trippiest shit.  Lots of times the muzik 
slowed a bit to give people a chance to space out abit before completely 
going mental.  I hads such a good time on the dance floor that i never 
did get to experience the chill rooms.  great party!!

I checked out scambled on sunday for a little while.  Never been to that 
111 mina st location.  I really enjoyed it.  Nice hardwood dancefloor, 
pretty decent sound system, good music, friendly vibe.  
Could use a few more people, so if anyone is up for dancing during the 
day on sunday, check it out.  I was only there for about 2 hours, as I 
was still in recuperation mode, and felt the need to enjoy some of the 
beautiful weather outside.  There were only about 15-20 people while I 
was there.  Most were dancing, which was pretty cool and made it seem 
like more.  
I do sometimes miss those boogy buffet partys.  With sunsets soon to be 
every week, nothing will be missed.  Its nice to have some alternatives, 
if the weather is crappy and sunset gets cancelled.
Of course it doesn't compare to sunset (imo), but still nice to have if I 
get a sudden dance crave on a sunday during the day.  Thought I might 
have heard someone say, it went on sat morning as well.


peter

sorta put everything off until after finals.   I thought for a minute 
about Sep 23 (I think that was the weekend) because of the Autumn

to have it during the summer.

hey all!

well, i haven't posted for a while, so here goes, a bit of a summary of 
parties and rave-related-in-the-broad-sense-only tidbits:

went to dust last friday.  still at the loading dock, tho' i hear they're 
moving soon.  yeah, the loading dock lounge itself doesn't do all that 
much for me (too gray), but i like the cushy dance floor (sure beats the 
cement i'm used to!) and the booths.. the space isn't bad for a friday 
night mellow party.  alex spun last friday and played an excellent set, 
but unfortunately he may have blown some speakers :( ..  it was really 
good to dance..i'd been pretty depressed (more later) and unmotivated, and 
dancing really got some creative juices flowing... i may be 
there friday, and i have shortish green hair, so if you see me, say hi...

weekend before i went to Carnival in the mission, and got some grand 
ideas in my head about a rave/dj float next year...would be fun as hell 
and hopefully easy to do!  (just hope they don't have some regulations 
about having to dance in formation!)  i figure it's really appropriate 
cuz it's a celebration of int'l musick and dance after all...
favorite part of Carnival: at the end of the Wise Fool contingent, there 
was a clown dresseed in a suit, i think, with a stick attached to his 
head, and at the end of the stick was a dollar bill, and as he kep moving 
forward reaching for the dollar, he dragged the earth (half-deflated) 
behind him in a dump truck...

so as i said i've been depressed lately, part of it  related to the fact 
that the death warrant was signed for Mumia Abu Jamal, a radical 
AFrican-Amer. activist and reporter in philadelphia who was framed for 
the death of a police officer.  he's been on death row for years, did not 
have a fair trial, and is now scheduled to be put to death and it's just 
reminding me more and more about the power of racism and the state in 
quashing dissent.  so, if anyone's interested or can make it, there's a 
rally/press conf. for mumia friday, june 9 at 4:30 at the federal bldg. 
in sf.

well, take care everyone,
with love and @,
monicat

 Just a reminder about today's South Bay Lunch ( first one for 1995 ) -
 
>  For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is basically
> me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
> the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
> nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules. At special times,
> we've met at a restaurant ( no boom-box , tho' .... ).
> 
>  It's every Wednesday , depending on my own work schedule , the
> weather , and park usage . I hope to see you folks there!

From: Derek Hansford <dhans@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Sad state of Cleveland report
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9506070951.A15877-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Not sure how many of you will be interested in this, but I feel like 
sharing it(if nothing else it should make you happier to be in SF)...

I went back to Cleveland to visit some friends and family, thinking that 
we'd go out dancing and I'd get to hear some of that hardcore and 
breakbeat that I loved so much from my undergrad days. We decided to head 
down to "The Flats" on Fri. to find a good club, and to make a long story 
short, it just plain sucked. For starters, the only club playing anything 
approaching dance music had about three people in it, including the 
doorman. Besides that and the over-abundance of drunk jock-wannabes, the 
city decided that it made sense to rip out all of the streets at once and 
cause major headaches and tensions. Ended up going home without dancing 
(heard about a hip-hop underground party too far away to go to though)

Decided to wait until "The church" on Sunday to try again. This used to 
be the greatest bastion for dancing in Cleveland (besides the few 
underground clubs that lasted about a month each). My friends and I were 
determined to have a good time, so we started dancing as soon as we got 
there. (Un?)fortunately, we were the only ones on the huge floor, so we 
got to be divas for a while (I think it's even funnier when you look 
completely normal:-) When they finally turned up the volume at midnight, 
the jocks got on the floor, along with those of us actually trying to 
dance and have fun. The music was good, but they tried WAY too much to 
mix it up: house straight into breakbeat into some weird gabber/jungle, 
back into house, etc. It ended up sounding very choppy and wore me out 
too quickly. The good part of the club was the back room, where they had 
a cool little house/acid jazz thing going. spent most of the rest of our 
time their, but the volume was overwhelming and we left early.

Overall, I think i may just have expected too much and may just be 
wasting your bandwidth, so I'll go now.

Love,
Derek (who may actually be able to go out this summer!)


Derek Hansford 		  || "Ah yes, spring cleaning. Just one more battle
440 Evans Hall 		  ||	in the war against dirt and dishevelment."
UC Berkeley, 94720	  ||			The Tick
(510) 642-1101 		  || 		
dhans@uclink2.berkeley.edu||

not to mention Cyberspace also consider the current hoop-la over 
"gangsta rap", how long before "drug music" like techo/rave
is banned from the Internet by people who think it promotes sex and drug orgies.

come to that, seriously Fax, call or write your Senator TODAY.

called their senators I assure you it WOULD make a difference, 10% of sfraves
is over 40 people, better yet Fax and call, each fax is suppose to count

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 01:37:31 -0700
From: Cyber Rights <cyber-rights@Sunnyside.COM>
To: Multiple recipients of list <cyber-rights@cpsr.org>
Subject: ALERT: Senate speeds towards Telecom Reform bill and Decency Act [cr-95/6/6]

To: stop314@panix.com

========================================================================
       CAMPAIGN TO STOP THE EXON/GORTON COMMUNICATIONS DECENCY ACT

	Update: -Senate changes gears, we're caught with little time
		-What You Can Do Now (US and non-US citizens)

        CAMPAIGN TO STOP THE UNCONSTITUTIONAL COMMUNICATIONS DECENCY ACT
			   June 6, 1995

      PLEASE WIDELY REDISTRIBUTE THIS DOCUMENT WITH THIS BANNER INTACT
		 REDISTRIBUTE ONLY UNTIL June 20, 1995
	     REPRODUCE THIS ALERT ONLY IN RELEVANT FORUMS

      Distributed by the Voters Telecommunications Watch (vtw@vtw.org)

------------------------------------------------------------------------
CONTENTS
	The Latest News
	What You Can Do Now -- U.S. and non-U.S. citizens
	Senate Contact List
        For More Information
        List Of Participating Organizations

------------------------------------------------------------------------
THE LATEST NEWS

The Senate is ready to act on the Telecommunications Reform Bill this
week, perhaps as soon as Wednesday, June 7th.  We had thought the
Counter Terrorism bill would take all week, but the Senate changed its
schedule without consulting us. :-)

(We sincerely apologize for issuing another alert on the heels of the
prior one, but the Senate's readiness to move on this legislation was
not anticipated.  We'll watch out for such a situation again and avoid
releasing two alerts to close together in the future. We also apologize
for the length of this Alert, but it contains the entire Senate contact
info.)

Note that there are few people who don't know about the bill.  However
if you are unfamiliar with the bill, take a moment to retrieve the
materials listed in the "For More Information" section.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
WHAT YOU CAN DO NOW -- U.S. and non-U.S. citizens

The Telecomm Reform Bill, will, in all likelihood, include either the
Exon Amendment (formerly the Communications Decency Act) or the Leahy
Amendment. It is essential that the Leahy language be substituted for
Exon's, and therefore it is essential:

1. That all citizens call or fax their Senators as soon as possible.
   There is no time for written letters and email is too easily
   discounted or ignored. Non-U.S. citizens should contact Vice
   President Gore.  Note, if you decide to send a fax, you'll want to
   write an expanded version of the statement below.

   It's very important that you always be cool, collected, and polite.

   U.S. citizens:

	<call your Senators' offices, contact info below>
	"Hello, Senator ________'s office"
	"Hi, I'm a constituent and would like to register my
	 opinion on the Telecommunications Reform bill to the 		
	 Senator."
	"Hold On please.  Alright, go ahead."
	"Please vote to remove the Communications Decency Act provision
         (Title 4 of S652) from the Telecomm Reform bill and 
	 replace it with the Leahy alternative (S714).  My name and 
	 address is ________."
	"Thanks for calling." 
	<click>

   Non-U.S. citizens:
	<call, fax, or send email to Vice President Gore>
	"Dear Vice President Gore,

	 The world looks to the United States as one leader in 
	 developing a Global Information Infrastructure.  Title 4 of
	 the Telecomm Reform bill (the Communications Decency Act)
     	 imperils that leadership.  Please work to remove it from the
	 Telecomm Reform bill (S652) and replace it with Senator
 	 Leahy's sensible alternative (S714).  I'm calling from
	 ____________."


2. Send VTW a note telling us what you did. If you contacted your two
   Senators, send a letter to vtw@vtw.org with a subject line of
   "XX ack" where "XX" is your state.  For example:

	To: vtw@vtw.org
	Subject: OH ack

	I called my Ohio Senators and expressed my opinion.

   If you contact Senators outside your state, please let us know what
   state you're from.  

   If you contacted Vice President Gore, send a letter to vtw@vtw.org with
   a subject line of "gore ack".  For example:

	To: vtw@vtw.org
	Subject: gore ack

	I called VP Gore and expressed my opinion.  I'm from France.

   An automatic responder will return an updated contact tally.

3. Forward this Alert to relevant forums on other online services and
   BBS's.  Check the letter you get back to see which Senators are
   underrepresented by citizen contacts. Forward the Alert to any
   friends and colleagues in those states.

4. If you haven't yet signed the petition to support Sen. Leahy,
   do so now.  Send mail to vtw@vtw.org with a subject line of
   "send petition" for directions.

5. Congratulate yourself!  Your two-minute activism joins that of many
   thousands of others over the past two months. 

------------------------------------------------------------------------
SENATE CONTACT LIST

Vice President Gore can be reached at:

	White House comment line
		Telephone: (202) 456-1111 (M-F 9-5 EST)
		Facsimile: (202) 456-2461 (M-F 9-5 EST)
		Email:	    vice-president@whitehouse.gov

FOR MORE INFORMATION

For more information on the Communications Decency Act, visit the
following resources:

Web Sites
	URL:http://www.panix.com/vtw/exon/
	URL:http://epic.org/
	URL:http://www.eff.org/pub/Alerts/
	URL:http://www.cdt.org/cda.html

FTP Archives 
	URL:ftp://ftp.cdt.org/pub/cdt/policy/freespeech/00-INDEX.FREESPEECH
	URL:ftp://ftp.eff.org/pub/Alerts/

Gopher Archives:
	URL:gopher://gopher.panix.com/11/vtw/exon
	URL:gopher://gopher.eff.org/11/Alerts

Email:
	vtw@vtw.org (put "send help" in the subject line)
	cda-info@cdt.org (General CDA information)
	cda-stat@cdt.org (Current status of the CDA)

LIST OF PARTICIPATING ORGANIZATIONS

In order to use the net more effectively, several organizations have
joined forces on a single Congressional net campaign to stop the
Communications Decency Act.

In alphabetical order:

American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU)		  infoaclu@aclu.org
American Communication Association (ACA)   comminfo@cavern.uark.edu
American Council for the Arts

     Dear all:
     
     Due to various movements (in and out of state) onwards, forwards and 
     so on, this Friday, June 9th will be the last weekly dust.  It will be 
     at the same place (loading dock), same time (10 - 3) and I hope that 
     you will join us.  Once again, a big thank you to all those who have 
     supported us through cyberspace, in person, in thought.  Doing this 
     has been an extremely gratifying experience for all of us.
     
     This week we will have Jonah Sharp (Spacetime Continuum), Lewis 
     (Vertigo) and our resident John Carel spinning.
     
     We hope to bring you other dust related events in the future, but for 
     now, Dj Minor will be joining forces with Philip (from 8th House) to 
     start a new venture -- look out for it, it will be happening soon.  
     Gateway Systems i.e. John Carel & Dave Abel, will be teaming up with 
     Clare Korich to bring you a series of summer parties entitled "Light." 
      And myself, I will be going to law school, probably on the East 
     Coast.
     
     So come down and wish us luck!  It has been great communicating with 
     all of you.  Have a great summer.

Well I just heard it on the news boys and girls...it's snowing in the 
tahoe forrest down to the 4000' elevation mark.  UGHHH!!!!  The site is 
ALL the way up at 6000 feet.  I guess that means 6-7' snow drifts.   
Hmmm.  I still think the weekend of July 28-30 is still very doable tho.  
The snow should be melted and it will be warmer however it won't be too 
dry from the new growth yet.  How does that work for all you guys?  
September could still work but I think that it is too late in the 
season.  People will be back in school and it will be much drier up 
there.  However if all you people think you could make it for the Sept 22-24 
date (Autumn Solstice) then please tell me...if school is not a problem 
(or work) then please let me now, that way I still know it is a viable 
option.  Thanks alot and I hope to hear from you all soon.

I'm looking forward to Come/Unity tonite & even hope to meet some
SFravers there.  Ambitious, I know.  But my question:  what is the
music?  I am too new to the scene to know the DJ's styles "by name".

We were at Cat's Grill for Acid Jazz on Monday Night, and it was a
good time -- we arrived at 12:00 and stayed until ~3:30.  Had a few
drinks, hung out, danced, etc.  The music was sort of a bummer though
-- I had a hard time picking out any variety.  I'm used to that style
being the slow stuff they play to give everyone a breather..  :-)

But for tonight -- if you're at 1015 and see a 6' tall white guy,
glasses, dark curly hair, wearing lots of black, dancing around with
a long-haired redhead, come say hi.  :-)  [even if it's not us
they'll appreciate it]

Also, for some pre-dance pizza eats we're going to the 20 Tank
Brewery on 11th.  Should be a good night.

Allan

> 
> I'm looking forward to Come/Unity tonite & even hope to meet some
> SFravers there.  Ambitious, I know.  But my question:  what is the
> music?  I am too new to the scene to know the DJ's styles "by name".

Generally CU are pretty much House music as in progressive, some acid
some trance, it tends to be very dancable and fun, getting trancy near
the end.


> 
> We were at Cat's Grill for Acid Jazz on Monday Night, and it was a
> good time -- we arrived at 12:00 and stayed until ~3:30.  Had a few
> drinks, hung out, danced, etc.  The music was sort of a bummer though
> -- I had a hard time picking out any variety.  I'm used to that style
> being the slow stuff they play to give everyone a breather..  :-)

Usually CUs are "repetative beats" type of music where one DJ rollls 
into the other.


> 
> But for tonight -- if you're at 1015 and see a 6' tall white guy,
> glasses, dark curly hair, wearing lots of black, dancing around with
> a long-haired redhead, come say hi.  :-)  [even if it's not us
> they'll appreciate it]

I'll be there, look for the Big African American guy dancing his a*s off :)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jun  7 20:05:25 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id UAA27669; Wed, 7 Jun 1995 20:05:25 -0700

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 20:14:18 -0700
From: kia@ghidora.planetx.org (kia)
Message-Id: <199506080314.UAA13693@ghidora.planetx.org>
To: ecto@python.magnet.ca, THROCKA@aol.com
Subject: Re: RE: Herbal Ecstasy
Cc: SFRAVES@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

THROCKA@aol.com says:
> does anyone know the relation between ephedra, ephedrine and pseudoephedrine
> hydrochloride? I know the last one makes me oh so very sleepy and feels like
> herion in many ways.
>

Ephedrine a the derivative of the ephedra (Ma Huang/Ephedra Equisetina) 
plant.  Its chemical structure looks like this (excuse my horrible ascii 
graphics):

        _____     OH
       / --- \    |  
      < \   / >---CH-CH-NH-CH3
       \_____/       |
                     CH3
                  
2-methylamino-1-phenyl-1-propanol (ephedrine)

(note it looks chemically similar to methamphetamine, which lacks the -OH)

Pseudoephedrine hydrochloride (sudafed, suphedrine) is the hydrochloride 
salt of pseudoephedrine and has the same formula as ephedrine, but it is
a different enantiomer (the arrangement of the chemical bonds is slightly
different, making it the d-form of the chemical), and it reacts differently 
in your body.

The Merck index lists l-ephedrine as a bronchodilator and d-pseudoephedrine
as a decongestant.  Ephedrine and ma huang are often used as stimulants,
as well.

I hope that answers your question.  :)

k

(recovering compulsive Merck reader)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: rhea@xinet.COM (Rhea Gossett)
Subject: ComeUnity, still in my heart!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Thank you everyone for a wonderful night at Come-Unity.
I got there at 11:00, stayed till the end, crossed back across
the Bay Bridge for a lovely *early* breakfast at Dave's diner
(I had the "Nutty Buck" cakes; try and say that fast). Home for a
shower, and now I'm at work - but the music's still in my
head, and I'm still raving, thinking...

Just when I thought I "understood" raves; when I feared they
could no longer surprise me - we take off last night with such
energy and grace.  Making me feel so strangely alive, like my
first time raving, but *not* the first time - somehow capturing
time in a loop, and letting me begin again!

I was helping chaperone two "acquaintances" (now friends)
who had never been to a rave, never done X (I still call it that, as
it sounds so deliciously sinister, an *always unknown* variable)...
I was so excited for them, so thrilled at their delight - I forgot to
worry about myself, forgot to implicate myself in my usual litanies
of hesitance and insecurity.

I forgot my usual expectations, and remembered how to BE.
Or, re-learned, maybe, no matter the forgetting.  It is such
freedom to be both brave and tender.  I am still tingling!

Thank you for letting me feel confident.  Thank you for letting
me move amongst you, and dance, and watch you dancing, and smile,
and look into your eyes, and touch your sweaty, glistening shoulders
with my fingertips!

I feel glorious and strong, and powerful, and grateful.



Rhea

ComeUnity! Once the rave of the "devoted" hardcore (people who didn't have
jobs the next day or didn't care that they had jobs :) has now become
mainstream.  I arrived at 3:30 expecting to see things thinned out a bit,
I didn't expect a line half-way around the block.  Sometimes club-courtesy
comes in handy :) Any way the place was Choc-O--Bloc Packed with people.
The Vibe was heavy and even though I saw many a new face mixed with the old,
many received first lessons and from the look of it learned them well.

I missed everyones set but Markie but he was  "doin it" when I got there
and continued for the rest of the morning, This was one of those parties where
I can completely straight but got that contact E buzz, complete with the
fire up my spine, blurry vision , the works, I love when this happens, I just
goes to show you, it's not how much drugs you injest it's how much vibe is
generated.  Many shouts out to all that I saw.



P.S.  Poppy, if your out there please give me a call I have
a question to ask you.

       daily.

     * the Global Party Network Buzzline - 415.568.1338

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Wednesday night mid-3am - "Cataklyzmol Pixel" ambient,
       experimental & noize - w/DJ Unknown, KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Geoff wisely says: Once the rave of the "devoted" hardcore (people who 
didn't have jobs the next day or didn't care that they had jobs :)..

Wow! What a great happening Come/Unity. The vibe was just short of 
ecstatic. Big smiles, and great grins reaffirmed my belief that the SF 
rave scene still has what it takes!

I walked into work at 10:00am , on 2 hours sleep,... tired, but shining in 
the "warm afterglow"!

It definitely was worth it :) Blinky blinky blink!

Rave on Folks... Sy

...here's some food for thought :

If there's any certain philosophy that comes from spending long periods 
of time in silence among strangers in line : or spending long periods of 
time in friction among strangers in sweat :  I've found mine to be the 
idea of Creativity and Respect.

House music/culture is an unconventional, underground ((for now)) form of 
youth culture. There's a lot of freedom and the rare oppurtanity in that 
moment to do things that wouldn't be all that welcome in other areas of a 
person's life... everyone has their own unique interpataion of the Punk 
Monk Performance Art Piece... or to put it another way, you don't necesarilly 
need a prom date to go to a rave. 

Just as a person can use whatever space he has to it's fullest, there's 
also a certain amount of respect given to the people around him for their 
own space and an etiquete involved in such matters as line-jumping, threading 
through the crowd, and finding a space to move. This is one of the 
instances where I freely give respect without waiting to have it earned. 

>From my experiences in San Francisco, I've found that quite a few of the 
regulars have similar philosophies... sometimes with a twist but almost 
always compatable.

Wednsay night found me in the company of some good friends and famaliar 
faces. For that I'm grateful. 

Wendsay night also found me at times among people who seemed to have a 
total disregard for anything or anyone except for their Fabio perm. 
Smokers on the dance floor, nappers on the stage, squatters on the stairs. 
Shoves, punches, enough Vanilla Ice attitudes for an entire MTV Spring 
Break marathon.

...at times it felt like raving with the cast of 90210.

Any debate on this medium would seem like preaching to the converted...

But like I said, it's just some food for thought.

Have you ever been at a rave, dancing away in the wee hours of the 
morning, and suddenly become overwhelmingly depressed and wondered why 
you're even there?
That's happened to me at every rave I've gone to for quite a while now. 
It just floors you to be so incredibly sad in the midst of so much joy.
Then, a few minutes ago, I read some of the posts from the archives on 
hyperreal.com.
I got real, genuine goosebumps from some of them, especially the posts
from people sharing their wonderful experiences. It was like the     
positive energy was shooting right out of the screen. 
 It made me remember why I like Raving. :)
						-Alex

Rhea said in a most signifigant manner:

RH>I forgot my usual expectations, and remembered how to BE.
RH>Or, re-learned, maybe, no matter the forgetting.  It is such
RH>freedom to be both brave and tender.  I am still tingling!

RH>Thank you for letting me feel confident.  Thank you for letting
RH>me move amongst you, and dance, and watch you dancing, and smile,
RH>and look into your eyes, and touch your sweaty, glistening shoulders
RH>with my fingertips!

RH>I feel glorious and strong, and powerful, and grateful.


Every time I step into COME-UNITY I get that same feeling. As the end of
the month comes around I feel like a salmon does at spawning season,
uncontrollably drawn to a specific destination.

That urge doesn't stop when I get there though. I keep searching inside
for the answer until I hear that snare drum rattle a thousand times a
minute in my head. I open my eyes real WIDE and see a collection of
souls. Like a collauge(SP) of spirits designed into a beatiful peice of
art. That artwork will live inside all of us, permanently showing a
naked truth about collective souls. As this ever changing world makes a
permanent impression I feel as if everyone met me without even saying
"Hi".

Milton and I got there a little past 12:30. As we entered I knew that I
wasn't goin asleep until 6:00 or so.

As I found my usual spot on the stage around 2:30 I didn't stop until
the last song.

Until next time.


Andrew Dressler smiled, laughed, and hoped, for tommorrow is going to be
better. Don't look for the best day, just look for a better one.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jun  9 08:17:03 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id IAA04032; Fri, 9 Jun 1995 08:17:03 -0700

From: MVasey@eworld.com
Received: by hp1.online.apple.com
	(1.37.109.16/16.2) id AA266820986; Fri, 9 Jun 1995 08:16:26 -0700
Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 08:16:26 -0700
Message-Id: <950609081625_10997202@eWorld.com>
To: dislex@mercury.sfsu.edu, geoffw@nexsys.net
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: ComeUnity (food for thought)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This was my first ComeUnity and all I can say is WOW. I had a blast and am my
poor feet are just now recovering from the non-stop dancing. I have kind of
been avoiding larger events for the last several years but couldn't resist
after hearing all the good reviews lately. 

soundgod mentioned:
>I open my eyes real WIDE and see a collection of
>souls. Like a collauge(SP) of spirits designed into a 
>beatiful peice of art. 

All night/morning it was so nice to scan around the crowd while dancing and
visually connect with so many new people. Never exchanging any words with
most but connecting in a way that we will remember the next time we meet.

The only bummer was waiting in line for over an hour to get in. The sad thing
was it was not just the wait but the observations while waiting. I was amazed
at the number of people who had absolutely no respect for others waiting in
line. It reminded me in a BIG way why I stopped going to big clubs for
several years. You would never know it once you got inside but I agree with
 dislex@mercury.sfsu.edu who said

>Just as a person can use whatever space he has to it's fullest, there's 
>also a certain amount of respect given to the people around him for their 
>own space and an etiquete involved in such matters as line-jumping,
threading 
>through the crowd, and finding a space to move. 
>Wendsay night also found me at times among people who seemed to have a 
>total disregard for anything or anyone except for their Fabio perm. 
>Smokers on the dance floor, nappers on the stage, squatters on the stairs. 
>Shoves, punches, enough Vanilla Ice attitudes for an entire MTV Spring 
>Break marathon.

>...at times it felt like raving with the cast of 90210.

What's up with waiting line dynamics? Was it just that night or is this
standard fare nowadays?

People don't seem to know where the end of the line is. All night long people
would just mill up and down the line looking for friends so they could cut
in. I have no problem with saving someones space while they park or something
but come on. The people in front of me let in about 30 people (I am not
exagering!)  during the hour wait and the folks behing me let in about 10 to
15. I saw the same thing going on all up and down the line. This is not just
a couple people. The whole problem snowballs when all these new people in
front of you have there own set of friends that they let in. Some amazing
displays of attitude also:(

Maybe it's just cranky old me but this realization that all these people have
a total dis-respect for others. 

Funny thing is it only took about three minutes once I got inside to totally
change my mood and I am filled with good thought of the party.

peace,
martin

Geoff declares:
>ComeUnity! Once the rave of the "devoted" hardcore (people who didn't have
>jobs the next day or didn't care that they had jobs :) has now become
>mainstream. 

For such a popular club party, ComeUnity has managed to maintain a general 
sense of togetherness and raging intensity that can compel even the most
responsible of citizens to blow off a workday for. ;)

>I arrived at 3:30 expecting to see things thinned out a bit,
>I didn't expect a line half-way around the block.

The strange thing about this was that it never seemed to get too
crowded inside.  I've been to CU's with much shorter lines and more 
people.  I thought the flesh density on Weds. was perfect.

>I missed everyones set but Markie but he was  "doin it" when I got there

I felt that Simon's set was more consistant.  Markie had some really
amazing peaks, though.  Earlier, I caught the last 1/2 of Max's set 
which was also very good.

Mike Bolger observes:
>Wendsay night also found me at times among people who seemed to have a 
>total disregard for anything or anyone except for their Fabio perm. 
>Smokers on the dance floor, nappers on the stage, squatters on the stairs.>Shoves, punches, enough Vanilla Ice attitudes for an entire MTV Spring 
>Break marathon.

Yes, there was a fair amount of this.  But for the most part the
Vibesters in the house were able to overcome it with enough postivie
energy to keep things focused.  My main bitch was with the lack of
ventilation on the main floor, usually not a problem at 1015.  The 
basement chill zone was comfy though.  Did Velocette ever play live
as advertised?  I went down there occasionally to check, but all I saw
was some guy putting on a lame kung fu exhibition.

>Wednsay night found me in the company of some good friends and famaliar 
>faces. For that I'm grateful. 

Yep, me too.  All-in-all, CU delivered the goods. I heard that the 
Minna street afterparty went off as well. 

Lee
