========================================================================
       CAMPAIGN TO STOP THE EXON/GORTON COMMUNICATIONS DECENCY ACT

        Update: -Senate currently considering four Internet censorship
                 bills.  You need to act now.
                -What You Can Do Now (US and non-US citizens)

        CAMPAIGN TO STOP THE UNCONSTITUTIONAL COMMUNICATIONS DECENCY ACT
                           June 8, 1995

      PLEASE WIDELY REDISTRIBUTE THIS DOCUMENT WITH THIS BANNER INTACT
                 REDISTRIBUTE ONLY UNTIL June 25, 1995
             REPRODUCE THIS ALERT ONLY IN RELEVANT FORUMS

      Distributed by the Voters Telecommunications Watch (vtw@vtw.org)

________________________________________________________________________
CONTENTS
        The Latest News
        What You Can Do Now -- U.S. and non-U.S. citizens
        Senate Contact List
        For More Information
        List Of Participating Organizations

________________________________________________________________________
[Note that this week is going to be a stressful one, as the Telecomm
 Reform bill is on the Senate floor and things are moving *very quickly*.
 We're trying very hard to minimize the numbers of letters we send out,
 and the size of the alerts.

 If you feel they're coming too fast and are thinking about unsubscribing,
 please consider waiting until the end of next week, when the traffic
 will die down again. -Shabbir]

THE LATEST NEWS

First there was the Exon/Gorton Internet Censorship bill.  Then, there
was the Dole/Grassley bill, which would criminalize "profane" speech
among other things.  Then came the Lott amendment, which would make
Internet Service Providers (ISPs) liable for the traffic of their
users.  Now, Sen. Dan Coats (R-IN) has announced his intention to
introduce his very own legislation.  Since obscenity is already
illegal, it's unclear what benefits Coats' legislation will bring.

However given the tradition of the Senate's attempts at restricting the
Internet (Exon/Gorton, Feinstein, Dole/Grassley, and Lott) it's
becoming clear that few people are taking the First Amendment into
account when drafting their legislation.

As you read this, the Telecommunications Reform bill is being debated
on the Senate floor.  The Exon/Gorton Internet Censorship language
is *in that bill*.

If the net as a whole doesn't do anything, the Exon bill will become
a reality.

Even if it's found unconstitutional by the Supreme Court several years
from now, the damage it will do in terms of BBS seizures and chilling
speech in the meantime will make online systems a very different and
sad place.

A few days ago we put out an alert asking people to call Congress and
Vice President Gore.  This generated significant support and we've
even seen Senators' offices take notice of the fact that lots of computer-
literate individuals are calling to point out the problems with the
Exon/Gorton bill.

If you already called, *thank you*.  Your comments warmed the hearts of
several of us, who have been swamped trying to process all the mail
you sent.  You have done your country proud.  Just as heart-warming
have been the letters from those abroad, who took the time to email
(and even call!) Vice President Gore.  We hope we can return the
favor somehow someday.

However, many of us have not called or faxed.  If you haven't done so
yet, take a moment to do that now.  Make your voice heard in
Washington.  Remind the Senate, which is paying more attention now to
voters than it has in several years, that you care about this new
medium that enables us to communicate in such an unprecedented
many-to-many fashion.  Demand the *exact same* rights and
responsibilities for speech in the digital world as we expect in
print media, no more, no less.

________________________________________________________________________
WHAT YOU CAN DO NOW -- U.S. and non-U.S. citizens

The Telecomm Reform Bill currently includes the Exon/Gorton Internet
Censorship bill.  Leahy intends to offer a swap, to remove the Exon
language in exchange for his bill which advocates a study of the issue,
with an emphasis on the preservation of the First Amendment and
parental control.  The other proposals could become involved as well.

It is essential that the Leahy language be substituted for Exon's, and
therefore it is essential:

1. That all citizens call or fax their Senators as soon as possible.
   There is no time for written letters and email is too easily
   discounted or ignored. Non-U.S. citizens should contact Vice
   President Gore.  Note, if you decide to send a fax, you'll want to
   write an expanded version of the statement below.

   It's very important that you always be cool, collected, and polite.

   U.S. citizens:
        <call your Senators' offices, contact info below>
        "Hello, Senator ________'s office"
        "Hi, I'm a constituent and would like to register my
         opinion on the Telecommunications Reform bill to the           
         Senator.  May I please speak to the technology staffer,
         _________?"
        "Hold On please.  Alright, go ahead."

        "Please oppose the Exon/Gorton bill (Title 4 of the Telecomm
         bill) and other bills for censoring the Internet.  Please
         support the Leahy alternative (S714) which examines these
         issues.  My name and address are ________."

        "Thanks for calling."
        <click>

   Non-U.S. citizens:
        <call, fax, or send email to Vice President Gore>
        "Dear Vice President Gore,

         The world looks to the United States as one of the leaders in
         developing a Global Information Infrastructure.  Title 4 of
         the Telecomm Reform bill and other Internet censorship bills
         imperil that leadership.  Please work to remove them from the
         Telecomm Reform bill (S652) and support Senator Leahy's
         sensible alternative (S714).  I'm calling from ____________."


2. Send VTW a note telling us what you did. If you contacted your two
   Senators, send a letter to vtw@vtw.org with a subject line of
   "XX ack" where "XX" is your state.  For example:

        To: vtw@vtw.org
        Subject: OH ack

        I called my Ohio Senators and expressed my opinion.

   If you contact Senators outside your state, please let us know what
   state you're from.

   If you contacted Vice President Gore, send a letter to vtw@vtw.org with
   a subject line of "gore ack".  For example:

        To: vtw@vtw.org
        Subject: gore ack

        I called VP Gore and expressed my opinion.  I'm from France.

   An automatic responder will return an updated contact tally.

3. Forward this alert to relevant forums on other online services and
   BBS's.  Check the letter you get back to see which Senators are
   underrepresented by citizen contacts. Forward the Alert to any
   friends and colleagues in those states.

4. If you haven't yet signed the petition to support Sen. Leahy,
   do so now at http://www.cdt.org/petition.html.  If you don't have
   WWW access, send mail to vtw@vtw.org with a subject line of
   "send petition" for directions.

5. Congratulate yourself!  Your two-minute activism joins that of many
   thousands of others over the past two months.

________________________________________________________________________

following resources:

Web Sites

        URL:http://epic.org/
        URL:http://www.eff.org/pub/Alerts/
        URL:http://www.cdt.org/cda.html

        URL:ftp://ftp.eff.org/pub/Alerts/

Gopher Archives:
        URL:gopher://gopher.panix.com/11/vtw/exon
        URL:gopher://gopher.eff.org/11/Alerts

Email:
        vtw@vtw.org (put "send help" in the subject line)
        cda-info@cdt.org (General CDA information)
        cda-stat@cdt.org (Current status of the CDA)

________________________________________________________________________
LIST OF PARTICIPATING ORGANIZATIONS

In order to use the net more effectively, several organizations have
joined forces on a single Congressional net campaign to stop the
Communications Decency Act.

Please send a message to vtw@vtw.org with "send orgs" in the subject
line to receive a list of these organizations.

________________________________________________________________________
        End Alert

I use and have been very happy with "Community ConneXion: The
NEXUS-Berkeley"        the dial in number is 510-658-6376. You can login as
"guest" or http://www.c2.org. $10 per month unlimited time. Community
ConneXion is a small provider with Berkeley phone numbers only. Sameer the
Network Administrator is friendly and helpful. He has never taken longer
than 48 hours (usually less than 24) to answer my questions. Compare this
to Netcom where it takes a week to get an "answer" that is no help at all.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jun  9 14:08:03 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: more cu thoughts
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



CU waiting -

We had to wait to get in, and then wait for them to
turn up the music (even use all the speakers).  It was all show, 
all night long.  Pure party antics.  Save it for the Cow Palace.

I noticed also, that the (greatly outnumbered) people who showed up
solo tended to frown and then respectfully take a spot at the end of
the line.  Any group of 4 or more seemed to cut right in front of me.

I can't recall ever waiting that long for any party.  Anything that has
ever looked close to that, I've left.  I have no idea what possessed me 
on Wednesday to stick it out.  A great urge to go dancing??
I admit.  2 ft inside and my spirits lifted greatly.  
Their line manipulation was a success.


 
raving with the cast of 90210 -

I was struck by how very Preppy the crowd was.
Where were all the Freaks?  There were only a few.
Let me make myself crystal clear:   MORE SLEAZY FREAKS



Vanilla Ice attitude and a Fabio Perm -

I think you are refering to Me.
And I do take offense to your hair comment.
Bad Ass Vanilla Dave ... yeah, I like it, kinda
gives me goose bumps all over ...

Besides the mainstream, Very Weekend, suburban feel to the party
it was probably As Good of a Crowd like that as I've found.  They 
were happy and nice as far as I saw.  I missed any attitude.  

In a way, it was sorta fun to find yourself dancing with a very
familiar face amongst all the muck (a nice happy muck, mind you).



I don't think there was really much teaching going on at the party.  
This crowd had the Basics.  They really swamped the place, though.

Dave

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jun  9 18:13:00 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id SAA24962; Fri, 9 Jun 1995 18:13:00 -0700

From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199506100112.SAA20572@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Black Diamond
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 18:12:58 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2439      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all,

last night amy t. and I checked out the black diamond at the oddball 
lounge in the City.  

i got there about midnight and was greeted most friendily by the lovely 
and glamourous doormaven, who charged me a mere $4 and hoped i would have 
a nice time.  i assured her i would and went in.

the sight of many happy, friendly youngish-looking people greeted me once 
inside.  there were also lots of candles, a parachute suspended over the 
dance floor, a projection tv and some non-cheezy art on the walls of this 
cosy club/bar.  all the customary rave accoutrement designed to make one 
feel right at home. 

the crowd was a bit thin, but a few were really getting into the 
reggae-inspired dub of dj mike, who was pretty damn good, i thought.  
folks wandered off and on the dance floor and not much vibe was 
achieved.  but all the same, pretty good for the night after a comeunity.

then, gasp, felix went on.  well, in my opinion, he is the best dj in san 
francisco right now.  he goes beyond the usual cliches of cheezy house.  
the stuff he plays is not in category that i can think of, except maybe 
"triphop heavy dub," a phrase not-of-my-inventing.  anyway, he plays a 
lot of stuff that has a heavy hiphop beat, but which also incorporates 
trippy electronic sounds.  but in a way that gives the music power.  it 
is very very intense to listen and dance to his records, because it dips 
down into the ambient realm often and then powers right up again with a 
heavy heavy beat.  well, more than a few good records does a good dj 
make...he also has that indefinable ability to know what to give a crowd 
to take it some place emotionally.  there was a definite vibe in 
effect on the dance floor and it was not the usual "let's all dance 
until we die" kind of thing.  gone were the usual rote housey moves, i 
noted.  people were really getting into it and were developing some new 
moves, some new steps, it seemed.  cool.

the black diamond..every thursday night..as far as i am concerned is the 
happening thing right now.  the music and the vibe makes everything 
else out there look like a cliche.  if you just want to take your pill 
and zone out..which is quite fun, i admit!...go do the 1015 thing.  but 
you sfravers usually want more than that..so go check out the black 
diamond.  the afore-mentioned door-maven says they could use more 
support and said to tell you guys all about it.  


love,

Ann

OOGA BOOGA TWO YEAR ANNIVERSARY PARTY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

This is a reunion of sorts for the promoters involved, so come and
enjoy the vibe they're generating for the sake of an anniversary.
Ooga Booga at it's best was one of the dopest parties anywhere, so
let's see what happens OUTDOORS for only three bucks!

Thanks for all those who tried to come out to the MESS/Harmony/Cloud 
Factory party north of Santa Cruz.  We got busted right as we were 
starting.  There were several reasons for this but I think the main one 
was the amount of people that showed up.  Some of the secondary reasons 
were our fault and we are sorry about the disorganiztion that happened 
although things came togethere pretty well (I'd like to thanks Greg from 
Harmony who pulled off a lot of what needed to be done the day of).  The 
problem of too many people partly stemmed from XYZ's flawed idea of 
trying to hold their fifteen dollar bass/tickettron rave at Bonny 
Doon...what a  brilliant idea!  So about half of the crowd that stopped 
at ours thought they had paid fifteeen dollars for our party (although it 
was free =).  Needless to say hopefully everyone involved the organizing 
part of things is more aware, more conscious of the things that need to 
happen before/during a party, and we all learned/gained somethnig from 
what happeneed.  Once again thanks to those people who did come and all 
the above groups will be having parties again soon (i don't know when) 
but they will be going off like a lot of parties before these by these 
roups!!

love drenalin

arrived in OKC on the 9th.played at club run by EveryBodys Music.
next night , benefit for victims of federal building bombing organized by 
Jack and Stephanie Acid.this party was awesome.3 sound systems on two 
floors and an ambient noise room.Dj,s from Dallas and Austin and 
OKC.Underground Resistance drove down from Detroit FOR FREE to play at 
this party.Utter madness until the cops decided to shut it down at almost 
4am.Dorks.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jun 11 23:51:16 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id XAA02556; Sun, 11 Jun 1995 23:51:16 -0700
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id XAA02551; Sun, 11 Jun 1995 23:51:07 -0700
Received: from [198.93.4.219] (sr-tty9-ppp.well.com [198.93.4.219]) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id XAA29727; Sun, 11 Jun 1995 23:51:41 -0700
Message-Id: <199506120651.XAA29727@well.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 12 Jun 1994 23:52:58 +1000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: First raving weekend back home
Cc: ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My first weekend back in SF
Well,  after a really packed Come/Unity,  I had a big fat grin on my
face,  for a long time afterwards.

On Friday,  I get word of a party out in the woods in Marin County,  so
I call the info number,  feed the audio into MicMac for later playback
and transcriptions,  and transcribe the complex directions.   Of course
I won't divulge the location for this party,   because it served it's
purpose well,   and provided an excellent backdrop for some of the most
insane trance I've heard,   even coming from Australia.

It turns out that DJ Mars who used to put on the 8th and Kirkham parties
a few years ago,  have decided to scout around for some killer
underground rave sites,  and really scored on this one.

We head to the designated spot just in time for a car to drive up and a
familiar friend says "Get in,  I'll take you to the entrance trail to
the site"..   He drops us off,  and we proceed to head into the woods,
listening for the familiar thump thump of the music.   We hear nothing
from the road.

Our friend said "Look for the glow sticks marking the path".   It wasn't
hard to miss,  because someone broke open a glow stick and sprayed it
along the path.   Looked kinda trippy...    Eventually,  we hear the
music and not long after that,   was totally into some really wicked
trance.   It was almost a full moon,  and lit up the area really well.

DJ Mars eventually went on,  and upped the BPM a lot,   despite the
bitching from some people complaining about the speed.

It was the ultimate setting for some of the most insane German trance
one can imagine.   The amount of people peaked at around 70 - 80 Ppl,
and naturally wasn't one of those Mega raves.   The vibe was all smiles
as I bounced around,   or at least my body did.   My head,  however was
certainly not in the immediate vicinity.  It was probably out there
somewhere far far away.

The ground wasn't the best surface to dance on,   so I changed my dance
style to fit the conditions,  and let the music take total control of my
physical being.

The end came far too soon for me,   but the promoters thought it would
be a good idea to pack up and leave,  before a hiker discovered us.   An
hour later,   not even a cigarette butt was seen in the area.

I very stupidly took a ride with a friend who wanted to leave sooner
than he thought.   I checked and found out that DJ Mars was going to
have to pass through Mill Valley on the way back,  so I had a ride home.

After DJ Mars dropped me home,   I started making plans to go to yet
another outdoor party yet again in Marin.   WOW!!  Lucky me!!   not just
ONE outdoor party,   but TWO of them,   12 hours apart,  and even in the
same county.

Again,   out came MicMac and after transcribing the directions,
gleefully aim the car in the right direction and take off.   WOW!!  We
were treated to the most awesome scenery,  as the clouds clung on top of
the hills.  Now,  THIS site was PRIMO!!    Right along the coast,
fully permitted to go till 9 PM,  and was the ideal picnic setting with
some really slow and funky house on a lazy Saturday afternoon.

It was an absolutely perfect afternoon,   with yet more people
discovering that I've returned,  I've been busy filling them in on my
Australian trip.   Got in some great Frisbee fun in the sun,  danced my
ass off,  and hiked up and around the surrounding hills.   These
conditions make for some rather interesting acoustical effects,  as the
music reverberated through the hills.

The music lasted until about 8 PM,   after the ranger came and told us
we had to leave.   The rangers were rather pushy,  and we eventually
left.

I headed back with my friend who wanted to take me to see "Congo",
which had bad reviews.   After the flick,  I drop my friend home and
transcribe the lengthy directions,  and head out to "Friends and
Family's" free party in Bizerkeley.   Friends and Family consists mostly
of SFRvers and their friends.   These parties usually tend to GET OFF in
a very big way,   yet remain small.   Again,  there were about 70 - 80
Ppl dancing to some trancy house.   Was discovered by yet more SFRavers
who wanted to talk,   so wasn't immediately in the dance area.   Dancing
surface rather poor,  but it didn't take me long to discover the hidden
rocks and dance over them.

Alex (originally from the UK) spun a rather low energy set,   but I
didn't really care,  as I was experimenting with new movements,  trying
some of my Happy Hard-core movements with house.   It didn't take me
long to trance out and really get into the groove.

Alex's set sorta fizzled out,  so took some time out to schmooze and
stretch after 2 hours of solid dancing.

After Alex came on,  this Japanese lady took to the turntables,  I
didn't get here name,  but she was really very good.   She started with
some strange noises,  which formed into some really trancey tunes.

Minor went on,  and after a really good start,  literally started to
escalate the energy to a very high level.   I don't know what he played,
but the people literally went insane,   yelling and shouting as this
very high energy track was on.   Ethan quickly ran up (And a few of the
other DJ's) to see what record he was playing.   Minor just handed him
the album cover with a shit eatin grin on his face.   WOW!! Whatta
score!

Didn't get the name of the last DJ,   but his set was really consistent
and trancey.

I've finally figured out the reason why Calif. dudes don't like hard-
core.   It don't have Soul!!

This party went on,  totally un-molested by porkey pig.   Again,  the
site was put back exactly like it was before,   except a little neater.

I immediately went home,  and had just enough time for breakfast before
the Dypsea run started at 8:30 in the morning.   Although I'm not
running in this 8 mile race over logs, trails,  and roads from Mill
Valley to Stinson Beach,   I wanted to see what the kick off was like.

This brings us to Sunday...   Haight Street Fair...   Oh Goodie..  A
really cool place to hang out....  All of Upper Haight is blocked off,
and cars are replaced with food venders,  jewelry,  and other fine
craft,  with live music at each end.

Ameba had a van with a sound system,   but was asked to remove it,  so
the music was just played in the store.   Just after Tracy spun,  I
walked out just in time to hear Paul Kantner and the Jefferson Starship
play "Volunteers of America".    People were going insane dancing in the
streets.   The energy was awesome...

After the fair,   we run into Galen of Sunset fame,  who informs us of a
small house party at his place on the Haight.   His place was 3 blocks
from Ameba,  so we head over.    I didn't even need his address,
because he hung his speakers over the balcony,  aimed them out into the
streets and pumped up the volume.

Hanging from his balcony was an "I love House" flag,  with "love"
replaced with a heart inside a house.

This party WENT OFF!!   People stopping in front of galens house to
dance to some of the most insane trancey house I've heard in a long
time.   WOW!!  So much new music around.

Galens flat was up on the 3rd story,  overlooking the street below.
Galen's turn tables facing out the window,  gives him an unobstructed
view of the crowd below.   Just about everyone was dancing for over a
hundred feet in either direction from his flat,  as he was skillfully
working the crowd.

I was standing on the fire escape waving my arms at the crowd below...

Eventually two cops barge in and stopped the music,   but we turned off
the outside speakers,  and let in anyone who wanted to continue dancing.

We went to yet another party,  where Solar was spinning.   The energy
was awesome,   as everyone was trying to crowd in the small bedroom
where Solar has his tables.

All in all,  for my first weekend back,   I pulled a coupe....
Although I had to stay awake the entire time with NO opportunity to
meditate,   I still had the energy to enjoy myself to the fullest
possible....   Hope you all did the same...

Crunchman

Subject: Positive Society
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This was a nice little Saturday daytime party in a great location
in the Marin Headlands, just 5 minutes past the GG Bridge.  They 
had a permit to go until sundown, which was around 8, I guess. 
One portosan, no running water or shade, but a nice big grassy field
surrounded by beautiful green hills.  This would be a great location
for a Sunset or a morning afterparty.  The permits are supposed to 
be cheap, like $35.  Amplified sound is supposedly OK because of a
nearby rifle range.

Very nice sound system with Community speakers like Ethan's, a bit
smaller perhaps.  Solor and DJ Unknown (Josh Bates) spun fairly 
relaxed sets while we were there.  The 60 or so people who showed 
up were laid back & friendly.  We only stayed for 3.5 hours and 
some folks were still arriving as we left.  The guys putting this 
on seem to be pretty cool; they brought around a really nice 
fruit spread and had plenty of garbage bags on hand.  Looking
forward to more from these folks.

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

My roommate and fellow sfraver Jonathan Wells and I are going to be doing a pavillion at NARNIA, which is going to happen this August on an Indian Reservation in the desert outside of San Diego.  Quite a few of our friends want to go too, so we've been looking into renting a bus to take everybody down.  It would either be one of those luxury busses with a VCR, sound system and comfy seats, or a cool old hippy bus with no chairs, just pillows (!)
We've talked to quite a few bus companies and it looks like the bottom line is that it would cost around $50 to $60 per person.  That would include getting into Narnia, too.
Is there anyone else who would be interested in going?  If you are, please email me asap since we're going to have to decide whether or not to do it soon.
Also, does anyone know of a good place to rent a bus which we might not have contacted yet?

No lineup has been announced for Narnia yet but the last three have been pretty incredible.  Some of the DJ's have included Robbie Hardkiss, Soulslinger, Jon Bishop, Dmitry, Mark E. Quark (****!!) Jason Bentley and tons of other cool djs. Also last year there was an amazing live performance by CRASH WORSHIP in the bottom of a gravel quarry(!!).  There was also a cool chill area beside a small lake and a path to a secret buddhist temple far away from the site.  And there were tons of people camping out ...

Just a reminder about the "SFRaves South Bay Lunch" 

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules. At special times,
we've met at a restaurant ( no boom-box , tho' .... ).

 It's every Wednesday , depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I hope to see you folks there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com
-----------------
 By the way - I was thinking of meeting at a restaurant next
week Wednesday. There's supposed to be a Chinese restaurant
in Mountain View on Castro Street called "Rave" (!) - anybody
know anything about it? It's my leading candidate , but I've 
never been there myself.
------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFRaves South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

Subject: sol'y'luna
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings Friends.

Many thanks to all of you who helped make sol'y'luna a very, very magic
evening. This one will be with me a long time.

The night itself was nothing short of amazing: the moon, the deep purple
sky, the massive cloudscapes, the city and bridges quietly glowing while
the stars sparkled and fell out of the heavens. =)

It is also gives me great pleasure that, with the exception of some
flattened grass, we left the site absolutely pristine, perhaps even better
than we found it. This is as it should be. People live there, animals live
there, it is anything but a dump.

Thanks too to everyone that helped lug speakers, amps, etc. down that long,
long road, the help was greatly appreciated.

I do have one small request though: please *do not* bring or support the
presence of nitrous at future F&Fs, it is not welcome.

love ya
ethan

Subject: Re:  full moon

Precedence: bulk

> I don't see at all why you told everyone "not to post" the full 
> moon info on the net...
> Timothy

I remember some big discussions about this, probably around the time
3000 people showed up for a Bonney Doon fmr.  I agree with you, Timothy,
I think it is pretty safe to toss out just about any renegade info to
this list.  Ultimately, if the folks throwing the party don't want
that to happen, then there isn't much more to say about it.

Given how Packed CU was, I suspect there are lots of people with more
midweek free time (summer vacation?) ... So if they have an intimate party
in mind, it is maybe understandable for them to be super-secretive about
the directions.

Dropping by one of the weeklies is considered a good way to hook up.
I don't recommend standing outside and hassling the door people or other
club-goer's though.  I've seen this before.  I recall one desperate
group of summer ravers being sent on a wild goose chase by the
less than amused Endup doorman ...

Dave

        Reply to:   RE>>Narnia!

NARNIA is a massive "rave" (or whatever) which is put together by Global Underworld Network and is going to be held at an Indian Reservation in Southern California in August.  I don't hink there's a definite date yet.  There have been three so far (one each summer for the past 3 years).  The last one was held on this beautiful Indian quarry/campground in the desert about halfway between San Diego and LA.  There were about 6,000 people there, so it was pretty massive, but it didn't feel like one of those huge corporate raves.  It ususally lasts from the afternoon until the afternoon of the next day.  Check out the cover of the last DEEE-LITE record, which is heavily influenced by the poster for the last NARNIA and keep an eye on URB magazine for updates as to who will be there  ... 

--------------------------------------

On Tuesday 6/13 Marc Fathauer said:
Please fill this Santa Barbara Crew in on was up with Burning Man this year
we all wants to go real bad.


Ahhh....Burning Man. The most amazing three days I have spent yet on this
planet.
A difficult experience to describe. Here are a couple little passages that
capture the sense of the thing:

---------------

"It is difficult to transmute into words the oddness of an image. The comic
grotesque distortions of inner time and space, the weird amalgams of feeling
that leave people perhaps a little more aware of their deepest responses to
life, and a little more unsure of the artifice with which they cover
themselves."(from Larry Harvey's((one of BM's creators))answering machine
message

---------------

Q: I've heard you describe the ritual of Burning Man as sacred.

A: Sure-if you view the experience in terms of how it works, what it does,
and how people respond to it. It's true we've never claimed it's
supernatural. We have no metaphysical doctrines that people have to believe,
but all that's unnecessary baggage. Functionally and phenomenally I'd
describe it as sacred. Consider what we do. We build this giant statue that
is larger-than-life and which glows in the dark. Then take it to the
desert-stage a pilgrimage. Our art's always playful, yet most of it is cast
in ritual form. There are torchlight processions, visionary spectacles, and
all of this culminates in an act of sacrifice. Priests and Shamans have
employed these methods since the Stone Age. I also know encounters with the
sacred inspire certain powerful emotions: awe, fear, delight, a sense of the
uncanny, and over all, a peculiar sort of transcendence.

Ahhhhh...........

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%Brad deCaussin%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
***************************bdec@Presage.com****************************

To all those who were unfortuant  enough to miss last nights full-moon 
rave you missed what can only be described as one of the nicest full moon 
raves that I have ever been to (and I"ve been to a few!).  As with other 
cool parties/rave related issues in the bay area Mark and Tracy from 
Ameba were in full effect.  Tracy played some of the nicest music that I have
heard at a party in years; she  is with out a doubt a true master of her art.
I won't go on and on about how nice it was on the beech, or how nice the 
people were, or how beautiful the vibe was.  Those that already know I 
will respect by not preaching to the converted; for those that don't, get a 
life!
But I would like to say thank you to everyone that went especially 
those that gave me a ride there and back.
Lots of love and happiness, Tristan.

Thought for the day:

My roommate and fellow sfraver Jonathan Wells and I are going to be doing a pavillion at NARNIA, which is going to happen this August on an Indian Reservation in the desert outside of San Diego.  Quite a few of our friends want to go too, so we've been looking into renting a bus to take everybody down.  It would either be one of those luxury busses with a VCR, sound system and comfy seats, or a cool old hippy bus with no chairs, just pillows (!)
We've talked to quite a few bus companies and it looks like the bottom line is that it would cost around $50 to $60 per person.  That would include getting into Narnia, too.
Is there anyone else who would be interested in going?  If you are, please email me asap since we're going to have to decide whether or not to do it soon.
Also, does anyone know of a good place to rent a bus which we might not have contacted yet?

No lineup has been announced for Narnia yet but the last three have been pretty incredible.  Some of the DJ's have included Robbie Hardkiss, Soulslinger, Jon Bishop, Dmitry, Mark E. Quark (****!!) Jason Bentley and tons of other cool djs. Also last year there was an amazing live performance by CRASH WORSHIP in the bottom of a gravel quarry(!!).  There was also a cool chill area beside a small lake and a path to a secret buddhist temple far away from the site.  And there were tons of people camping out ...

Just a reminder about the "SFRaves South Bay Lunch" 

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules. At special times,
we've met at a restaurant ( no boom-box , tho' .... ).

 It's every Wednesday , depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I hope to see you folks there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com
-----------------
 By the way - I was thinking of meeting at a restaurant next
week Wednesday. There's supposed to be a Chinese restaurant
in Mountain View on Castro Street called "Rave" (!) - anybody
know anything about it? It's my leading candidate , but I've 
never been there myself.
------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFRaves South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

        Reply to:   RE>>Narnia!

NARNIA is a massive "rave" (or whatever) which is put together by Global Underworld Network and is going to be held at an Indian Reservation in Southern California in August.  I don't hink there's a definite date yet.  There have been three so far (one each summer for the past 3 years).  The last one was held on this beautiful Indian quarry/campground in the desert about halfway between San Diego and LA.  There were about 6,000 people there, so it was pretty massive, but it didn't feel like one of those huge corporate raves.  It ususally lasts from the afternoon until the afternoon of the next day.  Check out the cover of the last DEEE-LITE record, which is heavily influenced by the poster for the last NARNIA and keep an eye on URB magazine for updates as to who will be there  ... 

--------------------------------------

Precedence: bulk

Timothy, there's a whole long history of the interaction between sfraves and
the FMR that goes back more than two years.  Check out the archives at
hyperreal if you want to see all of it.  Basically, it's a matter of trying
to keep the FMRs from getting over-run, and keep the chain-of-friends-and-
acquaintances strong so that the party will endure over time.  Quite a f ew
people on the list are willing to pass along the location info when they get
it (I don't usually have it since I live in Portland and make only maybe
two or three FMRs a year), so email is the way to make contact and make those
arrangements.  

What was true two years ago is even more true now.  Lots and lots of people
monitor this list and distribute the info.  At the last Liquid that Bryrce
organized on the Bay, lots of people we'd never met showed up just based
on the listing in the calendar.  That was fine, but handling the FMRs is
so much more arduous because of typically limited parking and so on, but
most of all the need to maintain the good vibe based on not being over-run
by a lot of people who don't know the history and sensibility of the FMR.
We're also concerned that should something not go well, the list here would
possibly get the blame.

Ultimately, we are only respecting the organizing crew's wishes, just as
we would prefer to have aour wishes concerning publicity be respected for
any events we do.  I don't know whether announcing the FMR sites here would
really pose all that much a problem, but this is the determining factor.

phred

the earths vibrations reverberate through my tissues. So I figured I'd

It has the power to turn the tides
What power must it have on us mere humans?

Rays glowing
Caressing sand, skin
Warmth

And the beat goes on...

Beauty, strength, POWER

Turning...

Technology
Power, strength..... beauty?

Salt and cloves
and the beat goes on...

Moon
Filling me full of the energy
That keeps me sane

Or was it due to Wigstock? Though amusing to see its participants roam
about 1015 like "Priscilla Queen of the Desert," this event dominated the
main room until about 3 a.m. Thanks to Tracy for laying down some great
stuff at that time and transforming the space into a world that I frequent
more regularly. :) By the time I left around 4:45 the place was taking off.

such wicked trance! He really kept me going (though Taj was so-so, IMO,
with his same old stuff) until Tracy started spinning upstairs.

the dancers up on the cabinets were a nice touch!! Were they paid? (hee,

san francisco police raided a hip hop party in north beach  june 3, 
arresting and 
assaulting several people,  in response, an open forum is being planned 
for this thursday evening.

i don't have all the details, but i do know that the police said they 
were responding to a complaint of drinking in the street, tho' no bottles 
were found, and that they then just went in and shut down the party.  at 
least one person who was attempting to videotape police conduct was maced 
in the face.

the reason i'm posting this to sfraves is because it's clearly an issue 
we have in common (our right to party, gather, etc.) and i think it would 
be a good idea for all those interested to attend the forum in support.

it's thursday evening, 7 - 9:00, at 435 Broadway, bet. Montgomery and 
Kearny (in north beach).  i'll be there.

take care everyone,
monicat

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: sol y luna afterglow
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

  Sol y Luna was one of those rare nights of pure inspiration that this city
has given me -- something like bicycling down to the Jack London Club in
Oakland, years ago, for Mr. Floppy's Flophouse.  It was such an idyllic &
unlikely spot, and such a lovely group of people to spend the early hours
with!  I got there around 2:30 AM to the sound of Alex's sublime & blissful
grooves.  Chizuru played a wildfire set, mixing on a dime, and pumping it
quite hard -- a tough act to follow!  In any case, I had the most ecstatic
experience I've ever had behind turntables, and on nothing stronger than
grapefruit juice.  Parafin put a nice cap on the evening, with a warm flow of
trance/house tunes.  The clouds opened up somewhere in the last few moments
before 7, and it was good.  Thanks again to everyone involved!
   - franklin minor minor

   In the fine tradition of Laura LaGassa, here's a list of what I played @
sol y luna.  The one everybody flipped out over was  Underworld's Chemo Bros
remix ;).  '*'s next to tracks means they're recent enough to find if you had
a mind to.

  Peter Vriends - Joy
* Sven Vath - Ballet Fusion

5:50 AM

X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 2.0.3
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reza@uclink.berkeley.edu (Reza Morin-Dayani)
Subject: Sol'y'luna and a weekend to be remembered...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     It began friday at dust...  I loved the music, the people and the
lights.  The laser was awesome!!!  
     After two hours sleep I biked down to meet up with sme friends and
headed for the American river.  We were 5 rafts of good food and good
friends.  The weather was wonderfull!  The only thing that could have
improved it would have required  putting a sound system into one of the
rafts...  We ended the trip with a bar-b-que.  
     After some food and a shower the sfravers in the group went home to
change for so'y'luna and to pick up a newbie.  We all walked towards the
site looking and listening with nervous anticipation.  The first thing we
heared was the  rythmic thumping of the base  we walked in awe of the
location.  So close to the city and yet a world quite seperate from our own.  
     When we finally arrived the only light to mark the spot came form the
moon a string of x-mas lights and the dj's tables.  The music was great...
I made new friends, saw old firends and helped introduce a new comer to the
"rave" experience.  Depite lack of sleep the music kept me dancing well into
the morning.  The experience as a whoe was reminiscent of my first fmr on
panther beach back in march...   Another completely wonderfull experince.
Before crashing blissfullly at a friends place a bunch of us went to Noahs
for breakfast.  
     Thanks to The Friends and Family crew, all the dj's and especially all
the wonderfull people who attended.    

            Smiles,
                         Reza

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jun 14 13:08:53 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA19768; Wed, 14 Jun 1995 13:08:53 -0700
Received: from nexsys.nexsys.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA19730; Wed, 14 Jun 1995 13:08:43 -0700
Received: by nexsys.nexsys.net (8.6.10/SM-8.6.4)
	id NAA09059; Wed, 14 Jun 1995 13:11:02 -0700
Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 13:11:02 -0700
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199506142011.NAA09059@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: geoffw@nexsys.net, sfraves@hyperreal.com, timothym@ocf.berkeley.edu
Subject: Re: full moon
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 
> I'm sorry, but I don't see at all why you told everyone "not to post" the full
> moon info on the net... jesus what's the big deal?  How are we who aren't cool
> enough to know a promoter supposed to find out about it?! I understand that
> you don't want to get busted, or that maybe you'd like an intimate party, but
> look at what F&F did this weekend--THEY had an outdoor party too, but they helpe -
> ed everyone out by at least providing a phone number... and what, do you think
> we'll all run off and notify the SF police department?  Trust us, we won't...
> Man, sorry to vent on you Geoff, and I hate to judge your intentions from here,
> and maybe this goes on all the time, but I think you could have helped every-
> one out a bit more.  
> Timothy
> 

This has been talked about on the list before, the bottom line is:

The people who put the party on request that it not be placed on the list for the
simple fact that the "fan out" is too great.  When it is posted on the list it is
in an electronic form that travels to at least 900 people simultaneously around the
world.  These people are capable of sending it to hundreds if not thousands of other
people.  We have experimented both ways with posting to the list and not posting. The
bottom line is that when the party is posted, it increases the number of participants
by generally 1000 people.  The party then generally becomes out of control but not in
a good way.  Many people come because it is the "place to be" not because they want to
experience the magic of a FMR.   The FMR is an _underground_ party.  You have to work to
find it, it's suppose to be that way.  Very often the actual location is not decided
until a couple of hours before the party is to take place.  If the location is posted
earlier in the day or people are informed a day or two in advance, they will be pretty 
disappointed to arrive at a location only to discover that the party has been moved
50 miles away. We don't not post because of the law, indeed there have been some 
indications that the police may have discovered a party or two due to the list but it
is my guess that they saw a print-out or some parent of a friend of a friend who got the
directions e-mailed to them informed the police, I don't believe the police waste their
time and energy monitoring the list looking for parties to bust.

Finding the FMR is suppose to be an adventure,  the party is underground (one of the few 
remaining free underground parties), it has the largest flyer in the solar system,
so you should know the approximate time that it is going to happen, there are many people
on this list who know how to find the info on the full moon, basically the info travels
by phone tree, it is suppose to pass among friends, I suggest that you reach out to people
that you know and get to know them better and you won't have a problem finding the FMR.
Don't bother asking 3 days in advance, the organizers are generally not that organized
that they know the location that early.  It is sort of a spontaneous thing, generally 
I have discovered that a lot of people know the general location by the afternoon before
the party.  Usually by 8 or 9 p.m. it is all over the Haight.

We are trying to keep the party a fun adventure that is enjoyable to the participants
and to the people that put it on.  It is also important that we control the crowd size
so that the location is not completely trashed.


I hope this sheds some light on the subject.




					G

Subject: A Full Moon Lurker.....
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hey all,

It's been so long long since I've seen my name on a post, that I nearly
 looked for  my name in the obituary column before writing....However, some
of you know that my poor little black Beemer died last month from
"Raveritis"...that's an indigenous mileage disease that raver cars develop
due to continual party miles.  In my case, my car died, appropriately, on the
way to Sf for a warehouse party.  She went up in flames,(an electrical fire)
after logging 220,000 miles. Not exactly a viking funeral for my car, but
better to "flame out, than rust out"....

 Anyways, I was asleep this last full moon's eve, when friend Forrest comes a
"rap,tap, tapping at my chamber door," calling out---Get Up, Old person, You
Wretched, Arthitic, Poor Excuse for a Rave-Buddy, there's a
FULL.MOON!!!!"......(an those were the nice words he had for me..)

Mark from Ameba had called and said Tracy was spinning at the full moon, and
that our presence was requested...and besides, it was going to be in our neck
of the woods...Panther Beach, Santa Cruz----

So, a full moon, and memories of the Halloween Boony Doon full moon came
flooding back, I remember the beach looking like a patchwork of snowflakes in
the moonlight, ( I think I was seeing things)... as I stumbled to get my rave
warmies on..then,....Driving up the coast....Dutch's Burning Chrome blaring
and pounding away......going in rave style....across the tracks and down to
the party......Spun was playin some very danceable sand music...(did he play
all night???since markie was sick.thanks to him....until Tracy.gave it
whurl... hugs.to her!!!...) I actually left with my legs this time!!!  Great
to see Geoff, Mark, Tracy, Crunch, etc.......
Thanks to all who said hi!!!! or smiled seeing this tall grey-haired raver
with (black Goodman Theater, Chicago Baseball Cap on)....... 
         .....  dancin in the sand   again.....Robertj......monterey......

.........Look for me to back this summer, at a rave near you!!!!!

  A guy with the the Goethe Institute got ahold of me at KALX with some info
on the 'Tuetonic Techno Temple meets SF House' party at DV8 on Wednesday the
21st.  Here goes:

DJ lineup:

SF
---
Markie
Henrik
Robbie Hardkiss
Jon Williams

Germany & elsewhere
--------------------
Marusha
Westbam
Hardsequencer
Jeff Mills
Joey Beltram
Mark Spoon
Patrick Pulsinger
Lester Young
Upstart
Erdem Tunakan
Blake Baxter
Talla 2 XLC
Pascal FEOS
Dr. Motte
Davis Maas

Visuals:

Synergy
Pure
Hyperdelic
Donavan

  They're going to be using all 4 floors of DV8, from 10pm-6am, and the
Gardening Club is also going to do a special ambient installation at the
Caribbean Zone behind DV8.  This is a special event of the 95 'Making Waves:
4th Annual SF Music Day' and the German contribution to the UN-50
celebration.
   For a technohead like me, this is easily the most exciting thing to blow
through town all year!  See you there,

  - franklin minor minor

Subject: The Smiling Moon - FMR report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The moon smiles on us
=====================

When I looked up at the moon last weekend,   it had a big phat smile on
it's face.   I thought that because of this,  maybe we were going to
have a really good FULL MOON party.

It certainly happened,  it literally WENT OFF...

As usual,  I stay home,  next to the Internet,  where I constantly get
updates and news on locations.   However,   Jeff failed to get that info
to me,  so It wasn't until WAY LATE that I actually learned it's SECRET
location.   It was very far from where I lived,   but I eventually made
it to the site.   The site was primo...  reminded me of the old full
moon parties.

When I arrived,  Dutch was spinning some funky house toons,  so I
wandered around,  saying hi to more people that noticed me back.   I
also saw Bruce Eisner there.    As expected,  a LOT of SFRavers were
there,   making the sacrifice of Monday evening to sleep,  and waking up
at 1 am to tune into the grid for loc. inf..

The moon was low on the horizon when we got there,   but the vibe was
primo to the MAX.   Ameba's Mark was dancing just about all the time,
yet another dude with AWESOME ENERGY!!

It wasn't long before the sun rose,   and by that time,  the quantity of
people peaked at about 200.   The crowd size was just about right,
given the limited area,  and the size of the sound system.

Getting the sound system down to the location was a huge monumental task
of dirty manual labor.   But somehow they made it down safely.

As I was tripping around,   the echo effects of the music against the
hillside was an amazing aural experience.

Eventually Tracy went on,  and the music even got better.   WOW!!  Heard
a whole lot of really good stuff..    As usual,  I went totally
insane,  trying to keep up with Mark...   But I also had to devote some
time from dancing to Schmoose and get caught up with the latest juicy
gossip...

Markie never did show up,  reports that he was sick,  and couldn't make
it.   Tracy eventually tired,  and somewhere mid morning,  pulled the
plug.   I could have used about another 8 hours of dancing,   but we had
to settle to just existing in this nice environment.   Late afternoon,
we started out on our trek back.  It was a wonderful and pleasant event
that left the beach and the environment in much better condition than it
was before the gathering.   This one gets a 10 on a one to ten scale,
Way to go Mark!...   You pulled off a good one....

Crunchman

Message-ID: <Pine.A32.3.91.950615042637.114363A-100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

To all those getting so exited by the Orb show a few words of warning.
Have any of you lot acctually seen the Orb before?  They don't play live 
(and yes, Techno bands can perform live in just the same way that 
rockbands do they are just using keyboeards, discks and drum machines) 
they just push a few buttons and dance around a bit.  The light and 
vissual show is really good but no better then a good light/slide show 
from Donavn or Synergy.  And the music, especially the last few releases, 
have sucked very badlly indeed.  I just want people who are getting all 
pumped for it only to read mail by lots of dissapointed punters the day after.
(Which I sincerlly hope is not the case!)
  You remember the Galaria show where Orbital played?  Now that was classic 
live techno at it's best.  Orbitall blow the Orb away anyday anyway so 
please don't expect it to be as good as that show.  I have seen the Orb 
three times when I was living in London and the first one was good but 
the other two got progressivly worse.  I am not trying to put a downer on 
the whole issue I just do not want people to be dissapointed.  In short, 
it's not worth $25.  Sorry.
Love Tristan.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun 15 06:54:51 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id GAA20892; Thu, 15 Jun 1995 06:54:51 -0700
Received: from nexsys.nexsys.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id GAA20885; Thu, 15 Jun 1995 06:54:47 -0700
Received: by nexsys.nexsys.net (8.6.10/SM-8.6.4)
	id GAA14941; Thu, 15 Jun 1995 06:57:05 -0700
Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 06:57:05 -0700
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199506151357.GAA14941@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Full Moon Madness
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


		Pray to the Moon, 
		When She is rounde,
		Luck with you,
		shall then abounde,
		What ever you seek for,
		Shall be founde,
		In Sea, or Sky, or Solid Grounde


				- traditional wiccan rhyme




	The universe operates on two governing principles,
	one is Reason,
	the other is Rhyme
	which is very close to rhythm

	Our culture is fixated on Reason,
	The Sea is fixated on Rhyme,

	This last full moon was truly stupendous for me.
	The night started early, Markie called me earlier in the
	day and said "it's on" though the exact location was not finalized
	until the evening.  By 2:00 a.m. I was cruising over the Santa Cruz 
	mountains in my hoopty of a CRX, the cell-phone rings, it's Markie
	telling me he's too sick to come and play (and boy does he sound it :)
	He say's that Chaulkie may show up but that if not, Spun and Tracy
	have to make it on their own. Oh well.  Behind me, in another
	car, is my friend Mellissa, this is her first FMR in about two years
	having almost completely dropped out of the scene, she is accompanied
	by Jessica (an old timer though she is only 19 :) and another friend
	who is about to go to her first Rave (and boy is she in for a treat :)

	We arrive in Santa Cruz, drive through the town and out to the 
	cool and the dark,  I find the appropriate hidden turn off and discover
	that there are quite a few cars already at the site, though it isn't 
	over crowded.  I find a good place to park, take out my back-pack and
	my new instrument, a didgery-do (sp?) and start the descent of the cliff
	The night is beautiful, the Moon is shining in a clear sky, the
	reflection on the sea is almost otherworldly.  This is the full moon
	before the Solstice, the most powerful full moon of the year.  As far
	as one's ability to trance and to "bridge the worlds" this is a most
	auspicious time. Perhapse that is why a certain Kind Soul choose this
	time to bless several of us with a drop or two of an absolute sacrement

	The beach was in full effect,  It was about 3:15 when the music started,
	Spun at the helm, starts off with some ambient music to set the tone and
	to dissapate some of the alcohol energy that was prominant. As
	he goes along I take some moments out to walk along the beach, the
	ultimate chill-out room, I go over by the cliff and sit up on the rocks
	playing my didgery-do to the surf.  As the music picks up, I decide that
	it's time to dance but as I do go back over to the  speakers, I began
	to experience the full on rush. I climbed up out of the beach and
	walked along the the top of the cliff, the top had been tilled
	and planted with some form of leafy green vegetable.  The whole country
	side was bathed in moonlight and it gave a silvery sheen to the
	ground and the plants.  As I walked closer to the edge I looked out and 
	saw the ocean in all it's magnificent beauty and power.  Initially, it
	was frightening, (I was up pretty high, I could look out for miles
	and the sea was so vast and some of the waves off shore were easily 
	about 30 feet in hight) as I watched, I became less afraid and realized
	the the sea has a story to tell and a song to sing, and if you listen
	carefully you can hear it.  I grew bolder and went out to the very edge 
	of the cliff, to a little power spot "between the worlds" it jutted
	out and was not more than 12 feet wide but it provided a place to stand
	or sit where you could see all of panther beach below on one side and 
	all of the  coast on the other.  As I looked down on the revellers
	and looked out into the sea, I began to realize that what we were doing
	was not particularly new at all but, in actuality it is _very_ old,
	cratures, especially sea creatures are very linked to the lunar cycle,
	and at the full moon there is more activity then at any other time.  As
	I watched the incessant approach of the waves, I finally understood
	about music and rhythm, House music in particular.  We as a species
	have a long way to go when it comes to rhythm, things like raving and
	trance dancing are just at the gate of remembrance so to speak. The sea
	and the creatures that inhabit her are far more "with it" when it comes
	to this fact of life.  At one point when Tracy  had come on, her playing
	was perfectly in sync with the rhythm of the approaching waves that
	were pounding the coast for miles in both directions, the sound of
	the music blended with the sound of the waves like an intricate fractal,
	I could feel the energy on the beach, some one screamed and then I 
	realized the lesson that our mother, the sea, was trying to tell us.

	For the sea, all there is, is Rhythm, it is the governing principle
	of ocean life, the currents and the tides are rhythmic and repetitive,
	although the song changes from hour to hour, month to month, season to
	season, eon to eon.  When we rave for 4, 5 or 8 hours we simulate 
	something that has been going on in the sea for millions of years,
	it will continue to go on for millions of years more even though we
	have to stop and do things like electronic funds transactions and
	building Web sites,  there is always a Full Moon Rave at the seashore
	whether we bring our sound boxes or not.  The sea calls to us and 
	invites us to return to the perpetual party, to the perpetual rhythm
	of her song, for some of us, (dolphins, wales) the call was so 
	inviting that we did return and remerged our lives with hers, we forgot
	what it was to "build" and make tools and reverted back to the Vibe.
	As I stood up there I could see whole weather systems come in from off
	shore, great clouds of moisture coupled with large wind-swept waves
	would roll in to the beach and the Vibe of the beach wiuld get moist
	and soggy and wet, the music would even change, but eventually it would
	drain out and and the Vibe would change again, it made me wonder about
	mood and temperment and Vibe and how much of this is generated by
	us or are we just responding to greater natural forces.  Humans are
	so vain, we think that because we are on the top of the food chain
	that that is tantamount to divinity, but it is not.  As I sat up on the
	cliff, it was almost as if the wild plants and rocks and the very shore
	around me began to speak, but not in words, more like a type of Jazz
	(or at least what Jazz is an attempt at), The conversation was sorta 
	like:
		"Hey bro, you finally come round to hang huh?"
		"Those be your people down there? That's kool, they seem kool"
		"Yeah we was checkin you all out, you be the new plankton 
		in these parts?"
		"Say what? You not plankton?, Yeah, well you be usin that 
		phospholuminescent shit, we figured you be plankton"
		"Yeah, that little sista down there, who she be?"
		"Trace-E? oh oh Tracy"
		 Yeah,she be  catchin the groove now...,
		pretty kool, yeah she got it now..., 
		"we be tryin to tell your tribe that for a while now
		good thing your gettin it."

		I had my didgery-do with me, the locals said:

		"Can you Play?" 
		"What?"
		"you Play, can you Play?"
		I make a feable attempt at playing my Didge, the sound
		resonates with the morning sunrise.
		"Yeah, that's kool, you`ll get it" (being kind :)
		"OK we Play now..."

		I listen to the sound of crashing waves, flying insects
		and calling birds and realize that all of life vibrates
		in around and through us, Tracy is throwing down some serious
		beats below on the beach, I wonder if she realizes how
		tuned in she really is.  Anyone can learn to be a DJ, many
		can become great and accomplished but very few can gain the
		ability to set aside their Ego and let Creation play through
		them, that what makes a DJ into a Shaman or Shamaness :)

		As I bid fairwell to my plant friends they invited me back,
		"Don't worry, we'll be here tomorrow and the next day, century
		and milenium. Party every night"

		If this is an indication of the summer to come it will be
		a good one.  Tracy, who played for 4 hours straight has come
		into her own and has shown the way for many of us.  The Wicked
		boys should be proud of their protege.

	
			G

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NEXUS SYSTEMS/CYBERTRIBE-5 : Voice:(415)965-2384 
Editor/Instigator/Catalyst : Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>

	              RAVE: For a better tomorrow

		--PGP Public key available upon request--
     "If I can't trance, I don't want to be part of your revolution"

Recently , Tristan posted a consumer warning about the upcoming Orb show:
> 
> To all those getting so exited by the Orb show a few words of warning.
> Have any of you lot acctually seen the Orb before?  They don't play live 
> (and yes, Techno bands can perform live in just the same way that 
> rockbands do they are just using keyboeards, discks and drum machines) 
> they just push a few buttons and dance around a bit.  The light and 
> vissual show is really good but no better then a good light/slide show 
> from Donavn or Synergy.  And the music, especially the last few releases, 
> have sucked very badlly indeed. 

 Many folks on SFRaves have seen the Orb the last time they came to San
Francisco , and they mostly gave it positive reviews , as I remember.
For myself, I don't need a dynamic stage show or lights. Hearing their
music LOUD on a better speaker system than my home stereo system is
another plus point for me.

 IMHO, I like their most recent release just fine , so I don't think
the concert will be very much of a disappointment for me ...
it'll be my first Orb concert .

   Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

I've seen um before.  They played a huge, I mean huge mixing board,
turntables, and a set of conga drums (maybe a few other instruments, but I
was so out of my mind I can't remember).

I've seen Orbital twice, and each time all they did (for the most part) was
punch buttons on a mixing board.  They rarely touched the keyboards.  They
still kick ass though.  

I thought the Orb was great live or DAT, and I have no problem shelling out
$25 to see them. 

Just trying to balance out the vibe with a contrary opinion.

Rick

> (and yes, Techno bands can perform live in just the same way that 
> rockbands do they are just using keyboeards, discks and drum machines) 
> they just push a few buttons and dance around a bit.  The light and 
> vissual show is really good but no better then a good light/slide show 
> from Donavn or Synergy.  And the music, especially the last few releases, 
> have sucked very badlly indeed.  I just want people who are getting all 
> pumped for it only to read mail by lots of dissapointed punters the day after.

in, but what each one sounds like.
4)i don't think anyone is going to this show under false pretenses. 
5)it's $20. 
just getting things straightened out. Sorry.

mikebee

bunch of lame MTV bands!!  Depressing... 

I'm missing the LA show tonight so I can check out UFO but I'm coming up
to SF tomorrow for the show up there, hope to meet some of you... 

Andy

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>
>On Thu, 15 Jun 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:
>
>> To all those getting so exited by the Orb show a few words of warning.
>> Have any of you lot acctually seen the Orb before?  They don't play live
>> (and yes, Techno bands can perform live in just the same way that
>> rockbands do they are just using keyboeards, discks and drum machines)
>> they just push a few buttons and dance around a bit.  The light and
>> vissual show is really good but no better then a good light/slide show
>> from Donavn or Synergy.  And the music, especially the last few releases,
>> have sucked very badlly indeed.  I just want people who are getting all
>> pumped for it only to read mail by lots of dissapointed punters the day
>>after.


The whole POINT of going to see the Orb is to have the experience with 2000
people who also enjoy them.  I know they're not going to be up there waving
guitars and inviting girls from the audience to dance on stage.  But
neither does Dub Tribe, and I see no one slagging their concerts for being
a lot of knob-twiddling.  I don't think anyone is going with any of the
sort of illusions you seem to feel are running rampant ... at least, not
here in Vancouver.

As for the last few releases sucking, well, maybe for those who don't like
this sort of extremely esoteric musical experimentation.  I only heard
Pomme Fritz for the first time last weekend myself, the reason being that a
lot of people I know said it was awful, so I hadn't bothered.  I discovered
an incredible mixture of weird and wonderful layers that wove over and
around itself in amazing and lovely ways.  So nyah, I liked it!!!!

ANYWAYS .. that's my little spark for the day.  see y'all.


k

At 4:40 6/15/95, Kevin Keiper wrote:
>To all those getting so exited by the Orb show a few words of warning.
>Have any of you lot acctually seen the Orb before?  They don't play live
>(and yes, Techno bands can perform live in just the same way that
>rockbands do they are just using keyboeards, discks and drum machines)
>they just push a few buttons and dance around a bit.  The light and
>vissual show is really good but no better then a good light/slide show
>from Donavn or Synergy.  And the music, especially the last few releases,
>have sucked very badlly indeed.  I just want people who are getting all
>pumped for it only to read mail by lots of dissapointed punters the day after.
>(Which I sincerlly hope is not the case!)
>  You remember the Galaria show where Orbital played?  Now that was classic
>live techno at it's best.  Orbitall blow the Orb away anyday anyway so
>please don't expect it to be as good as that show.  I have seen the Orb
>three times when I was living in London and the first one was good but
>the other two got progressivly worse.  I am not trying to put a downer on
>the whole issue I just do not want people to be dissapointed.  In short,
>it's not worth $25.  Sorry.
>Love Tristan.

Jeez, an I thought you were turning a positive leaf after the full moon.

Last time I saw the Orb they were pretty incredible, and while some stuff
may have been off DAT they put a lot of work into their live show with
massive reworkings of recorded versions and tremendous visuals. Whether the
last few releases have sucked is a matter of opinion. I actually like
Pommes Frites and some of the Oxbow Lakes mixes. Haven't decided yet on
O.T. Regardless, the versions they're likely to play live will be wildly
different from the album versions.

And the show's $20, not $25...

Joe

 > To all those who were unfortuant  enough to miss last nights full-moon 
 > rave you missed what can only be described as one of the nicest full moon 
 > raves that I have ever been to (and I"ve been to a few!).  As with other 
 > cool parties/rave related issues in the bay area Mark and Tracy from 
 > Ameba were in full effect.  Tracy played some of the nicest music
 > that I have
 > heard at a party in years; she is with out a doubt a true master of
 > her art.

I just came to SF area a couple of weeks ago (live in London) and this
FMR was my First Real Meeting with Pacific Ocean and all that; so I
thought it must have been me: FMR couldn't be THAT AMAZING!

It's good to hear that other people actually shared shared the same
feeling: FMR WAS that amazing.

Mark and Tracy did a seriously great job. Tracy went on and on and on,
as if in some kind of understanding with those big slow waves.

Thanks to all,
-- Dusko

(I don't think FMRs would be better if they were bigger or easier to
access. A couple of guys stood and laughed at a dancer, until she put
on a sweater. How do you filter them out on a beach?)

The Orb is the big show this weekend; I think tickets are still available.
Also in town this weekend are Little Louie Vega (at Sound Factory), Joeski
(at Progress), jazz DJs Raphael and Takemura (at the On the One party), Moby 
at the Trocadero, and lots of European DJs at Wednesday's Making Waves 
festival and party (Teutonic Techno Temple).  Finally, the Gay/Lesbian Pride
parade has lots of floats with techno and house :)

Props to the Dust crew for going out with a bang last Friday, and the Friends
and Family crew for a great outdoor sol y luna party last Saturday...

       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.

       90.1 Stanford
     * Wednesday night mid-3am - "Cataklyzmol Pixel" ambient,
       experimental & noize - w/DJ Unknown, KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)

       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills

       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

On Thu, 15 Jun 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:
> To all those getting so exited by the Orb show a few words of warning.
> Have any of you lot acctually seen the Orb before?  

Yup, saw them on the last tour.

> They don't play live 
> (and yes, Techno bands can perform live in just the same way that 
> rockbands do they are just using keyboeards, discks and drum machines) 
> they just push a few buttons and dance around a bit.  

Ah, but what buttons!  :)  Actually, according to posts on the idm list, 
they are indeed using a wide array of samplers, keyboards, tape loops, 
etc.  They also play for a *long* time this round supposedly, 2 hours or 
something.

> The light and 
> vissual show is really good but no better then a good light/slide show 
> from Donavn or Synergy.  

Not to diminish any of it of course :)

> And the music, especially the last few releases, 
> have sucked very badlly indeed.  

Actually I was incredibly surprised by Orbus Terrarum - very rich in 
textures, very clean sound, very melodic.  They got their ya-ya's out 
with Pommes Frites, I think.  

> I just want people who are getting all 
> pumped for it only to read mail by lots of dissapointed punters the day after.
> (Which I sincerlly hope is not the case!)

Actually, people have been posting to the ambient and idm lists about the 
orb shows, and the vast majority have been positive (though a few 
negative of course).  You can read them in the archives on hyperreal.

	Brian

The Orb and "Orbital" are not the same band. (judging by post people were 
confused)  Orbital did Pome Fritz.  As far as I know there is only two
 original albums by the Orb available in 
this country.  My real thing I have about the Orb (and I don't disslike 
them, I am listening to Towers of Dub as I write) is that they do not 
write or perform all there stuff; they get in many outside writers and 
musicans such as Steve Hillage and Jah Wobble.  NOthing wrong with that 
you might say but I am old school and music that has only been made and 
produced the band themselves somehow has more sicerity asbout it then 
committee music.  This is one of the reasons I really like Orbital.  BUt 
that's just my own personal thang.
Tristan.
PS.  Please all have a good time.

No, the Orb did.  Please check out

http://hyperreal.com/music/artists/orb/www/

for an Orb discography and

http://hyperreal.com:70/1/music/artists/orbital

for an Orbital discography.

> As far as I know there is only two
>  original albums by the Orb available in 
> this country.  

Released domestically:

Adventures Beyond the Ultraworld
Aubrey Mixes -- The Ultraworld Excursions (out of print)
U.F.Orb
Live 93
Pomme Fritz
Orbus Terrarum

> My real thing I have about the Orb (and I don't disslike 
> them, I am listening to Towers of Dub as I write) is that they do not 
> write or perform all there stuff; they get in many outside writers and 
> musicans such as Steve Hillage and Jah Wobble.  NOthing wrong with that 
> you might say but I am old school and music that has only been made and 
> produced the band themselves somehow has more sicerity asbout it then 
> committee music.  

I don't think the Orb call creating a song "writing" so much as "getting 
really stoned with a bunch of friends and jamming on anything that would 
make a noise" :)   It's not new or unique, but yeah, Orbital probably 
deserve the moniker "songwriters" more.  But it really doesn't matter to 
me.

	Brian

larry,
best (and usually cheapest) bet for Warfield parking is the city run 
garage at 5th and mission - it's only a block and a half from the
warfield - there is a small parking lot in back of the warfield
and another lot on golden gate - about a block away - actually, 
come to think of it the 5th & mission lot may be more expensive than
one of the lots close to the warfield - you have to pay by the hour,
compared to one flat fee - anyway hope to meet you there!
jim cyr
