To: Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Rhyme and Reason United! (Philosophical)
In-Reply-To: <199506151357.GAA14941@nexsys.nexsys.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.APO.3.91.950616072502.4005F-100000@planecrash.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Sfravefriends,

	I am glad to be back with you again. Now being electronically 
hooked up from home rather than remotely, I hope to be a more regular 
contributor to the list.  Reading some of the recent posts, I was struck 
by some of what Geoff White wrote in his beautiful account of the Full 
Moon Rave at Panther Beach:


According to my server, on Thursday, 15 Jun 1995, Geoff White shared:

> Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 06:57:05 -0700
> From: Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: Full Moon Madness
> 
> 
> 	The universe operates on two governing principles,
> 	one is Reason,
> 	the other is Rhyme
> 	which is very close to rhythm
> 
> 	Our culture is fixated on Reason,
> 	The Sea is fixated on Rhyme,
>      
It seems to me that Geoff is alluding to several dichotomies when he 
writes of reason and rhyme:  man and nature, science and magic, logic and 
intuition, the brain and the heart/soul, the knowable and the unknowable.

But it also seems to me that these divisions are ones that we ourselves 
create.  As humans learn ever more about the nature of the universe and 
its creatures by means of our improving technology and accumulated 
understanding, the unfamiliar, the strange, the mysterious, loses for us 
some of its wonder and mystery.

Imagine if you will an Ohlone tribesman several hundred years ago taking 
part in a full moon celebration with native drums on Panther Beach, and 
standing on the very cliff Geoff White stood on last Monday evening.  How 
different his attitude toward the sea, not knowing that one day men would 
fly over it in airplanes, mine oil from its depths, sail under it in 
submarines, study the details of its creatures in aquariums, and relate 
the monthly and seasonal ebb and flow of its tides to the cycles of the 
moon and the patterns of ocean currents?  To the Ohlone it might have 
been a vast, frightening, beautiful, religious experience, a stretch of 
water of untold depth and unmeasured vastness, like space to us, populated 
with the Great Spirit only knows what alien creatures?

Thankfully, this romantic amd intensely spiritual view of the ocean may 
still be experienced by us of course, especially when we are in moods such 
as Geoff's.  However we will not have as easy a time of it, because we 
will inevitably be distracted by thoughts of Japanese cargo ships and 
weather monitoring satelites.  Because these things are familiar to us, 
and related to the "boring" world of media, commerce, contemporary 
culture and material things, we perceive them as non-magical.  I think 
this perception is a mistake.  The intricacies of how such things as the 
tides function in accordance with the laws of nature should be cause for wonder 
and appreciation for both the things themselves and the science by which 
they have become known to us, not a blind mysticism that worships nature 
and holds man and civilization in contempt.

Geoff's experience at Panther Beach was, I would guess, made more 
beautiful and memorable for him by many factors, among them:

-The sound system (perhaps carried at one point on a Japanese cargo 
	ship?) and music made possible by modern technology
-The contrast of the scene with his everyday, presumeably urban and 
	largely indoors existance, a facet of modern society
-Possibly the imbibing of one or more substances discovered through 
	modern pharmacology
-The knowledge that he would be able to share it later with the rest of 
	us by means of the net, a product of modern technology
-The fact that he (presumeably) reached the site swiftly by automobile, 
	in comfort, as opposed to trekking for many miles as the Ohlone might 
	have done...

Let's not put ourselves down.  Modern man is part of nature, and so too our 
constructions are part of nature, not in opposition to it.  The 
more we learn, the more that we learn there is left to learn, thus as our 
knowledge of science and the workings of the universe increases, so 
should increase our wonder and awe at its magic.  

The scientific is magical, and the magical has scientific explanations.  
Intuitively, I let logic guide me, and sometimes logic tells me I should 
rely on my intuition.  The heart is an organ that pumps blood, so where does 
the real "heart" or soul of each of us lie in the body if not in the 
intricacies of our brain?  When we say "mind" and "heart" and "soul", are we 
unknowingly refering to different aspects of the very same thing, like 
the blind men examining the elephant?  As for the knowable and the 
unknowable, mathematics has proven the existance of a fourth dimension, 
and mathematicians have designed representations of four-dimensional cubes, 
but from what I have heard, you can look at one and not understand it.  
We all use mundane objects such as pencils, but not one of us could make 
a #2 pencil from scratch, or even give the details of the process by 
which one is made.  Perhaps all things are individually knowable, but the 
interconnectedness of things, the big picture, is ultimately unknowable 
save by God, if such a creature exists.

I say surely if there is a Supreme Being, in such a being rhyme and 
reason would be united.  If we aspire to divinity, or at least earthly 
bliss and enlightenment, I think we must also try to achieve such a 
unity.  Some people may prefer the left or the right brain, but none of 
us can survive with half a brain.  I say embrace that which increases our 
ability to shape our environment, to know more about the universe, and to 
"do the impossible," without sacrificing our appreciation for the part of 
nature not created by humans and our delight at taking part in simple 
primitive pleasures such as dancing on the beach under the full moon.  
I want people to enjoy movies without forgetting it took a film crew, 
a director, lights, cameras, and much more to make them.  To lose 
themselves in the experience of the Pirates of the Carribean, and then 
afterwards be able to marvel at the imagination and ingenuity of its 
creators.  Leave the dichotomies behind, and we can have the best of both 
worlds.  Or, as a famous man who was both scientist and artist might have 
put it...

	"Plunged in his study of the problem of transmission of power by 
	means of blocks and levers, Leonardo (da Vinci) had forgotten the 
	machine.  He had just finished a complicated calculation.  The inner 
	necessity of reason, i.e. the law of mathematics, justified the outer 
	necessity of nature, i.e. the law of mechanics; two great secrets 
	blended into a single one that was still greater...

	"In his soul was that familiar emotion of reverent amazement 
	before the abyss into which he was peering -- an emotion which 
	has no similarity with any of the other emotions within the ken
	of man.  On the margins, alongside of the plan for the machine...
	alongside of the figures and calculations, he wrote down the 
	words which resounded in his heart like a prayer:

	"'O, that admirable justice of thine, Thou Prime Mover! To no force
	hast Thou denied the order and ability of its necessary effects; 
	inasmuch as, if it be supposed to move a body for a hundred
 	ells, and it meet an obstacle in its path, Thou hast ordained 	
	that the force of the impact produce new motion, receiving as 
	compensation for the untraversed distance divers jolts and shocks --
	oh, Thy divine necessity, Thou Prime Mover -- thus dost Thou compel
	with Thy laws all effects to flow out of the cause in the 
	shortest course. *There* is a miracle!'"

	-from "The Romance of Leonardo da Vinci" by Dmitri Merezhkovsky


******************************************************************************

			    *** Starchild ***        8)    

******************************************************************************

>Does anyone heading over to the Orb from Berkeley have room for two more in

From SFRaves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU Tue Apr 12 01:33:34 1994

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 94 01:37:14 MDT
From: Juggler <IH23%UTEP.bitnet@utepvm.ep.utexas.edu>
To: Vrave List <v-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu>
Subject: Little Red Raver Girl fairy tale!!

                     Little Red Raver Girl
                            by
                      Noah "juggler" Lee
              (respect to the original of course)


[ed's note: This evolved from a trip to Albuquerque for the Orbital X
rave. We had to keep ourselves entertained on the four hour drive with
no radio or tape deck. Gotta do something!!]


   Once upon a time, cuz, heck, what better time than that, there lived
Little Red Raver Girl. She was a happy little girl who loved to wear
baggy overalls and the grooviest striped shirts. Her red pigtails and
keen shoes could charm the Blow-Pop (tm) out of any raver's mouth.

   Well, it seems that Little Red Raver Girls's promoter grandmother was
not feeling so hot cuz an event she was throwing wasn't going so great.
Little Red Raver Girl decided to take a skippity trip over to her grand-
ma's house to deliver some lollipops, a new whistle, and a hit of X. She
only wanted Grandma Promoter to feel better. :)

   Little Red Raver Girl set out into the scary city with a warning from
her tired out hippy mother, who warned her of the evils of the world. As
usual it went in one ear and out the other. Little Red Raver Girl only
wanted peaz and unity and didn't like to hear about the bad people out
there because they gave off such bad vibes.

  Hippity, trippy skipping down the avenue whistling some housy, funky
toon, Little Red Raver Girl hardly noticed the Big Bad Gothic Girl come
out of the shadows of an alley.

"Whoa!" said Little Red Raver Girl, "You put quite a fright into me!"

"Yeah, whats new?" angrily replied the Big Bad Gothic Girl.

"Hey, you wanna sticker? I got heart stickers!! Or how about a
lollipop?" asked Little Red Raver Girl.

"Nah, I don't want no stinking lollipop," gothically replied Big Bad
Gothic Girl. "Where you think you're headed to in this dark, cold,
miserable world of ours??"

"Well," said Little Red Raver Girl, "i'm off to see Grandma Promoter
to deliver some goodies so she can be happy and throw the phattest event
this side of the world."

"Big event eh?" interestingly replied Big Bad Gothic Girl. She thought
to herself, "Hmmmm....you know I bet if I get those goodies I could
throw a dark, scary event the way I want it."

"Well, I best be off now. Peace, love and unity to you Ms. Gothic Girl."

"Uhh...yeah, sure."

And Little Red Raver Girl was off. But so was Big Bad Gothic Girl.
Seeing as how she hung out in dark alleys all night she happened to know
a shortcut to Grandma Promoter's warehouse. She sped ahead to beat
Little Red Raver Girl there.

[here's a plot twist in the story! Oooooohhhh!!!]

Little Red Raver Girl continued on her way wondering why someone would
paint their face chalk white and wear all black clothing on such a
beautiful day. Just as she was daytripping this she ran into a funky
phresh young man stepping from a record store.

"Yowza!" exclaimed Little Bloo DJ Guy, "Sorry about the bumping action
there."

"Oh excuse me! I wasn't watching where I was going. Would you like a
sticker? A lollipop?"

"Yeah! Sure! Thanks a lot!"

"Here ya go," said Little Red Raver Girl as she stuck on a groovy frog
sticker onto Little Bloo DJ Guy's chest. She hands him a lollipop and
asks, "Are you a DJ by any chance?"

"I certainly am! In fact i'm supposed to be spinning later at Grandma
Promoters event. You going??"

"Yesssss!!! I'm her granddaughter! I'm Little Red Raver Girl! I bet you
are Little Bloo DJ Guy then!" exclaimed she. Quite a good guess too
seeing as how he had on a bloo hoody shirt with "Bloo DJ" in holographic
type on it. She's quite the quick witted one ya know. :)

"Yep! That's me! I'm sooo happy to meet you! Hey, I gotta run but i'm
going over to Grandma Promoter's Houze of Funky Toons for the Pre-Party,
so I hope I see you there," said Little Bloo DJ Guy.

"You sure will. Be seeing you later!" happily exclaimed Little Red Raver
Girl. And off went Little Bloo Dj Guy. Little Red Raver Girl breathed
a sigh, for Little Bloo DJ Guy was sooo sweet and just the nicest guy
she had met in the longest time. She really wanted to hear him spin
and get to know him better. "Maybe at the pre-show," she excitedly
thought.

[Meanwhile...]

   Back at Grandma Promoter's Houze of Funky Toons, the bass was
bumping as Grandma prepared for the rave and was stressing hard getting
ready for the show. Then, all of a sudden a "ding, dong, boom boom boom"
came from her specially designed doorbell.

"Who is it??" asked Grandma Promoter.

"Tis me! Little Red Raver Girl" replied a slightly gruff and not quite
happy voice.

"I best let her in to help me and cheer her up. She sounds as bad as
I do!" thought Grandma Promoter to herself and opened the door.

As soon as she had in leaped Big Bad Gothic Girl and she quickly tied
up Grandma Promoter in a extra long pair of fishnet stockings and
handcuffed her to the sink in the bathroom with her handcuff belt.

"You can't do this! It doesn't promote peace and unity!" cried Grandma
Promoter. "Lemme go and i'll hook you up with a hit of X and you can
dance all night with us and feel the groove. I guarantee you'll feel
better."

"Nice try grandma. Stuff it," and Big Bad Gothic Girl promptly
crammed a black candle into Grandma Promoter's mouth to quiet her down.
She then went on to change the music to something much less happy and
got into some of Grandma's  clothes. "Ick...these are soooo bright and
happy. I think i'll throw up."

At just about the time she was done there came a sound in the warehouse,
"ding, dong boom boom boom."

"Yeah, who is it??" asked Big Bad Gothic Girl who was now dressed like
Grandma Promoter.

"It's me!! Little Red Raver Girl!!" came the reply. "Let me in Grandma!
We need to change that music and make you feel phresh!"

Big Bad Gothic Girl opened the door and let Little Red Raver Girl in.

"Why Grandma! What a pale, icky, clammy white face you have!" said
Little Red Raver Girl.

"The better to scare you with my dear." came the reply.

"Why Grandma! What morbid, black fingernails you have!" exclaimed Little
Red Raver Girl.

"The better to scratch off your face with you little happy hippie wanna
be!!" yelled Big Bad Gothic Girl and she LEAPED from her baggies and
pounced on Little Red Raver Girl.

Just at that moment the door swung open and in sped Little Bloo DJ Guy
with his patented Bag O' DJ Music. He rapidly threw on the phattest of
toons and started spinning and cutting it up as best as he could.

As he did this, a strange feeling overcame Big Bad Gothic Girl. She
felt a pumping bass shaking her body. She felt a warmth overcome her
entire soul. She wanted to stop almost, but she couldn't help herself
from getting up off of Little Red Raver Girl and dance. She got down.
She boogied. She threw massive moves. Little Red Raver Girl rushed to
the john and freed Grandma Promoter. They went out to the dancefloor
right as a large crowd had gathered at the door. The pre-party was in
full effect and at the heart of it was Big Bad Gothic Girl dancing
everyone into amazement. She gave everyone a hug and some a kiss she
felt so good. The vibe was the best they had ever felt that night.
Grandma's event went off like never before and was of legend promoter
proportions. Little Bloo Dj Guy spun his best set and fell deeply in
love with Little Red Raver Girl to everyones happiness.

And they lived happily ever after.

T h e  E n d.

[The people in this story are totally fictional and any relation to any-
one in real life is purely coincidence. Heck, I made it up on a trip
for Christs sake!! :) Hope you liked it. You can reprint it, distribute
it to anywhere you want as long as you don't modify it and keep my
name attached to it as the author. Peace to all of you and keep the
vibe alive. - - - Juggler [Noah Lee - ih23@utep.bitnet]

For those wishing to connect my body with my postings, I will be:

1) tall
2) with long hair pulled back, samurai-style
3) wearing my Marvin the Martian t-shirt and
4) funky one-leg-red, one-leg-yellow long shorts
5) at the dinner also unless events intervene

ObRave: I would like to echo Geoff's sentiments.  Though I was not
at Panther Beach that night, I know (I think) the experience he
describes, of being really aware of the moment and one's surroundings.
We-as-humans have been walking the earth for thousands of generations,
and we-as-animals (there is no sharp line, here) for millions more.
The rhythms of moon, sun, season, and a thousand other things we have
forgotten are deeply imbedded in our consciousness.
	When we step out of our concrete, metal, stone, and tin boxes
(how often do you see box shapes in nature?) and really _see_ our
surroundings, the glow of recognition is palpable.  Clouds, sand, dirt,
plants, animals, we know these.  We have known them for hundreds of
millions of years.  Cars, buildings, roads, cops, televisions, we don't
know these.  We are like kids playing with matches; we have no experience
or understanding of them.
	Sure, we can intellectualize about techno-toys, their
effect on us, why we have them, but we are not, fundamentally, logical
animals.  Our visceral understanding of them is limited to their intersection
with experiences we already know, and we mistake the representation (TV,
movies, concerts) for the lived experience (dancing, making music, love, the
hunt).
	We _know_ all-night dance orgies, from way back.  Waaaaay back.
It's that pesky superego getting in our way, usually constructed by other
overintellectualized types to make us serve their representational desires
(more money, more stuff, a false sense of control over entropy), that keeps
us on the fringes, afraid to jump in the fire and get down with the demons
of your subconscious.
	You've got a big hindbrain.  Don't be afraid to use it >%^)

// g

Well as most everyone's excitement lies in seeing the Orb, my excitement 
is going to Sunset this Sunday!
I don't know about the Bay Area, but Sacramento's skies have begun to 
clear up real nice, so maybe my freverant and desperate hoping may have 
done some good.  Maybe I'll perform some more sun rituals and dances to 
assure nice weather for Sunday. ;) 
Now I have to just cross my fingers that Sunset won't be too far to 
drive from Sacramento.  I've been looking forward to this for almost a 
month now, and I'd just die if it were held in Santa Cruz. :(  I'm also 
bringing 5 people along *with* me - 6 of us crammed into the raver 
wagon!  One of the people (who is toting his conga drum) has never been 
to any kind of rave event, so I thought a nice free Sunset saturated with great 
vibe will be a good first.  Doncha think so? :) 

So then for those of you sfravers how have not yet met me, I am about 
5'6" with long straight reddish-brown hair.  If it's nice and warm (pleez 
pleez) I'll be wearing my lavendar overall shorts.  Please come and say 
hi, I adore meeting fellow sfravers and their friends!  

giddy with anticipation,
Amy

Do you consider my "electro" DJ name in bad taste?
 I will be spinning at CHAOS 415.552.2398 sat 17th

My take on the electro revival is: Some funky attempts at drum programming 
were made under the guise "electro". After a long period of trying to mix 
trance and disco, I realised that its more fun to mix electro and techno. I grew 
up in Mountain View and  the electro vibe cruised the El Camino Real in low 
trucks.When I heard that bass, I was always concerned that my ass was about 
to be kicked.

On listening to LTJ Bukem's "Horizons" release again this week, I was
completely captivated by the vocal fragment on this track.  Consider
this if you think jungle isn't worth bothering with:

    Each new hour
    holds new chances
    for new beginnings.

    The horizon leans forward
    offering you space to place
    new steps of change.


peace

phred

From: Peter Fogel <peterf@netcom.com>
Subject: Raving in LA
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9506170759.A145-0100000@netcom3>

Precedence: bulk

Here I am, still on my visit in LA.  Got back a little while ago from a 
rave called nectar.  Great party!  Thank you socal-ravers who recommended 
it to me.
Things sure have turned around for me on this trip after having a ruff 
start.  Got a good dose of traffic, pouring rain, and a $55 parking ticket.
Enuff said about that stuff.
This party started at 3am, music and sound system were great.  A little 
different set up from the usual sf partys.  Rather than having most of 
the people facing the dj, here the dj was off to the side, and most of 
the people dancing were facing this wall of speakers.
Is this typical at LA partys?
This party had a nice vibe, no separate chill out music, but some spaces 
to chill out away from the dance floor with fantasia being shown on the wall.
It was great to share some of the beautiful energy at this party.
Its nice to see the sun shining today, hope its like that in sf, where 
i'm going to try and make it to the sunset party.
Hope everyone who went to the orb show in sf had a great time.  It 
sounded like the orb had quite a show down here.
speak to you all later, got to get some breakfast.


;)

peter

Well I'd have to say that The Orb was one of the bestest concerts Ive been to
in a while.  The Visuals, the peoples, THe dance floor (If you could call it
that ;).

I don't think words are ness. to express the musical majick that transposed
that lovely friday night.....   
The traceable factor was so, that I caught that natural high vibe and am
thankful ti will be one of thoese memories that'll will be kept intact (un
like the many, many fragmented memories of other raves...).

The only down side would be that I'd assume The Warfield would be better
equipped on the H2O front.  I mean seriously out of water b-4 midnite?

Fun Factor:

            Frendz & Hugs: 9 smiles
   Funky Sample score: 9 smiles
    Light show antics:   9 smiles

Overall a resounding 9....

Seeya'll at Cosmibog or Progress (or if in any case, I can get a 411 on any
renegades)....

they whipped me around pretty good !  you had to keep keep dancing, 
cause they would trick you to thinking they were going into another
lull, but then it would kick kick back in, and if you werent still
mesmerized and moving, you would not be on it when it came down 
again :)  

what a wonderful show !  yeah, the dance floor was crampy - it's 
tough when you want to flail your arms, and cant.  those guys looked
so cool behind there boards !  is it typical for them to go from
slow to pumping to slow to pumping ?  i coulda just kept pumping,
pumping myself :)

doug

Message-Id: <v01510101ac0909073f53@[204.19.170.86]>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Sat, 17 Jun 1995 18:12:54 -0500
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ecto@python.magnet.ca (ecto)
Subject: help me! :)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Hey everybody!
        I was wondering if i could ask for your help.  I'm helping out with
a party here in Montreal on July 8th and me and the others involved are
wanting to do something a bit different.  We're planning on stapling some
small info sheets to the tickets that ppl will buy in stores.  The info
sheets will be partially about the djs, their music, bios etc and a
definite emphasis on the importance of M-U-S-I-C and dancing.  We ALSO
wanted to include some short bits about PLUR, why we 'rave,' and other
ambiguous philosophical things which we feel are very important, especially
at this juncture in our scene (and, from the sounds of it, everywhere else
:( ).  So, we're going to start with a bit about 'why we're throwing this
party' which will lead to some quesitons that one would have to ask
themselves about why they are going to the party.  THis is where y'all come
in.  Because we don't want to come off as pedagogical or preachy (i
personally beleive that the best way to teach is by example but you can't
do that on paper all the time, y'know) so we're looking for input from all
of you bright, intelligent and pllurrrry people who've given ME so much
inspiration and insight in the past.
        I guess i can't specifically ask what i'm looking for: in general,
just inspirational words, ideas about why _you_ go out to parties and do
watcha do, ideas about P.L.U.R., about things that raves have to offer,
things you'd like to see more at parties, things you'd like to see less of
at parties, and so on.  The main emphasis of this will be 100% positive, as
we think that it will attract more positivity rather than DONT DO THIS or
DONT DO THAT which will usually make ppl do those things.
        Well, any help would be appreciated.  You can either reply
privately or to the list, and let me know if you'd like to be accredited by
putting your email address/name beside your thoughts or whether you'd like
to remain anonymous.  Also, if you could include your area of the west
coast (to show that there are ppl thinking the way that you do ALL OVER)
it'd be cool.
        thanks a lot for your time :)
        peace,
                brad

!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?

                                        -the irresistible force

There wasn't as many really freaky people there this time. 
I remember at the '93 show the Day Glow Tribal Dancers running
through the crowd and the guy with the light suit dancing on
stage. Too bad they didn't have more DJs also. I didn't care
much for DJ Lewis, it was a bit to fast for me.  
All and all it was a pretty good show and well worth the $20.



-Sean

-SeanC@scruznet.com

To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Sincerity vs Remixing (was Re: Orb show post )
In-reply-to: Your message of "Thu, 15 Jun 95 17:34:15 PDT."
             <Pine.A32.3.91.950615172610.47440B-100000@itsa.ucsf.edu> 
Date: Sat, 17 Jun 95 17:25:00 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Tristan writez:
| My real thing I have about the Orb (and I don't disslike 
| them, I am listening to Towers of Dub as I write) is that they do not 
| write or perform all there stuff; they get in many outside writers and 
| musicans such as Steve Hillage and Jah Wobble. NOthing wrong with that 
| you might say but I am old school and music that has only been made and 
| produced the band themselves somehow has more sicerity asbout it then 
| committee music.

Uh, this is a pretty lame statement. It seems like you're actually 
dismissing a lot of great music that has come out of "committee" music,
aka sampling, remixing, dub-versions, blues, rock, or what have you. I
hate to break it to you, but this is what music is about, and has been
that way for a long time. Composers stealing and embellishing a theme
from another composer they respect/admire, Blues artists covering and
mutating "traditional" tunes of unknown origin, british rock bands
and/or the greatful dead covering these selfsame toonz, changing them
and calling them their own. And rap/hip-hoppers sampling old school
funk into boppin new songs. If it wasn't for the fact that all music is
made by a "committee" that consists of all the musics and musicians
that every musician has ever been influenced by... if it weren't for
that fact, we simply wouldn't recognize the stuff we hear as music.

With the orb, your comment is especially out of line because i see this
band as being one of the biggest promoters of the dub-influenced sound
to the techno masses. remixing and versioning was going on full well in
Jamaica in the late 60's and early 70's -- i have some of the material
and it's positively awesome, trancy, butt-moving sounds. The orb have
done a good job of transitioning the sound into the 90's, melding it
with techno sounds etc. Listen to some Lee Scratch Perry (who the Orb
sample occasionally -- a tip of the hat) and you'll hear a lot of stuff
that sounds vaguely proto-trance/techno/electro-like even though it was
all done  20 years ago in incredibly primitive studios w/ incredibly
primitive equipment (tape splicing and dubbing, live remixing and 
mastering, etc). The Orb aren't the only ones doing this and if you dig
a little deeper you can also find that dubby techno sound in Tack>>Head
and various early Adrian Sherwood On-U productsion...

Are the Orb sincere musicians? Absolutely. Was Lee Scratch Perry
sincere when he crafted (but never got recognized for) Bob Marley's
early sounds that jettisoned him to stardom and there's sincerity where
L.S.P. was creating incredibly spacy dub plates... And aren't the
Stones the Dead, and the Beatles sincere as they version classic US
blues numbers for the rock world? Yes....

(w/r/t earlier comment about the "global music committee", i do have 
problems w/ music that goes beyond musical because it stands alone and
apart from what we consider "musical"... this is essentially the
problem i had with the too-fast stuff that  DJ Lewis was playing before
the Orb show -- i get the same kinda feeling when i listen to my
computer's CPU by sticking a transistor radio up close to the box --
fast, impentetrable, and meanlingless). IMHO. ((fortunately the orb
themselves and the Dig-Truth/Dust afterparfty were *great* and even
though i tweaked long and hard last night, if feel positively bubbly
and good afterwards.)).

PS: sorry this is scattered. i'm too giddy to make this make sense.

	"Every day they cut another version"
				-- Lee Scratch Perry.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

I printed this out from a post I got from sfraves on November 2, 1994 
right after Friends and Family IV.  These inspirational words were on the 
visual screen and is a pretty good summation of why I rave:

BECAUSE WE CELEBRATE LIFE AND BATTLE
BECAUSE WE ARE NOT SATISFIED
BECAUSE IT IS UP TO US
BECAUSE WE LOVE TO SING AND DANCE
BECAUSE THE PRESSURE IS UPON US
BECAUSE THERE ARE GOVERNMENTS AND BORDERS AND COPS AND COURTS
BECAUSE THE BOUNDARIES MUST BE BROKEN
BECAUSE WE ARE OUT OF CONTROL
BECAUSE THEY SAID WE COULDN'T DO IT
BECAUSE WE FEEL LIKE IT

keeping it alive,
love,
Amy Starkey              sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu
                         Sacramento, California

[ To SFRaves mailist ]

As far as The Orb is concerned , if Tristan is the SFRaves Little Fluffy 
Cloud #1, then I guess I'm LFC #2 ...

 I actually enjoyed seeing again all the folks I know from other rave 
events more than I did listening to The Orb. Why? Well , I'll try to 
list the reasons ...

1. I had been awake since 5:30AM Friday morning , and even a nap in the
   balcony didn't get me fully rested. The late dinner at 8:30PM didn't
   help.

2. Pre-Orb/Post-Orb dj music was uninspired for the most part.

3. Too much bottom end ( Most folks are probably going HUH!??!? ). I like
   The Orb's music , but mostly for the aspects of their music apart from 
   the rythmic component. I couldn't hear what I came to hear. 

4. The $#%! strobe lights , aimed over the heads of the dancers and into
   the eyes of everyone else.

5. I didn't start dancing to The Orb until 2/3 into their set - I had 
   been listening to them upstairs. I enjoyed it more when my body was
   doing something. 

 As for pure fun, I had more of that dancing to house music at the 
1015 Folsom afterwards - that was the free admission event that Mark Ameba
was handing out flyers for. I had my choice of 70's disco or two rooms
of house music - ended up in the basement for some pure joy! (HappyHappy!).

 Congratulations to those who had a good time listening/dancing to The Orb!
See you guys at Sunset ...

Little Fluffy Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jun 18 09:53:59 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA15641; Sun, 18 Jun 1995 09:53:59 -0700

	id JAA55540; Sun, 18 Jun 1995 09:54:16 -0700
Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 09:54:16 -0700 (PDT)
From: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: The Orb Show.
Message-ID: <Pine.A32.3.91.950618090442.81254A-100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yes it was a good light show wasn't it?  And yes they did play live.  And 
yes, I am sure that if one was on acid it would have been a very 
memorable show.  BUt music that can only be appreciated on drugs is 
exactly like people on drugs: you will only ever see superficiallity and 
stuff like covictions (remember that as a reason for getting into 
music?) go straight out of te window.  And give me the equipment and two 
fingers and I, or anybody on 
this net for that matter, can do stuff better then that.  The Orb have 
done for techno what Michael Jackson did for pop/disco: they have trivalized 
it to the point where comerciality comes way ahead of talent; but who 
gives a fuck so long as the kids by it?
In my opnion, after seeing a good live show one should feel like they know 
the mucians and composers better; that while these people are not 
personal friends at least we can relate to them as people.  I didn't 
even know which one Alex Patterson was and nothing during the show made 
me think about anything to do with him.  In short, the show had no 
concept about it bassically because the music was to week to be worthy 
of one.  When one consideres other great techno bands such as Orbital or
Caberet Voltaire or Kraftwerk one can easily answer basic thematic 
questions such as "how do you look at life?" "do you believe in love?" 
"what kind of thing's in your past made you look at life in this way?"  
"How do you look at life?"  This can be done through music, lyrics, samples, 
song titles, and live with visuals or theaterics.  After an Orbital show or 
album, for example, you can listen to a track and see the situation that it 
relates to in your minds eye ("I wish I had Duck Feet" or "Monday" for 
example).  In short, to be able to write sheer escapism music like House 
one has to be an extreamly good mucian and "The Orb" most certainly do 
not cut it in this department.
In short, the whole show represented all the worse aspects of the music 
industry.  It had loads of hype, it was extreamly short on quality and 
talent and everyone left the show thinking it was fucking amazing while 
record industry suit types were watching in the wings with $ signs in 
their eyes.  Wasn't the whole underground scene set up in the first 
place to get away from bullshit such as this?  Ah well, I guess we have 
all become victims of our own success.  And do I care?  No, I am to busy 
going out, taking drugs and having to good a time to ever think or 
care about it.
Tristan.

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Here's my 2c on the Orb at the Warfield:

- The light show was good, unless you were sitting in the balcony,
  where the strobes could give you a headache quick..

- I thought the DJ was great!  It certainly wasn't SF style, but
  when I heard it, I thought, "how come nobody plays *this* shit anymore?"
  that's what i call rave music.

- Music was great, unless, again, you were sitting in the balcony.
  Up there it was mud city.

all in all, i would give it an 8.5 from the main/dance floor perspective..

-e

Subject: sunset and more
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Well I left LA early this morning feeling good about my visit.  It was 
nice to leave with no traffic and plenty of sunshine which was just the 
opposite coming in.  Sorry I didn't get to meet anybody from the 
socal-raves list, but I do feel closer to you all after being able to go 
to a good rave there and share the energy.
Driving back I had plenty of time to enjoy some tunes and philosiphy a 
bit as I enjoyed the nice scenery.  I thought a bit about how much I been 
gaining  by learning more about how to recognize the beingness in 
everything thus adding to my own state of beingness.  I feel I got to 
thank raving for helping me alot with this.  To me dancing is such a 
great way to show recognition in the beingness of the music the people 
and the whole enviroment.  As we all recogize the music together, there 
is then a recognition in the beauty of our togetherness which we all can 
get high  from.
This sure happened in abundance at the sunset party which i am so HAPPY i 
made it back in time for.  As usual this sunset party was GREAT!  The 
vibe was so thick you couldn't cut it with a chainsaw.  A beautiful sunny 
clear day, great music and so many friendly people.  I really enjoyed the 
socializing when I did, which wasn't much away from the dance floor.  I 
felt I couldn't leave the dance area much as it was so filled with 
BEAUTIFUL energy and it felt so good to be able to share it.
So here I am still basking in the afterglow.  Feeling so good, thought I 
share some of it with all you beautiful people through in cyberspace.

;)
peter

I spoke at sunset with one of the people involved with putting on the 
progress party, and I think she said that the sound guy or the the guy 
who owns the equiptment (not good on details while I'm raving) thought 
the fog was too much for the equiptment so it didn't happen.  But she did 
say they are going to put on another to make up for that one.  If your 
wondering when, uh, ( those details again), I don't know but I remember 
that its soon.  Sorry about those details, I'm sure somebody out there 
may get them details if your interested.  One detail I do remember is 
that there next scheduled progress party is at big heart city.  Its been 
awhile since i been there.  I've had some great times in that space.  
OOhh those tuesday together partys in the basement.  Anybody remember  
those.  I used to have  weds off and used to have a great time tues night in 
that sweaty basement when I went.

The dark rainy cloud torts:


KE>In short, the whole show represented all the worse aspects of the music
KE>industry.  It had loads of hype, it was extreamly short on quality and
KE>talent and everyone left the show thinking it was fucking amazing while
KE>record industry suit types were watching in the wings with $ signs in
KE>their eyes.  Wasn't the whole underground scene set up in the first
KE>place to get away from bullshit such as this?  Ah well, I guess we have
KE>all become victims of our own success.  And do I care?  No, I am to busy
KE>going out, taking drugs and having to good a time to ever think or
KE>care about it.
KE>Tristan.

You know Tristan. I wasn't going to reply to any of your post about the
orb because I knew every would just delete your post anyways, after
reading them and forget what they said. But read on:

I work with musicians on a daily basis. Both with my day job and with
the business I own on the side. I would like to see you get in front of
all that equipment and churn out stuff one tenth as good. If you can
then mail it to me at:
K&D enterprises
1901 P street
Sacramento , ca 95814

I will send those songs to a couple of record companies. If one of those
songs become popular I am going to take a picture of the $$$$$$ in your
eyes and then show you a print out of this post.

I take your last post as a complete insult to the music industry. There
is no underground in music once it becomes released to the public. Even
house underground is public and popular and about money. That's why the
musicians work hard. To pay the bills. I'm sure when you go to work you
think about money! If you don't then your a gimp.

  Read your post about not liking the orb then read this next statement:

WHY THE PHUCK DID YOU GO TO THE CONCERT?

I don't mind people voiceing their opinion over sfraves but, Tristan,
you are way too predictable! Your post don't excite the senses!

My computer tells me that on Sun, 18 Jun 1995, Kevin Keiper shared (in part):

> Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 09:54:16 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.edu>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: The Orb Show.

> Ah well, I guess we have all become victims of our own success.  
> And do I care?  No, I am to busy going out, taking drugs and having 
> too good a time to ever think or care about it.
>

I'm sure that the rest of Tristan's comments on the Orb show will be 
flamed and discussed at length [:)], so I feel no need to add my voice to 
the din, being less knowledgeable about the music than many here and not 
actually having experienced the show anyway.

However her closing words, sarcastic though they may have been, should 
give us all pause for thought.  After the after-party at 150 Folsom I was 
given a ride home by some kind Monterey ravers (thanx guys!) and one of 
them let me photocopy an article she had on the rave scene in England.  I 
think it illustrates quite well how much more aware, committed and 
involved our counterparts across the Atlantic are when it comes to larger 
social issues beyond simply throwing and attending parties.  The article 
is fairly long and I am too tired to type it in now, but I promise to 
post it soon.
**
			--------------------------------
"Oppressed peoples, suppressed ideas, and persecuted individuals 
throughout history have had one important thing in common: nonconformity."
			--------------------------------

				*** Starchild ***

 	(Damn, now I feel all melancholy like Big Bad Gothic Girl...)  ;)

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: The Orb Show
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Tristan wrote:

> I didn't even know which one Alex Patterson was and nothing during the 
>show made me think about anything to do with him. 
>In short, the show had no 
>concept about it bassically because the music was to week to be worthy 
>of one.   When one consideres other great techno bands such as Orbital or
>Caberet Voltaire or Kraftwerk one can easily answer basic thematic 
>questions such as "how do you look at life?" "do you believe in love?" 
>"what kind of thing's in your past made you look at life in this way?"  
>"How do you look at life?"
 

Personally I went to this show to enjoy the music, which I did very much. 
I did not go to "see" Alex Patterson, I went to escape into the music and to
be carried to other wonderful places. I think Alex Patterson/Orb was
successful
in NOT bringing the focus to himself. This show was not about an audience all

focused on a performer (at least not for me). I was not at all interested in
someone
elses *concept* or a show *theme*.  I let this music move me at a very basic
simple 
level. 

It may be interesting to compare Orbital, the Orb, etc based on *themes*, or
*concepts*, 
or other thought based layers above the raw basic music. But when you throw
out all that
over-analysis and get down to the underlying music.. The Orb music draws me
in and
moves me at the most basic level. It takes me to some amazing places that
other, more refined, 
developed, contrived music simply can't.  I very much enjoy Orbital, but it's
more *head* music 
for me. The Orb very much is head and *body* and the show definetly moved
*both* for me. 

Just my opinion,
martin

PS. I can see how someone who was just maybe sitting in the balcony the whole
time and was not 
really  "in" the mood (and i'm not talking just drugs) to be moved could have
been dissapointed. It's funny how music is so many different things to
different people.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jun 19 09:21:25 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA15627; Mon, 19 Jun 1995 09:21:25 -0700

	id AA23424; Mon, 19 Jun 95 09:21:17 PDT
Date: Mon, 19 Jun 95 09:21:17 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9506191621.AA23424@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Orb/Sunset report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Tristan whines:
> yes, I am sure that if one was on acid it would have been a very 
> memorable show.
 
I can't understand why anyone would go to a show like this unenhanced.
Janie and I went expecting complete sensory overstimulation and the
Orb totally delivered.  We found a great spot downstairs; the sound
swirled around us, the visuals engulfed us, we were blown away, and it 
was fabulous!
 
> BUt music that can only be appreciated on drugs is 
> exactly like people on drugs: you will only ever see superficiallity and 

Perhaps you speak of your own experiences in which case I can only
feel sorry for you.  But with the Orb show, I'm not sure we were supposed 
to be looking for anything deep and meaningful anyway.  It was a crazy
journey to the beyond in which sensory overload became a vehicle for a 
transcendental experience.  Now that I think of it, this kind of communal 
letting go *is* meangingful, and has always been a big part of what raving 
is all about - our ability to go beyond our limits.   As the show 
progressed, everyone around us on the main floor was going nuts in a manic
tribal celebration of perceptual insanity.  But it was also apparent that 
we were not supposed to take things too seriously as the Orb would 
periodically inject silliness into the stew to reground us.
 
> In my opnion, after seeing a good live show one should feel like they know 
> the mucians and composers better; that while these people are not 
> personal friends at least we can relate to them as people.
 
Y'know, I couldn't disagree more with this.  I couldn't care less about 
who Patterson is as a person.  The whole point of techno is that the
creation transcends the creator; the DJ or musician becomes a shaman, a 
guide to another world.  I left the whole personal-statement-from-the-artist
trip behind a long time ago.  It even seemed silly to us that a "band" was
present at all.  Luckily we couldn't really see the live musicians in
front of the stage stupidly playing their instruments.  At one point during 
the frenzy, I wondered how many ravers thought they were at a rock show, 
and how many rock show poeple thought they were at a rave.  All I knew was 
that whatever it was, it was fantastic!
 
> In short, the whole show represented all the worse aspects of the music 
> industry.  It had loads of hype, [...]
 
Actually, I'd say it represented the *best* aspect of the industry:
the ability to deliver PIZAZZ.  The one thing of value that the entertainment 
industies  have to offer is big production, simply because they have the 
technology and money.  Unfortunately, corporate-inspired entertainment 
rarely caters to psychedelic sensibilities like the Orb did.  In that 
regard the Orb was much better than any show I've seen, easily surpassing
the last time I saw Pink Floyd a trillion years ago.

After the Orb ended, many of the supercharged remained to be treated to
a great set by DJ Lewis who spun some tasty electrotrance on the 
Warfield's big system.   People raved pretty hard until we were thrown
out at around 3:30.  We hopped over to 1015 Folsom with free passes, but
the scene there was too much of a comedown so we decided to chill out in
anticipation of Sunday's Sunset.

Sunset, back at the Berkely Marina with the Karma Kids was, as usual, 
utterly great.  Nick Philips started out which one of the best ambient 
sets I've heard in a while.  Galen followed, picking things up a bit, then 
Loren gave us some juicy house to sink our teeth into.  Solar followed with 
one of his harder  sets and really got the crowd going.  John Howard kept 
the energy level high... Wow, we must have danced for 6 hours on Sunday 
along  with the shitload of SFRavers, old timers and new timers in 
attendance.  We didn't stay for the end, so I'm assuming everyone sang 
Happy Birthday to Galen when it was over.

We'll probably take next week off but are already looking forward to
Freedom on July 1st, which like last year will be at the Livermore
racetrack.  Nothing like a good outdoor massive.  Ahh.

Lee
_______________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

>Yes it was a good light show wasn't it?  And yes they did play live.  And 
>yes, I am sure that if one was on acid it would have been a very 
>memorable show.  

>In short, the whole show represented all the worse aspects of the music 
>industry.  It had loads of hype, it was extreamly short on quality and 
>talent and everyone left the show thinking it was fucking amazing while 
>record industry suit types were watching in the wings with $ signs in 
>their eyes.  Wasn't the whole underground scene set up in the first 
>place to get away from bullshit such as this?  Ah well, I guess we have 
>all become victims of our own success.  And do I care?  No, I am to busy 
>going out, taking drugs and having to good a time to ever think or 
>care about it.
>Tristan.
>
>

I wasn't on any drugs for this show, and I had a great time.  One of the
best times I've had at a concert yet.  All I can remember from the last Orb
show, and the last Orbital show in SF, was that I had fun...but I was so
high at them that I can't remember what happened.  I'll always be able to
remember this show as one of the best.  

I liked how most of the tracks seemed to have more hard bass in them which
made them more dancy.  I was able to go places in my mind that in the past
only drugs would induce.  IN MY OPINION, the Orb is still genius.  They have
taken me on trips in my mind that no other band has.  When listing as
background music, the samples always come in at just the right time in
conversation.  IMO it is state of consciousness that determines what music
sounds like and the way it affects you.  IMO we create our own reality.  If
my opinion is correct, then my positive attitude before seeing the show had
a great affect on it.  It was a great show for me, I was totally amazed.
Regardless if everyone in the world thinked they sucked, my experience was
splended...

This is not a flame on Tristan, but he didn't seem to have a very good
attitude going into the show and just maybe, just maybe that's why he had
difficulty with it.

Thoughts

Rick

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Sunset afterglow
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

I was so elated to find out that Sunset would be at Berkeley Marina! :)  
That is such an ideal spot with a beautiful view of San Francisco.

I had *such* a good time and danced hard - hell, who didn't? Saw many 
familiar faces, and met about 20 new people.  I feel so happy to be a 
part of sfraves.  All of the sfravers I have met so far - and that is 
*alot* - have been absolutely WONDERFUL!! Being on sfraves has given me 
the opportunity to know so many of you - and each of you is so unique 
and special.  Everywhere I turned at the Sunset party I saw someone I 
recognized or knew, and it made me feel, even more, that I was 
surrounded by *family*.  And that is the kind of closeness and community 
that I find is so unique to raving.  I felt the warmness from EVERYONE 
and the energy was addicting. I had brought an old friend of mine who 
has never been to a "rave-type" event before and he ended up doing alot 
of dancing and feeling the energy. I love bringing "newbies" because I 
feel so proud to be a part of all this, and when I bring them to 
somethig like sunset, I can say "This is ME!!" :):):)
I'm *so* happy that Sunset will now be a weekly thing.  I took up a roll 
of film with some great shots of many sfravers I met.  I'll bring them 
on July 2nd to show 'em to ya.  

Have a great week!
love,
Amy

> questions such as "how do you look at life?" "do you believe in love?" 
> "what kind of thing's in your past made you look at life in this way?"  
> "How do you look at life?"  This can be done through music, lyrics, samples, 
> song titles, and live with visuals or theaterics.  After an Orbital show or 
> album, for example, you can listen to a track and see the situation that it 
> relates to in your minds eye ("I wish I had Duck Feet" or "Monday" for 
> example).  In short, to be able to write sheer escapism music like House 
> one has to be an extreamly good mucian and "The Orb" most certainly do 
> not cut it in this department.

>concept about it bassically because the music was to week to be worthy 
>of one.   When one consideres other great techno bands such as Orbital or
>Caberet Voltaire or Kraftwerk one can easily answer basic thematic 
>questions such as "how do you look at life?" "do you believe in love?" 

Maybe you need to go attend a real rock concert, with a real star on
stage spreading his/her legs wide and trying to look cool (look at me
I'm a rock god!) while noodling up and down the guitar neck in full
masturbatory regalia. I've seen plenty of that, and it gets *old* after
a while, (but at least you'll know the names of the lead guitarist and
lead singer.)

If I wanted more cult-of-personality signer/songwriter schtick, there's
plenty out there to choose from. I don't think that's the "techno"
style, except for maybe Moby... 

And, IMHO, the Orb was much a much more interesting live performance
than Cabaret Voltaire.

I think you're being ridiculous to think that Kraftwerk or Cab Voltaire
are going to give you the answers or a theme behind life or love. If I
want life/love-themes, I'll listen to Bob Dylan lyrics -- for example
the lyrics to his "Blood on the Tracks" LP, ancient though it may be,
speaks more to love/live than any Orb or Orbital tracks. Part of that
is because Dylan's poetry is evocative, it literally speaks to you and
reminds you of lost loves, lost lives, love, anger, emotion, and
sentiment. The "evocativeness" is in the poetry and lyrics -- complete
sentences or stanzas are a lost art in the era of the sample and the
sound byte and the 10 second attention span.

There's nothing comparitively lyrical and evocative in techno, which is
fine, because it "speaks" to a more basic, less structured, and perhaps
more primitive part of the psyche. In some sense "techno" is all sound
and fury signifying nothing. And that's good and fine too.

I'd say you (Tristan) are looking for love/life in all the wrong
places. I listen to the Orb and other "techno" "dub" etc to shake my
booty and forget/escape/surpass/overview the quagmires of love and
life. Words are more often than not tinged with lies, deceit and
pretense. Techno speaks straight to the boppin' of de booty and the
mind temporarily freed from the chains of rationality and language.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

At 9:30 6/19/95, Rick Riffle wrote:

>>On Sun, 18 Jun 1995 niemitz@cats.ucsc.edu wrote:
>>
>>> of Cameo's "word up," alex didn't get his hair caught
>>> in the console ( i was worried for a while that he might),
>>
>> Alex would have had to be doing something rather special for this to
>>happen since he has very little hair with the exception of the shortish
>>braided pony tail.
>
>
>What was all that stuff hanging in his face then?

Alex was the guy on the left in the black and white shirt, not the guy by
the mixing board on the right.

I thought the show was pretty good, with some nice versions of some of
their tracks, especially "Towers of Dub." The sound really disappointed me,
however. During the DJ's set it was sorely overdriven and while it was a
bit better during the live show it was still brittle and harsh.

The afterparty was amazingly good. Lee played a stellar set, the visuals
were cool, and the vibe was excellent.

Joe

From: Timothy McIntyre <timothym@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>

Subject: great weekend
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Wow!  This sure was a pretty thick weekend for me; thought I'd say hi to all
of you and let you know what transpired...
I went to the Orb show with SFRaver Reza and had a fantastic Friday night. I
think I was equally impressed by both the Orb *and* DJ Lewis, who blew me away
at the Warfield... it was so nice to hear FAST FAST music!  
We headed over to the afterparty being put on by the Dust crew around 2:30,
met up with more friends and caught the vibE and danced to more excellent spin-
ning, especially from Jon Carel, who closed the party with some of the best st            
stuff I've ever heard. 
After quite a bit of dancing and splashing about (we noticed that water can be
a lot of fun when tossed in the air), we headed back to Berkeley for some sleep,.
My roommate and I woke up around noon, had lunch with a friend, and then stopped
by some friends' house, where I listened to my friend spin some brilliantly
FAST stuff, which was so much more fun to dance to for me than the music I'm 

used to hearing. Hey all you DJ's out there!  How 'bout some slices of 180 bpm?
It tastes reeeeeallly good. Anyway, Progress was next on the agenda, but we 
bought tix for 5 dollars and then the thing was rained out. Do any Progress
people plan on giving refunds soon?  We have 9 tickets here! 
So Saturday night we crashed in the aforementioned friends' attic back in B,
and Sunday was nice and peaceful.  Sunset was the weekend's cherry-on-top, and
it was as great as it always is to bump into so many of you there.

(blissful sigh) Whew... Mondays are so hard.
See you all out there
Timothy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jun 19 13:35:44 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: sunset 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

John Howard 
absolutely ruled my world at Sunset
to borrow a friend's phrase, it was my cup of tea

I finally, briefly, met Amy S - which was a pleasure.
Mike, the san mateo sfraver, had a nice hometown revelation. 
I felt the same way meeting another astronomer/raver the other weekend 
... we seem to share an affinity for photons *and* feather boas. 

The central dance area was in the funkiest little bowl.  It was cozy to
perfection.  From every spot you could see just about everybody else.  I like
it when you are dancing and looking around and then you momentarily lock with someone
across the crowd.  Besides the thirty yards and 200 people in between that sorta
thing tends to leave me speechless no matter what.  Note also, how much I 
adored the tragic weeping on the grass.  It was very greek amphitheatre.

After dark, there was an intense torchlit communal groove.  What seemed
to be simmering in the afternoon turned into overflow writhing.

so much fun,
Dave

	Tristan, it is an oft-repeated bit of wisdom in the country of
my people that he or she who accuses one of having no clue is quite
often the clueless one. Maybe it would behoove you to more closely
read the posts you so cleverly rip to shreds before priming the
flamethrower. Two small points:

	a) It is rather pointless to say that someone is less clueful
than one when one is discussing opinions, and in fact tends to make
one look like a bit of an ass.

	b) Niels was specifically discussing the merits of seeing the
Orb vs seeing CV _live_. Although it's not particularly germane
because it is, again, an opinion, I thought I'd point out that I've
heard plenty of live recordings of both, and I strongly prefer live
Orb stuff to live CV stuff.

I thought the Orb were quite good. I didn't like the Warfield that much 
but the music was extremely tripped(and I wasn't on drugs). Whoever says the 
Orb does not have talent can't really know that much about music.

pretentious.

     Amy Starkey sez:
     
     "And that is the kind of closeness and community that I find is so 
     unique to raving.  I felt the warmness from EVERYONE and the energy 
     was addicting." 
     
     ------
     Not to belabor a point, but after being out of the scene for a couple 
     of weeks and going through alot of personal stuff, I have to agree 
     with Amy.  At first I thought I was going through music & dancing 
     withdrawals, and then I thought it was some other type of withdrawal 
     ;) but the reality of what I was missing in the past two weeks was the 
     connectivity and joy that I felt at Sunset.  Thanks Pacific crew for 
     bringing us together!
     
     It was truly a good time for me as I needed a release or escape from 
     day-to-day pressures and was able to let go of the negative energy 
     that's been bapping me over the head.
     
     I finally met some more sfravers, too.  I felt very much like a newbie 
     gaggling over the fact that I met so many of the people I've 
     identified with and/or appreciated for their contributions to the list 
     (or even for making it happen!).  Thanks Peter for grabbing me to the 
     "sfraves circle" and introducing me to the group.  As I started 
     conversing w/y'all, I felt a surge of energy rise in the air--a 
     definite sign for me that things were going to take off.  It was great 
     to see Lee and Jaimie again.  And to finally meet Amy, Laura, Brian, 
     Neils, Seth (Welcome!), Mike and a few others who's names I can't 
     remember right now.  
     
     Looking forward to meeting more of you as time goes on. 
     
     Warm embraces,
     Diane
     
     P.S.  I think it'd be fun to have a pre-Burning Man get together of 
     sfravers to see who might need a rides, etc.  I, personally, would 
     rather have people seated in my vehicle and contribute towards a 
     rented van to haul my water and art supplies.  If anyone's interested 
     in meeting, e-mail me privately and I'll arrange something...perhaps 
     at Sunset or something less formal.  In any case, let me know.  
     
     P.P.S.  My lil' guy just discovered chi energy while stretching in bed 
     this morning.  Isn't it great to know some raised awareness is rubbing 
     off in the world?--Ok, so this is kinda out there, but if you know 
     what I'm talking about, you'd be excited too!


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jun 19 14:09:11 1995

	for sfraves@hyperreal.com id AA26141; Mon, 19 Jun 95 14:04:53 -0700
Message-Id: <9506192104.AA26141@xinet.COM>
X-Sender: rhea@xinet
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 14:06:15 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: rhea@xinet.COM (Rhea Gossett)
Subject: Re: The Orb Show
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I agree with Niels' message for the most part,
but on this one point, I have to *resoundingly* disagree!

>....The "evocativeness" is in [Dylan's] poetry and lyrics -- complete
>sentences or stanzas are a lost art in the era of the sample and the
>sound byte and the 10 second attention span.
>
>There's nothing comparitively lyrical and evocative in techno, which is
>fine, because it "speaks" to a more basic, less structured, and perhaps
>more primitive part of the psyche. In some sense "techno" is all sound
>and fury signifying nothing.

This is so different from my own feelings about techno music  -
for me, techno is the most lyrical, most evocative music I have yet found.

It has inspired my passions and thoughts, and connected me
with my emotions like no other music.  In its beat, I feel rhythm,
patterns, a cycle like life or the beat of our hearts.
The "trancey," "acidy" sounds worm through my mind with the same
intensity as my own obsessions - put to music, though, I can watch
them squirm through my mind - thoughts turned to sounds, which I can
dance with, instead of blindly follow.

The vocal samples, in their endless loops, hold for me such poignancy
and longing - they are impossible, infinite, inhuman.  Voices removed from
meaning, or any hope of meaning save than which we, the listeners,
bring to them - their digitized humanity is so plaintive,
electronicly cut-off from context, made "mute" in the face of technology,
that they become paradoxically human and inhuman at the same time.

I do not listen to music for, as Tristan stated earlier:
an "answer" to "basic thematic questions such as 'how do you look
at life?' 'do you believe in love?'"

I do not want to be fed these "answers," through the interpretations
of someone else - we get these standardized formulaic answers so often,
from everywhere, every day.  Techno/trance/ambient music
provides the soundtrack for my own internal "movie" -
my own themes, refrains, cast of characters.  The sound moves me
through my own imaginings, and doesn't limit me
to specific themes or moods like conventional songs/musical genres/
lyrics do.

Instead, techno music lets me create my own questions, and,
my own *answers* - my mind is free to move, imagine, dream with
the music to a place where my thoughts take me.  When I feel FREE,
_then_ I dance - I am SELF conscious, not self-conscious, and I can
move with joy and understanding inside my mind & body.

This process of listening, responding, interpreting, relating,
moving, dancing, *being* - is not just a way to feel about techno music,
but the best way, so far, for me to try to _live_ that I have
found...

Sorry this is so long.
Rhea

bit better during the live show it was still brittle and harsh.

The afterparty was amazingly good. Lee played a stellar set, the visuals
were cool, and the vibe was excellent.

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk


Tristan wrote:
> I didn't even know which one Alex Patterson was and nothing during the 
>show made me think about anything to do with him. 
>In short, the show had no 
>concept about it bassically because the music was to week to be worthy 
>of one.   When one consideres other great techno bands such as Orbital or
>Caberet Voltaire or Kraftwerk one can easily answer basic thematic 
>questions such as "how do you look at life?" "do you believe in love?" 

Maybe you need to go attend a real rock concert, with a real star on
stage spreading his/her legs wide and trying to look cool (look at me
I'm a rock god!) while noodling up and down the guitar neck in full
masturbatory regalia. I've seen plenty of that, and it gets *old* after
a while, (but at least you'll know the names of the lead guitarist and
lead singer.)

If I wanted more cult-of-personality signer/songwriter schtick, there's
plenty out there to choose from. I don't think that's the "techno"
style, except for maybe Moby... 

And, IMHO, the Orb was much a much more interesting live performance
than Cabaret Voltaire.

I think you're being ridiculous to think that Kraftwerk or Cab Voltaire
are going to give you the answers or a theme behind life or love. If I
want life/love-themes, I'll listen to Bob Dylan lyrics -- for example
the lyrics to his "Blood on the Tracks" LP, ancient though it may be,
speaks more to love/live than any Orb or Orbital tracks. Part of that
is because Dylan's poetry is evocative, it literally speaks to you and
reminds you of lost loves, lost lives, love, anger, emotion, and
sentiment. The "evocativeness" is in the poetry and lyrics -- complete
sentences or stanzas are a lost art in the era of the sample and the
sound byte and the 10 second attention span.

There's nothing comparitively lyrical and evocative in techno, which is
fine, because it "speaks" to a more basic, less structured, and perhaps
more primitive part of the psyche. In some sense "techno" is all sound
and fury signifying nothing. And that's good and fine too.

I'd say you (Tristan) are looking for love/life in all the wrong
places. I listen to the Orb and other "techno" "dub" etc to shake my
booty and forget/escape/surpass/overview the quagmires of love and
life. Words are more often than not tinged with lies, deceit and
pretense. Techno speaks straight to the boppin' of de booty and the
mind temporarily freed from the chains of rationality and language.

        Thank you to all who sent me ideas to put on the little info sheets
that we're going to attatch to the tickets for this party, it's really
appreciated and i hope it goes over well :)
        Also, i'd just like to *briefly* say that i'm really amazed by the
lot of you sometimes.  When confronted with a lot of negativity (no names
mentioned) i see a lot of work at empathizing and discussing and
acceptance, with a few flames but it's only normal.  I guess i just think
that, with me at least, i confront negativity with positivity rather than
feeding the flames (no pun int.) Understanding is the only way we can all
get this culture and, i guess, this planet going along in a good direction.
y'all should be proud of yourselves.  I also wanted to say that i too used
to be kind of a bummer type of guy but, though i hate to pinpoint it so
specifically, when i got a little hElp i really REALLY began to see things
in a different way.  I used to think i was 'realistic' in being cynical and
depressive.  I realized that i was just being cynical and depressive.  So
i've been there and i know that it's not a permanent thing, you just need a
little help and support from others, be they chemical entities or not =)
        sorry, that wasn't as brief as i'd wanted to, oh well.
        peace n hugs n positivity n sunshine
                        brad

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 17:45:37 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@collab.com>
Subject: my lives, misc list-flaming, and my thoughts
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi,

This is my first post containing real content to this list. It's kind of a
mish mash of things, but if you have the time, I would appreciate it if you
could read it.

I have been on this list since June 12th. I have only been to a few raves,
but that's changing quickly. :)

I am actually writing to the list and saying these words because I too
(like tristan?), and not that long ago, was a very cynical person. Dark
humor and cutting words ruled my world. I probably did it as some kind of
release. I don't know for sure. What I do know was that it really wore on
me, and it overshadowed my spirit, and over the years, dulled my aura, so
to speak. Upon further, honest introspection, I knew that it was not a good
thing. These deep, dark feelings reared their ugly head in conversations,
in relationships, in friendships. Deep down, I wasn't that happy with the
person I was, and people around me probably weren't that happy with me
either.

Coincidentally, about two months ago, I crashed a party down the hall from
my place that happened to be a small rave. To my benefit, a few special
friends introduced me to their rave scene (SYNTONIC!) and I feel that I
have been changed forever. After my enlightenment, I can now easily explain
to someone that you that you can tell someone to be happy, but until you
show them what it is to be happy, they will not understand. You might as
well be speaking to them in a foreign tongue, because they probably won't
get it. It's really sad, because they may even have some fleeting thoughts
about being happy, but until they have been led to it, they may never find
it on their own.

The most powerful and surprising thing I have received from this (scene and
list) is the support and major _positive vibe_ from each and every person I
have met in this scene. They (you!) have been my inspiration and my
unknowing (but willing!) 'support group' that's helped me find and keep and
remember that positive energy that I get from our experiences together. The
benefit is that I feel so spiritually cleansed, and I feel like so much of
that dark baggage of the past is gone. Often, I think back to the person I
was just a couple months ago and look at the person I am today, and also
think of the person I will become tomorrow (hopefully!) and just can't
believe what an awesome, magical force that exists in your (now our)
incredibly enlightened culture.

Anyway, I read this list not just to find out the happenings (although to
tell you the truth that's why I originally subscribed), but to also read
the words that people are writing that's coming from their hearts and their
soul, which was an unknown-to-me added bonus of the sfraves-list scene. The
poems and post-happening experiences messages are really cool. I often feel
the same way as these people do about the events we've gone to (sol y luna,
orb, dust/truth, sunset!!) and the parallels of our experiences. The
positive energy of both the events and the list are great.

Now the place where this is all breaking down for me, I have to mention
something about. Every once in a while, one of our fellow list-members pops
up his head, takes a cynical pot-shot at something and then goes away. It
brings me down. I don't want to auto-filter his messages, because in an
idealistic way, I really want to hear what _everybody_ has to say. I
actually take the time to read and ingest read each and every message, and
I feel like I learn something interesting or valuable from most all of
them. I just get the impression that our friend's 180 degrees out of sync
with the open and feeling vibe that this list and culture seems to be all
about. I don't want to preach to him, but I wish that he could be as lucky
as I have been in making a transformation to a more positive contributor
(spiritually, if nothing else!) to the scene. I think he really needs his
friends (that's you?!) to help him through this difficult time so that he
can really 'find the other side'. It's really much more fun over here where
all his friends are. That's the side I am now on, and I would not trade it
for anything.

I don't want to ramble on much longer, but those of you who have known me
for a while (some of you have known me for years, some only for hours) know
that I don't write and emote this way often, if ever. I just had to get all
of these feelings off my chest and into your brains so you may hopefully
understand me and my new perspective a little better next time we meet.

And now, as they say, 'to sum it all up:'

-I used to have a bad attitude, and it was a dark cloud that affected all
   aspects of my life.
-I got a clue to the coolness* of this scene. (*the word 'coolness' does not do
   begin to do justice but I was feeling a bit short of words. sorry.)
-I opened my mind and my heart to new friends, and learned from them.
-I cleansed my spirit through sharing, caring, and regular check-ups (sunset!)
-I feel like I have now mostly left my old self behind.
-I want to thank my old friends that made this trip before me and that acted
   as my guide for helping me get to the other side.
-I wanted to share this with all my new friends that I truly care about SO MUCH
   that have helped me change my world in all their special ways.
-I want the same magic to happen for anybody that's having a hard time shedding
   their negative energy and old ways, that really wants to grow spiritually,
   and become a better human.

Remember, each of us has our own special interests, skills, and knowledge,
and none of us knows it all. When we get together to share ourselves with
each other, collectively, we can know a lot, and that's exciting. Everybody
I have met has something special they've shared with me that has added to
my collective knowledge, and it's been exciting. It just takes a good
attitude, a lot of caring, and leaving your ego at the door. The rest seems
to all just follow.

Thanks to everybody that's been there for me, and thanks in advance to
those of you I haven't met yet.

a big hug for all of you,
Wayne

same party.  The posts may always be positive, but I equate it to a 
really good song that is in several different mix tapes:  the song may be 
the same, but each time I hear it I get chills and could never tire of 
hearing it because of the different contexts surrounding the song in each 
mix tape.  That's the way I look at it anyway....

On Mon, 19 Jun 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

> I'd say you (Tristan) are looking for love/life in all the wrong
> places. I listen to the Orb and other "techno" "dub" etc to shake my
> booty and forget/escape/surpass/overview the quagmires of love and
> life. Words are more often than not tinged with lies, deceit and
> pretense. Techno speaks straight to the boppin' of de booty and the
> mind temporarily freed from the chains of rationality and language.

And Rhea Gossett added:
> I do not listen to music for, as Tristan stated earlier:
> an "answer" to "basic thematic questions such as 'how do you look
> at life?' 'do you believe in love?'"
> 
> I do not want to be fed these "answers," through the interpretations
> of someone else - we get these standardized formulaic answers so often,
> from everywhere, every day.  

	Possibly something is being overlooked here. Tristan didn't say he
was taking their answers (or questions derived from the stated questions)
as his own. He said that was how he got to know someone and indeed to
really know someone, one knows something about how another thinks on these
topics, don't they? I came at this from one perspective because I didn't
think one could really understand what an artist put into her or his work
without sittting down with the author, but there is a lot one can learn
about someone from the music they play - the various style spawns some
emotions and feelings and the such in the listener, and thus one does get
some sense of who the artist is (Granted it is not going to be a deep
understanding and I still have doubts about whether one can decipher the
thoughts on love and death from the emotions produced by the music). I 
may be m,issing the mark totally, in which case, I assume at least one 
message will find its way to me describing just how wrong I am so that I 
will not make such a mistake again....


dave
