Precedence: bulk


Although actually a bit dated, here are a few thoughts from that night :

My first impression was dissapointment at being ambushed with a $20 
cover charge at the door. For a show that had no price on either the 
flyer *or* the phone line, and was assumed to be somewhere around the $10 
listed price range of the failed May 12 show, I thought it to be a pretty 
bunk tactic. If you think your party's good enough to warrant such a 
steep price don't be afraid to admit it beforehand. Pull something like 
that again and I'll be forced to brand you a coward.

Once inside it seemed that there was a lack or personalities, or I guess 
you could say there was an abundance of personalities yet to be developed, 
although with time and effort and it didn't prove all that difficult to 
find neat people to bug out with. Life tends to be like that.

My biggest problem with the set up was that someone accidentally left the 
ambient room in the downstairs main floor and crammed the danceable 
material in an upstairs closet. The music that the masses were 
listening to was scictozphrenic, absent-minded, and timid...Like having 
virgin sex with your senile grandmother. Kinda fun at times but not the 
real orgasm.

I was all set to give bonus art-core points for the Naked Pagan Girls, but 
the 5th encore kind of overkilled that sentiment. Although I thought it 
was really interesting to see ((from what I saw)) that a mixed all-ages 
crowd treated the sometimes defenseless pair with quite a bit of 
respect. Call it San Francisco, call it House Music... I don't know, I 
was pretty impressed. Next time don't be afraid to parade some dick 
around as well.     

The visuals definatelly fell into the way-cool category. Finally someone 
who put a bit more effort into their trade than just running some nature 
slides or renting the mind's eye from Tower for the night. 

I still have mixed emotions about the eveaning. I think it could have been 
a far greater party than it was if the music being played was more 
appropriate for the space it was being played in. I haven't decided 
whether I'm willing to shell out $20 for a another CosmicBog party, but I 
appreciate the effort that went into their production and hope to see 
something equally creative, if not a bit more focused, from them in the 
future.

Bolger

Date: Tue, 21 Jun 1994 01:37:04 +1000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: Sunset - A perfect sunny sunday afternoon
Cc: ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sunset
======

I had planned to go to the Progress outdoor party,   but as usual,  it
was rained out.   I didn't want to pay $20 to go to "All together now",
although I hear it did go off.    I was still nauseated from the over
exposure to tobacco smoke from the Orb show,  and it's afterparty,  so
after going as far as Tam Junction,  I wisely turned around and went
home.

On Sunday afternoon,  waited for the info to be updated that was to give
out the location to Sunset.

We eventually left around 3 PM,  and discovered it had moved from where
it was last year.   After walking around for a while,   I discovered it
was closer to the water in a perfectly shaped grass bowl that was made
for this very purpose.   After scouting around for a wind sheltered
place,  I set up my blanket in time to hear some really spacy ambient
music that fit perfectly for just lying in the sun.   The day was
perfect,  although cool and windy.   There was this dude in a cart,
getting pulled around by his kite.   Lots of kite flying,  and people
just hanging out.

Later on,  Galen went on and gradually shifted the music towards the
beats and eventually people started dancing.   I had just returned from
walking around and discovered 20 people dancing already.

Galen started picking up the energy,  and it didn't take me long to
totally trance out to the music.   All through the afternoon,  the
outing was perfect in every detail.   There was a very high SFRave
quotient,  which is always a good indication of the quality of the vibe.

I don't know how many people showed up,   but it seemed to be over 200
to me,   but I wasn't really paying attention.    After Galen went on,
DJ Loren (Who I have seen around the scene,   but don't recall hearing
him spin),   spun some really good trancy house that really went off.

Then,   John Howard went on,  and really got the place hoppin.   People
cheering and really getting it on..  Then,  at the end,  we all sung
Happy Birthday to Galen,  and John spun a slower final song to end one
of the best Sunsets I've been at,  and my First since my return from Oz.

Ahhh!!  Looks like this is going to be one really killer summer.   WOW!
Solstice on Wednesday afternoon,  German trance that evening,   and who
knows what comes later...   Yowsa!!  I'm ready to rave...  and I might
just stay out of the clubs and give my lungs a break.   Lets keep these
outdoor parties churnin...

Crunchman

person.  If someone was being racist should I just say, "that's okay he's 
just voicing an opinion?  Stupid and ignorant opinions,  or opnions that 
can not stand up to healthly argument, are obviouslly not based on deep 
held convictions by the person holding the opnion so the only person you 
are really dissing is yourself.
You say that the Orb are better then Caberet Voltaire live.  I saw a Cab 
show the other day from 1983 and the light show was very similer to the 
Orb.  In short, you can not say the Orb were better live because they 
stole all their ideas from the Cab Kraftwerk and Pink Floyd in the first 
place.  All the Orb have done is re-hashed a bunch of old ideas, given it the 
coorperate touch, and watched their bank accounts rise.  And suckers like 
you fall for it every time.

and so i retort...

I like most of what comes in the mail box from s/f raves, and a few 
other lists that i'm on, it tends to give me something neat to read 
while i'm on the phone...

And all day long i talk with lazy negitive people, who whine and 
winge that they cant get things done, when a little common sence and 
reading of the manual will solve their problems.

Its a pitty that a few people on the sf raves list folow the same 
behavior. Most people who e-mail the list are positive caring 
THINKING people who realy want to leave this place better than they 
found it, thus the rave and anjoy raving.

Perhaps those who enjoy cutting things down, insted of giving an 
ailternitive, i suggest they theu go into the army, where they will 
mingle with like minded souls...
 
Or, if they also happen to be verbose, and have no real content, i 
recomend that they hang out around the state cap, or wash dc.

There are lots of list and news grps that kater to the flame bait/ 
negitive attitude that some immature people toss around.

Please if you want to bash some ones posting (like mine), e-mail the 
person directly. If you wish to bash a show/dj, how about saying 
something that you LIKEd about past perforamaces, or another 
group/person at the same show.

I DO like some of the 'negitive information' that comes acoss the 
list, places that had a chill room that was to small, 'un cool' 
locations etc etc. These people are not realy into the scene,
etc etc That is information that is usefull to us.
 

Its realy nice to see a 'review' of the partys/stuff. The more a 
reviewer posts about the partys/music /things that i goto/do the more 
i can guage 'oh this person likes concerts/sounds that i like'.If 
they think its good, perhaps ill make the effort to check it out.'

 
Please remember that all your messages to to LOTS of PEOPLES PRIVITE 
mail boxes, not just to some generic bord that we logon to, your 
opinion goes to a wide range of people, Some of how agree, or not, or 
dont care,some who dont want it.

Please try and remember that the messages are making a visit to some 
ones privite space, accurate helpfull information is (most of the 
time) allways welcome.

PRIVate feed back is welcome...
rev

Over the last few weeks, several different Detroit-based labels have
contacted me about doing a video or video-related projects for them.
I work for a large special effects house in LA, so I cannot take on
these jobs.  What I can do is recommend to them who might be able to
do the work.  We are looking for broadcast quality work of various
lengths.  MTV-esque videos, promotional videos, film & video performance
displays, and CD-Rom's are all possiblities being discussed.

The labels that are currently looking are +8, Planet E, and Transmat.
Please do not bombard them in regards to this, as that is specifically
what they wanted to avoid by having me screen talent.

If you are interested, please contact me and we'll talk.

	(5.65c/IDA-1.4.4.1-DomainOS) id AA28743; Tue, 20 Jun 1995 11:57:33 -0700
Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 11:57:33 -0700
From: Timothy McIntyre <timothym@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
Message-Id: <199506201857.AA28743@drought.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: taste
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Don't mean to stretch an already taut thread out any further, but all this 
bickering over whether or not such-and-such a troupe is better than group s                  
so-and-so seems terribly silly to me.  If an argument about artistic merit is
to be conducted, fine.  But the only time you can pull off a discussion like
that is when both parties maintain a mutual/irreverent/playful level of respect
with each other.  If that's the case, then quibble away. But once the discussion
descends into defiant posturing, it almost never goes anywhere; both sides
just dig their heels in deeper and spit farther.  So I propose that from now on,
if an argument turns into a venom exchange, it should just be dropped                      
altogether.  Does anyone else feel that way?
I'm reminded of an old David Bowie quote: a journalist asked him who was the best
(best) band in the world at the moment, and Bowie scratched his chin and said,
"You are aware, I hope, that nobody gets any medals at the end of all this?"
Just my thoughts. 
See you all out there,
Timothy

"Taste is the enemy of art" --U2

At 9:10 AM 6/20/95, Kevin Keiper wrote:
>Hey look;  racism is an opinion too but as any sound person knows it a).
>a wrong and bad opnion and b). it is an opnion made by an ignorant
>person.  If someone was being racist should I just say, "that's okay he's
>just voicing an opinion?  Stupid and ignorant opinions,  or opnions that
>can not stand up to healthly argument, are obviouslly not based on deep
>held convictions by the person holding the opnion so the only person you
>are really dissing is yourself.
>You say that the Orb are better then Caberet Voltaire live.  I saw a Cab
>show the other day from 1983 and the light show was very similer to the
>Orb.  In short, you can not say the Orb were better live because they
>stole all their ideas from the Cab Kraftwerk and Pink Floyd in the first
>place.  All the Orb have done is re-hashed a bunch of old ideas, given it the
>coorperate touch, and watched their bank accounts rise.  And suckers like
>you fall for it every time.

        the prevailing tool of postmodernist art is pastiche, the sampling
and recontextualizing of past works to form a 'new' work.  Knowing that
there is no such thing as an avant-garde (as 'everything has been done
before') we are left to, (to paraphrase Jean Baudrilliard) 'play with the
fragments of shattered modernity.' thus, pink floyd weren't 'original' nor
were caberet voltaire and nor are the orb..there is no such thing as
'originality' anymore, just the effecting and stimulative and articulate
recontextualization of past works of art...Cabaret Voltaire, btw, got their
name from the dadaists who were some of the original non-originals.
        brad

ps-->flame me if you want, i'm just trying to get some use out of my art
school degree ;)

From: Kyung Rok Lee <krok@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Breakdance Circles
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9506201427.A679-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Just wondering if any thoughts about the breakdance circles (for lack of 
a better term) that occasionally crop up @parties.  To my displeasure, I 
saw a lot of these at All Together Now last Saturday night.  Though 
actual breakdancing doesn't usually occur, you do find w/in these circles 
a lot of bodywork and generally showy (rehearsed?) moves.  IMO, those 
performance circles are the place where hip hop (which I love) 
and house clash.  These circles, like the ones formed around the two 
half-naked, fire-breathing female performers throughout the course of the 
evening, disrupt the flow of energy on the dancefloor, focussing it in 
one specific location, instead of having it flow through everyone -- as 
equals.  The phenomenon of BD circles probably has something to do with 
the relatively young age of a lot of the party-goers -- it definitely has 
something to do with a spirit, albeit usually friendly, of one-upsmanship 
that might lead to... fire-breathing breakdancers?  Hopefully not.  

rok

is still going strong.  There *is* a lot of attitude being thrown there,
it comes from the street.  It's a world many people can't relate to.

a better term) that occasionally crop up @parties.  To my displeasure, I 
saw a lot of these at All Together Now last Saturday night.  Though 
actual breakdancing doesn't usually occur, you do find w/in these circles 
a lot of bodywork and generally showy (rehearsed?) moves.  IMO, those 
performance circles are the place where hip hop (which I love) 
and house clash.  These circles, like the ones formed around the two 
half-naked, fire-breathing female performers throughout the course of the 
evening, disrupt the flow of energy on the dancefloor, focussing it in 
one specific location, instead of having it flow through everyone -- as 
equals.  The phenomenon of BD circles probably has something to do with 
the relatively young age of a lot of the party-goers -- it definitely has 
something to do with a spirit, albeit usually friendly, of one-upsmanship 
that might lead to... fire-breathing breakdancers?  Hopefully not.  

rok

I have to say that from the wilds of the East Coast, I have not enjoyed
these flame wars.  However, at the risk of trolling, allow me to posit that
the depth of conviction in which one's opinions are held are no protection
against stupidity or ignorance.  There were quite a few folx who were
convinced that slavery was divinely instituted, and sadly, there are still
people who are convinced that ravers are drug-addled maniacs.  IMHO, one is
convinced less by the tenacity with which one clings to his or her beliefs,
as by the reasonableness of the arguments offered to support those beliefs.

Just my .02.

> Stupid and ignorant opinions,  or opnions that can not stand up to
healthly argument, are obviouslly not >based on deep 
>held convictions by the person holding the opnion so the only person you 
>are really dissing is yourself.
Paul Richard
pp000267@interramp.com

I know it's unhealthy to repily when not reading all of the threads but this
sorta hits close to home....

What Ya'll call break dancing circles are in reality called Firewalking...

Firewalking is essntally predefined moves that are (or at least are tried) to
be performed in sync with the tremenosly fast moves (ie. 130-180BPM).  It's a
great excersice and helps create that naturall high.

As for additudes it depends on the raver, i guess.  I've been going out since
91 or 92 and I've ALWAYS been firewalking...  Back in 92' yea I threw
additude but now it seem that I tend to show respect 4 fellow firewalkers and
actually hooked up w/them to trade moves and vice a verse....

A lot of the affronting seems to stem from not so hot dancers...

So if ya see me, ask me, I'll be more than happy to teach ya a move or
two....

Peace and peanut butter,
Adam...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jun 21 00:12:53 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id AAA07637; Wed, 21 Jun 1995 00:12:53 -0700

	id AAA24509; Wed, 21 Jun 1995 00:11:23 -0700
Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 00:11:23 -0700
Message-Id: <199506210711.AAA24509@ix6.ix.netcom.com>
From: ascend@ix.netcom.com (Gregory Sandler)
Subject: Circle Dancing
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

	In fear of getting flamed, I feel I should say my opinions on 
	this subject. It is something that I think about at every party 
	I go to. Also the following comments are only my own opinions, 
	and should not be associated with anyone else from Harmony and 
	or Beautfiul People. (Cause their opinions may differ greatly.)

I feel that circle dancers have a great talent or gift of being able to 
move the way they do. I know that if I tried to do any of the things 
that they do I would probably end up with a broken back! So, I totally 
respect that! It is just like skateboarding or stunt-biking, it takes a 
lot of talent. 

However, one thing I think is a draw back to circle dancing is the 
amount of space that it takes up. I can deal with it a big huge parties, 
but not at smaller parties. Sometimes there just is not enough room. I 
just can't seem to find justification to take up half the dance floor to 
watch one dancer at a time. I feel that everyone should dance together. 
But at the same time I can understand  dancers wanting watch eachother, 
to learn new moves. Basically I feel that dancers should keep in mind 
how small or big the party is, and if there is enough room then great, 
go for it. But if not, then save it up for a later time.

*That is just something I thought should be brought up about circles. 

******Peace, love and harmony to all,*******

Greg

who hadem. The guy is over here from Scotland, and his trip got cancell

more prevalent in Scotish heritage. JUst explaning the why, but I agree 
its like sending up a flare, here we are come bust us,. But I still

cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Greg,
I totally agree with what you said.  Personally I prefer parties without 
circle dancing.  I feel more energy on the dance floor when everyone is 
dancing rather than having alot of people standing around watching, 
focussed on one dancer, rather than the whole.  For me I get the biggest 
rush when I can let myself go enough to experience as much of the whole 
room of dancers as possible, and it really adds to the rush when I feel 
like others are doing the same.  Speaking of standing around on the dance 
floor, I'd also prefer it if people are to have LONG conversations, they 
don't do it in the middle of the dance floor.  
For me the biggest problem I have with the circle dancing is also when 
there is a lack of space.  I've felt circle dancers pushing me, so that 
they can make their circle.  I don't think all circle dancers will do 
this disrespecting of others space, and I'm pretty sure that there are 
plenty of circle dancers who choose not to do it when there isn't much 
space.  For those of you out there, thank you,

:)
peter

My computer says that on Tue, 20 Jun 1995 THROCKA@aol.com shared:

> Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 20:07:32 -0400
> From: THROCKA@aol.com
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: fireworks
> 
> i have a problem with the fireworks
> they were pretty
> but
> we don't need to give the man
> any excuse to
> prevent further parties
> and i know i am not alone in this
> replies?

This touches a really critical issue.  How much should we refrain from 
expressing ourselves and trying to create the best possible atmosphere at 
parties due to concerns about the law?  Facility owners have been known 
to throw people taking drugs out of their buildings because they didn't 
want the reputation with the cops of a place that allows drugs.  I'm sure 
if they just turned people over to the cops directly it would create even 
more of a favorable impression with the powers that be.

Wouldn't it be nice if we lived in a society where we had the freedom to 
do what we want as long as we didn't hurt anyone else?  I for one believe 
in change and am optimistic we may eventually get there.  But it won't 
happen through self-censorship.  It *will* happen through enough people 
taking a stand for freedom.  Let the fireworks begin!

				*** Starchild ***
______________________________________________________________________________
"People who don't stand for something will go for anything." 
-from "Let Me See Your I.D.", Artists United Against Apartheid album.
______________________________________________________________________________

From anarchy-list-request@cwi.nl Wed Jun 21 02:28:58 1995
Return-Path: <anarchy-list-request@cwi.nl>
Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 10:20:29 +0000
From: cllv13 <cllv13@ccsun.strath.ac.uk>
To: anarchy-list@cwi.nl
Subject: Treason in the Park!
X-Sun-Charset: US-ASCII
Content-Length: 775
Sender: anarchy-list-request@cwi.nl
X-Lines: 26
Status: RO

Treason in the Park!

Sunday, 18th June. Glasgow Anarchist Group organise a
Temporary Autonomous Zone (TAZ) in Kelvingrove Park in direct
defiance of the draconian Criminal (In)Justice Act.

The TAZ, a fund raiser for the Scottish Federation of Anarchists
and the Glasgow Solidarity Centre, was an all day rave and
very well attended. The venue, a bandstand in a public park,
is under threat of being sold off by the council for private
development so the TAZ showed that the bandstand should be 
left as it is, for use by those who own it - the people of
Glasgow.

The event was very  well attended and the police kept well away.
As well as music, food was provided and anarchist stalls
did well.

A good day was had by all.

Pearl
*****
GAG-SFA
PO Box 1008
Glasgow
G42 8AA


----- End Included Message -----

> Wouldn't it be nice if we lived in a society where we had the freedom to 
> do what we want as long as we didn't hurt anyone else?  I for one believe 
> in change and am optimistic we may eventually get there.  But it won't 
> happen through self-censorship.  It *will* happen through enough people

The other problem I have with these fireworks is the guys that usually set them
off have more investment in being seen as Promytheous rather than giving
the crowd a need fireworks display, so they set them off right next to the crown
where more than once I've seen the fireworks burn somebodies backpack or
land on someone's head.  Also if you are drunk or dosed YOU SHOULD NOT BE
OPERATING FIREWORKS plain and simple.  If we were at the beach and someone
who knew what they were doing wanted to put on a display and shot them up in a
responsible manner I'd be less negative about it but the bottom line is that
almost all of the fireworks experiences I have had at parties in the last
3 years have ended in  either something catching on fire or sending up
a locator flare for the Police (Pt. Richmond in '93 as an example).

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9506211640.AA25404@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Freedom
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Wouldn't it be nice if we lived in a society where we had the freedom to 
> do what we want as long as we didn't hurt anyone else? 

Unfortunately, people exercising their freedoms rarely allow themselves
to be aware of the hurt they inflict on others.  Too busy being "free"
to notice.  Whether it's breakdance circles destroying the sense of 
unity, or fireworks bringing on the heat, or ambient DJs jarring spaced
out tripsters with punk tunes (sorry allen ;), or cigarette smokers in 
nonventilated venues, or people who cut the line, stand or sit down on 
the dance floor, or incesssantly blow their whistles...

Realistically, we usually can't do whatever we want without hurting 
*someone*.   Of course, "hurt" can range from mere annoyance to 
absolute terror; everyone has different sensibilities.  And there are 
those who say that some pain is good for you.  Thinking about all this, 
it's easy to see why humans have been killing each other so much over
the years.

But I've been amazed at how well the rave scene has managed to "police" 
itself while maintaining a strong sense of freedom.  The paradox of 
promoting  unity while respecting individuality is a challenge, and it's 
been fun to see it work.

Raving has nothing to do with anarchy.  They operate more as TAZs - 
Temporary Autonomous Zones, which are self-GOVERNING.

Fortunately, there are different kinds of parties we can go to.  Some 
will welcome nitrous, others won't.   Fortunately, like-minded folks 
have the ability to throw their own parties with their own preferances,
and each of us can choose where to go and feel the most "free". 

Just some semi-random thoughts.  Speaking of freedom, a belated happy 
Gay Pride day to all those who value our ability to love one another.

Lee
_______________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com

> 
> > Wouldn't it be nice if we lived in a society where we had the freedom to 
> > do what we want as long as we didn't hurt anyone else?  

It would be great. But I would suggest that the fireworks at Sunset posed two
problems: 

Attracting the police. 
It seems that that the Sunset parties have a rep with
the police for being "responsible" parties. So the police don't really care.
However, if we pose a fire risk... then they may feel compelled to interfere
and not only does that wreck the party at that moment..but it can potentially
wreck future parties as well. Why test this particular boundary?

Fire. 
Dry grass. High winds. Fireworks. Seems like a nutty combination.


> >I for one believe 
> > in change and am optimistic we may eventually get there.  But it won't 
> > happen through self-censorship. 


I would suggest that discouraging fireworks would be called intelligent 
self-policing, not self-censorship. Although not necessarily so, when I think
of censorship, I primarily think of the censorship of ideas. 
When I think of self-policing.. I think of reining in innapropriate actions. 
Of course, what may be inappropriate to me may be appropriate to 
others, I guess. However, since fireworks *may* have a direct effect on
everyone's ability to enjoy a party, I personally deem them inappropriate.

brian

I saw a "women's circle" at the New Years Gathering of '93
there were all types of Women going in and out and it seemed real
empowering for them as the circle fed each and every woman who entered
supportive energy in realizing her self expression.  I think if you have
circles like this, they can do wonders but you have to drop attitude
CONPLETELY.  It might be interesting rather then trying to "ban" circles
maybe we should try to influence their development in a positive way.
One way to do this is to form your own circles when you see a real
attitude circle forming, invite everyone into your circle and let
the energy radiate out, eventually a balance will be reached,  I think at
a good party their can be room for circles for people who want to dance
that way, they just have to be sensitive to the whole.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 10:57:58 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <9506211640.AA25404@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM> from "Lee Fogel" at Jun 21, 95 09:40:57 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Raving has nothing to do with anarchy.  They operate more as TAZs - 
> Temporary Autonomous Zones, which are self-GOVERNING.

I think raving has everything to do with anarchy.  What is the 
definition of anarchy?  An organization that prohibits certain
behavior and mandates others _by threat of force_.  This force can
range from death to imprisonment to confiscation, and is always
equivalent to torture (prison is psychological torture).

What threat of force do underground raves use?  I've seen people 
asked to cool their behavior, and I've seen people asked to leave.
Were these requests backed up with guns?  No, and you can't call
the police when you yourself are outside the law.

It is difficult to maintain a functioning anarchy when one is still
potentially subject to the rules of a government.  This permits 
a "safety valve" kind of mentality where, if I judge that the risk
to me of letting something continue is more than the risk of calling
the cops in and us all being found out, I can do that, and sidestep
the problem.

Voluntary organization is anarchy.  Involuntary organization is not.

Therefore, the effective difference between anarchy and state-slavery
is this:  In anarchy, for ethics (standards of behavior) to exist,
all must consent to them and abide by them; no one is held to a standard
of behavior they don't espouse, and there is no guarantee of another's
behavior but your knowledge of the other.  Under a state, ethics are
guaranteed by the threat of force, but there is no guarantee that the
other person has consented to them, and the ethic is only as powerful
as its weapons of enforcement.

Non-anarchists often confuse ethics with their enforcement, and think
that if people weren't threatened with death they would all become
serial killers (like the Army, or Dow Chemical?) or something.  Ask
yourself this: if the government were to vanish tomorrow, how would
YOUR ethics change?  Never mind what other people might do, what would
YOU do differently?

Is there some evil, dark, slavering beast lurking within you, waiting
for all the black-and-white cars to disappear so it can slouch out
of your subconscious and commit unspeakable atrocities upon your friends?

Or do you just want to smoke dope in public places?

Never mind the state: what do YOU want?

// g

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

you said ...
>
>I think raving has everything to do with anarchy.  What is the
>definition of anarchy?  An organization that prohibits certain
>behavior and mandates others _by threat of force_.

Erm .... your dictionary is far different from mine then, which defines
anarchy as "a state of society without government or law", or "confused
disorder", and defines anarchism as "a doctrine urging the abolition of
government as the indispensable condition for full liberty".

I see no sign of either of these definitions when I'm at a rave.  Raves ARE
self-governing, not anarchistic.  The rules at a raves do tend to be a
little more fluid than the rules of society, but they do exist.  They are
also common sense and most people are perfectly happy to abide by them.

Laws which class a reasonably safe "drug" such as marijuana with things
like heroin, yet allow the legal sale of nicotine and alcohol, THAT is
something I can't abide.  On the other hand, I've never seen a rule at a
rave I didn't agree with....once I knew the reason for it.

k

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jun 21 12:16:57 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA13015; Wed, 21 Jun 1995 12:16:57 -0700

Subject: testosterone (was Re: fireworks )

             <199506210535.WAA02900@nexsys.nexsys.net>

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk

geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White):
>he clearly saw the ramifications of his actions (I hear he didn't
>go out for a long time after that).  Why is it always young guys
>that seem to want to burn things down, must be testosterone poisoning :)

Actually, there was an article in yesterday's chronicle indicating that
estrogen and/or low testosterone levels actually caused agressive
behavior, and that giving people w/ low testosterone artificial
testosterone actually increased their friendliness level, generated a
calmer, more positive outlook on life, etc. The article also alluded to
the direct role of estrogen in aggression....

After all, what kind of hormonal changes are going on in women during
PMS? They certainly ain't getting a big dose of testosterone, that's
for sure... :-)

Basically, the article contradicted the usual testosterone mythology.
IMHO, most men that act in what we'd call "testosterone poisoned"
fashion are just acting out the "caged rat" role defined for them by
industrial society. Such pathological behaviour is more a disease of
modern society than some fault of being male.

I see the whole "testosterone poisoning" myth as yet another way that
society is attempting to reduce and diminish the uniqueness and
importance  of maleness. After all, you cannot subjugate the natural
male and  put them into industrial servitude unless you subvert male
energy into something unnatural (obsequiousness, defferring attitudes,
the wearing of suits, the shearing of hair, the covert feeling of
wanting bite the hand that feeds you, banale servitude, a meaningless,
mind-numbing 10 hour workday, being taught from a young age that the
male must shoulder the burdens of the world) and then attempt to
brainwash people into thinking that the maleness that rebels against
such bullshit is something primitive and stupid that can be cut out and
removed like a spare appendix. All in the name of productivity and
progress. Well, we all know that's a bunch of crap. 

Cage the wild beast and he will snap. Cage the beast and you get the
sick dominator society we now live in in which the oppressed male finds
unhealthy release in human subjugation, hoarding of
foods/goods/wealth/land, the raping of earth and woman, and highly
detatched, deeply impersonal, and genocidal acts of warfare and
aggression. Cage the beast and you get rows of lonely men sitting at
the bar, failing to understand the changed nature of the world and the
conspiracy against them.

Detachment, free floating aggression, domination, subjugation, anger
and rape aren't the natural outcomes of "maleness" -- it's more a
malignancy we define upon ourselves.  And one is continuing the cycle
by telling "men" that it is their maleness that is at fault, that the
cage doesn't exist, and that there' something wrong with themselves. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Some of you may be interested in this...



Friends & Colleagues:

Happy Summer Solstice!

For tens of thousands of years, this has been a day of celebration, of
dances, of weddings and feasting.  The Sun, at its zenith, graces Earth with
a full complement of light.  The Earth responds in love, and grows rich and
green.

To celebrate this event, we would like to announce the conversion of the
Zero Circle, from CyberSamhain.  (This is the event & VRML model that is
discussed in the "Technopagans:  May the Astral be Reborn in Cyberspace"
article in the July WIRED.)  Originally built in Labyrinth VRML, Scott Young
has begun its transformation into VRML 1.0.  The first revision of this
magickal world (450K) is available at:

http://hyperreal.com/~mpesce/circle.wrl

More information about the structure of the site can be found at

http://hyperreal.com/~mpesce/samhain.html

Please come and visit; we will be adding many features to it in the weeks
and months to come, and look forward to meeting you there.

IO EVOE, and Blessed Be!

Mark Pesce (mpesce@netcom.com)
C. Scott Young (necron99@netcom.com)

(Worldview, a freeware VRML browser for Windows 3.1 - required to view the
scene - is available at http://www.hyperion.com/intervista.  WebSpace NT
also works!)



----- End Included Message -----

From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>

To: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White), sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re[2]: you got coicles?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
I haven't had time to read the entire thread about circles but I wanted to say a
few things:


1)  Circles can be very powerful as Geoff implied.  If a group forms a circle 
    with a specific intention, and the circle has a gap, shit happens.  I've 
    experienced this in many groups settings and it's not to be taken lightly.
    We've had fires break out, energy distortion, and definitely a lack of
    unification among other things.  

2)  I've also inadvertently walked or danced through circles or even unknowingly
    danced too close to them.  I find that there is a break in a continuous 
    flow of energy when encountering these firewalkers (or whatever they're 
    called) but at most parties, you can find pockets of energy flowing or 
    stagnating too, so what's the diff?!  Attitude is one thing but I haven't
    really encountered this.  I find it's more of an alienation in not being
    able to connect with the dancers _except_ in showing appreciation by
    watching.  Since I like things on a more reciprocal level, I find it
    unsatisfying after five minutes and move on.

3)  At my community dance jams and with my dance collective events where 
    there's about 100 people, after we're warmed up and are moving about the dj 
    stops the music and we form a circle (this includes _everyone_). 
    Announcements are made re:  housing, support, events, etc. and then we go 
    around and state our names.  Then we join hands and dance one entire song  
    together as a group with the intention of making eye contact, smiling and 
    seeing who we are with at this dance to make it go off.

    In doing this, the awareness is raised removing us from an individual atti-
    tude to a group consciousness and sometimes we do the "rope dance" where we 
    get entangled and work as a group to untangle.  It requires consideration
    to _not_ pull eachother's arm off and to _not_ get carried away with the
    momentum if it's too energetic.  While it'd be difficult to do at a rave 
    w/such a large group, I agree with Geoff that it'd be good to develop one 
    in a positive manner.  Again, at the prompting of one particular song
    that is played almost every gig, people skip, hop, hold hands, hug and dance
    _around_ the "freestyle" dancers who are in the center of the circle.  Maybe
    we could try something like this to encompass the group energy sometime?

    At the end of the Basics anniversary a few months ago, one of the organizers
    asked for a circle to form.  Immediately, I joined hands with others and 
    followed only to be rebuffed by some people who thought I was plain wierd!  
    It's too bad, because after an amazing party like that, to hold hands 
    and feel the shared glowing energy with others is really something to
    behold...if you think huggEing someone is good, then you're in for a real 
    treat!  When I think of some shared moments from various circles, I know 
    that they should never be recreated but only built upon and improved.  

Happy Summer Solstice Day and remember to let your light shine :)

Love,
Diane

Subject: re: you got coicles?
Author:  geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White) at beluga-mail
Date:    6/21/95 10:37 AM

     
I saw a "women's circle" at the New Years Gathering of '93
there were all types of Women going in and out and it seemed real 
empowering for them as the circle fed each and every woman who entered 
supportive energy in realizing her self expression.  I think if you have 
circles like this, they can do wonders but you have to drop attitude 
CONPLETELY.  It might be interesting rather then trying to "ban" circles 
maybe we should try to influence their development in a positive way. 
One way to do this is to form your own circles when you see a real 
attitude circle forming, invite everyone into your circle and let
the energy radiate out, eventually a balance will be reached,  I think at 
a good party their can be room for circles for people who want to dance 
that way, they just have to be sensitive to the whole.

Forwarded message:

> Sunday, 18th June. Glasgow Anarchist Group organise a
> Temporary Autonomous Zone (TAZ) in Kelvingrove Park in direct
> defiance of the draconian Criminal (In)Justice Act.
> 
> The TAZ, a fund raiser for the Scottish Federation of Anarchists
> and the Glasgow Solidarity Centre, was an all day rave and
> very well attended. The venue, a bandstand in a public park,
> is under threat of being sold off by the council for private
> development so the TAZ showed that the bandstand should be 
> left as it is, for use by those who own it - the people of
> Glasgow.

> The event was very  well attended and the police kept well away.

hmmm ... funny that you think raves have everythign to do with TAZs and 
nothing to do with anarchy, lee, cuz i think TAZs (and many raves) have 
EVERYTHING to do with anarchism.... (of course, we can say "anarchy" and 
"anarchism" are two different things, "anarchism" being organization and 
social interaction and cooperation without hierarchy.

i don't know who came up with the definition of anarchy as using "the 
threat of force" - i've never heard that before! anarchism to me implies 
no coercion.  

okay, some BSP...
from The Little Red Rave Book:
"I've also come to realize that good renegades are a perfect example of 
practical anarchism.  People come together - some offer music, equipment, 
some offer food, drink, art, positive energy...at a good renegade we look 
out for each other - interdependence.  We know tht sometimes nasty shit 
can go down, especially since sometimes we can't party in the safest 
spaces, as we're relegated to the edge of industrial wastelands where 
we're (hopefully) free of police.  We watch out for each other, don't let 
people wander off alone, take care of someone if they are hurt.  And we 
transform the wasteland, the parking lots, the pavement, the abandoned 
buildings into ritual playgrounds full of color, energy and life (Or if 
we are lucky we find a space in woods and fields!)"

okay, end quote.  
but, yes, i do understand that most dictionaries define "anarchy" as 
chaos and disorder, rather than the more "political" definition , or more 
"social" definition of cooperation without hierarchy as well as "do what 
thou wilt an ye harm none" (hmm...isn't that the wiccan saying...could 
there be a connection here ...? ;) )

well, i could go one, but i've already gone on a lot :)
but if anyone is interested in discussion this with me please email me :)

take care everyone!
monicat (busy busy busy and not much time for the net - sigh.)

  I haven't been reading much mail lately, but this whole Orb thread 
caught my eyes.  I just wanted to make a few comments on it, since it is 
getting a bit out of hand.

  o I thought the show was fantastic, full of VERY intense energy. 

  o The energy was so intense at times that I'm sure many of the upper 
    crust 'Groovemasters' couldnt handle it.

  o The music they played could hardly be classified as just techno. 
    There orb is in its own class.  The combination of dub, trance and
    sample mania make for an incredible sound.  If you don't like it... Oh
    well.

  o Personally I'm not suprised at all the flames and various comments the
    show caused.  It was so intense, you just HAD to talk about it. I 
    know I've been talking about it for days now.  

  o Finally I'm suprised people aren't freaked out at the direction SF is 
    heading in.  3.5 years ago I went to a rave at the Warfield. It was
    all ages and went all night. 1.5 years ago I went to the Orb there.
    If the ushers saw you without a 21+ bracelet on after 2am, you
    were kicked out.  Now, June 1995, they had to stop the whole show,
    turn the lights on, and check everyone for a handstamp, essentialy
    ending the party at 2.

    This is getting ridiculous people.  The current trend is not a good one
    and if people don't start taking notice, soon all our rights will
    be gone.  It happened in England, and it could happen here.  It would
    not suprise me if in 5 years there were even more anti-dancing laws 
    on the books.

...or maybe it's just hump day... ..  .

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun 22 01:39:57 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id BAA22885; Thu, 22 Jun 1995 01:39:57 -0700
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id BAA22880; Thu, 22 Jun 1995 01:39:54 -0700

From: "Fred Heutte" <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <9506220139.ZM19391@well>
Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 01:39:49 -0700
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, nw-raves@hyperreal.com
Subject: The Orb in Puddletown
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I know the Orb has gotten good to excellent reviews elsewhere, but 
they just didn't impress me here.  I was all set for a soaring experience,
but the group basically plodded through a two and a half hour performance
before a dodgy, inert audience.  

DJ Lewis played about an hour and a half of mostly flat, not very fast
breakbeats -- he peaked out at not much more than 135 bpm, which surprised
me given the reports of his sets from elsewhere.  I didn't recognize
anything except the long mix of "Keep House Underground" (a new one by
O. Voom on Touche, he's also been collaborating with Juan Atkins recently
I believe).  The crowd basically shuffled around, not really knowing what
to do.

The Orb played a somewhat more industrial-sounding set than I'd been
expecting, but frankly it didn't really move me very much and it seemed
to have more oomph when the rhythm section (bass and drummer) were on
board.  And when Dr. P briefly stepped up to the 1200s for a short spin
about halfway through.  La Luna is a small place and I gather they
couldn't do their full light show; it was mostly the rotating spots
and Intellabeam-type stuff (no, they're not Intellabeams but you know
what I mean).  Very nice but somewhat restricted in their effect.

I guess the best part of the show for me was the seven or eight minute
Blue Room segment, but I'd sure hoped for something new and different
to surprise me.  

I don't think it was me, quite a few of my friends were less than fully
engaged in the show here, though the crowd mostly stayed until the end,
sort of waiting for something to happen.

Perhaps it was just overinflated expectations on my part, but that's the
way it goes.  

c u
phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun 22 09:41:12 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA11600; Thu, 22 Jun 1995 09:41:12 -0700

	id AA17231; Thu, 22 Jun 95 09:41:07 PDT

	id AA15169; Thu, 22 Jun 95 09:41:06 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9506221641.AA15169@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: Fish
To: sfraves@taz.hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 22 Jun 95 9:41:05 PDT
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com
In-Reply-To: <m0sOdsn-000ILGC@priscilla.ultima.org>; from "Monica and Tom" at Jun 21, 95 9:28 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> hmmm ... funny that you think raves have everythign to do with TAZs and 
> nothing to do with anarchy, lee, cuz i think TAZs (and many raves) have 
> EVERYTHING to do with anarchism....

Mainly, I see a big difference between *autonomy* and *anarchy*.

> (of course, we can say "anarchy" and 
> "anarchism" are two different things, "anarchism" being organization and 
> social interaction and cooperation without hierarchy.

Well, I don't know much about "anarchism", but I won't let that stop
me from forming an opinion about it.  Basically, I'd say that
if you think you can have cooperation without some form of hierarchy
then you are just fooling yourself.  True, you may not need an
oppressive force to keep things organized, but there will always be
a shared value system, or unwritten rules of conduct that the
group allows itself to be led by.  And some "laws" will be more
powerful than others.  It doesn't matter to me if people obey the
laws voluntarily or not.  Once we become organized, and in sync with
each other, we have bought into a hierarchical power structure that
controls our behavior.

At raves, the music, the vibe, our shared desire to connect with
each other... these are the things that lead us and become more 
important than our individuality.  Those who put their own
personal agendas first work to destroy the unity, structure, and
meaning of what a rave is, in favor of anarchy.  I agree that less
heirarchy is good.  At raves, the pyramid is pretty flat, but it's
still there.

"Anarchism"?  Sounds like an attempt to legitimize the concept of
anarchy as a practical (i.e. "good") thing.  To say that ravers
are participating in anarchy because they just happen to be doing
what they want to anyway  renders the term meaningless to me.
Look at that school of fish, swimming in perfect formation, what
anarchy!  

True anarchy, like chaos, is a big part of the way the universe
works.  I see no need to denegrade these rather abstract concepts
by trying to make them fit into a political package.

So in conclusion, I really doubt that we disagree very much at
all.  It just comes down to semantics, in which case I tend to
rely on my dictionary.


Lee
_______________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com

In-Reply-To: <9506221641.AA15169@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM> from "Lee Fogel" at Jun 22, 95 09:41:05 am

ObRave: Thanks to everyone at the Equinox yesterday afternoon and night.
It was beautiful.  Hugs to all I didn't hug while I was there.

Here follows a big discussion about the anarchy thing.  There are no
sentences containing the word "Orb" or "circle".  You've been warned.

On a bright and warm day just after the solstice, Lee Fogel said:

> Mainly, I see a big difference between *autonomy* and *anarchy*.

Anarchy _permits_ autonomy but is not sufficient to produce it.  That
effort must come from within.

> me from forming an opinion about it.  Basically, I'd say that
> if you think you can have cooperation without some form of hierarchy
> then you are just fooling yourself.

"True communication is only possible between equals."  Communication
is necessary to cooperation.  There are degrees of co-operation, and
my experience from living and working in co-ops of various sizes and
kinds is that the less hierarchy, the more communication, and the more
co-operation.  We had food on the table, and a place to live, and I 
don't think we were fooling ourselves ("That's not a building!  That's
a collection of soggy cardboard boxes leaning against a tree!").

> True, you may not need an
> oppressive force to keep things organized, but there will always be
> a shared value system, or unwritten rules of conduct that the
> group allows itself to be led by.  And some "laws" will be more
> powerful than others.  It doesn't matter to me if people obey the
> laws voluntarily or not.

I guess if you believe that people who voluntarily choose to co-operate
with each other have automatically formed a government and passed a law,
I don't know what to say.  I don't believe that choosing to live in a 
certain way automatically oppresses everyone else who doesn't.

> Once we become organized, and in sync with
> each other, we have bought into a hierarchical power structure that
> controls our behavior.

I can choose to look at it that way, and most of us do, because we have
no experience with any other form of interaction.  Can we leave, alter,
protest against, climb on, or swing from the structure without being
beaten up or jailed by its members?  Coercion is the defining feature
of the state -- or, stated by someone much more famous than I, "Political 
power grows out of the barrel of a gun" (Mao Zedong)

> At raves, the music, the vibe, our shared desire to connect with
> each other... these are the things that lead us and become more 
> important than our individuality.  Those who put their own
> personal agendas first work to destroy the unity, structure, and
> meaning of what a rave is, in favor of anarchy.

Maybe my personal agenda is to dance!  The unity you talk of is not
enforced by a hierarchy: we've all been to totally vibeless parties
where people's agenda was "project a 'tude" despite best intentions
of the people throwing the gig.  I've also seen people having amazing
fun at parties thrown by "in-it-for-the-money" promoters.

It's you, and I, that make it happen.

> True anarchy, like chaos, is a big part of the way the universe
> works.  I see no need to denegrade these rather abstract concepts
> by trying to make them fit into a political package.

You are correct: calling oneself an "anarchist" doesn't really say anything.
What will you do once the boys in blue go away?  (I think I've asked this
before.)

> So in conclusion, I really doubt that we disagree very much at
> all.  It just comes down to semantics, in which case I tend to
> rely on my dictionary.

Who wrote it?  What agenda did they have?  I tend to use it for the sake
of commonality, but (since I don't believe in objectivity) I take many
definitions with a grain or two of salt.

// g

Diane,
Your community dance jams sound really cool.  These people most be ravers 
at heart whether they go to raves or not.
I like the experience of both, 
having some stucture to help bring us together, 
and a less stuctured dance with full spontinaety, having the feelings and 
the the natural free flowing of the dance bring us together.  
Like Lee says there is always some structure at the partys whether spoken 
or not. 
I ok with different degrees of it as long as it helps us experience.
Hopefully a harmonious experience, where kaos and order can live in harmony.
For me dancing is alot about that, I'm dancing out of mind (hopefully to 
a merging of a shared state of mind) in a 
controlled way, keeping myself in tune with my mind at the same time.
Dancing allows me to be crazy (a fun crazy) and very sane at the same time


:)
peter

_______________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
--------------------------

So I guess that's why I'm finding myself thinking "yeah, what he/she said" to
each post I've seen on this subject. :->

While TAZ and anarchy make for some really interesting discussion, for me
neither political model really touches the essence of how a rave exists - it
certainly isn't a pure manifestation of either. There's a balance between the
communal and individual that I haven't experienced anywhere else, including
"real life." Every other scene (or whatever) I've encountered has exaggerated one
at the expense of the other.

Has anyone experienced the vibe, the connectedness, and the tribal aspects of a
rave and not asked themselves something like "wow! what is it in me that's resonating
with this?" Likewise, it's really pretty rare to see someone stand in the middle
of the dance floor endlessly tripping on their personal specialness. 

I recently visited the Monterey aquarium, and besides becoming uncomfortable at
seeing all the living creatures in such cramped quarters, I was really disturbed
by the cylindrical tank packed with anchovies swimming around and around and
around in circles head to tail.

Part of respecting other people involves respecting other people's
self-expression. I wasn't there for allen's unconventional ambient room set, but when
I heard about it my reaction was "that's great!" Most of the "best raves I've
been to" involve bumping into the unexpected in some form. I was glad to hear
I'm not the only one who enjoys watching circle dancers when they're not edging
others off the floor, physically or otherwise.

That said, I think the scene here and everywhere has plenty of vitality left for
some time to come, and I'm still convinced this summer will be a significant one
for us all!

take care!
-nate

> > Once we become organized, and in sync with
> > each other, we have bought into a hierarchical power structure that
> > controls our behavior.

how does being in sync = hierarchy?  there's a big difference between 
"power-with" and "power-over."  and i think a vibrant anarchist community 
would definitely have room for change and questioning...
 > 
> 
> > At raves, the music, the vibe, our shared desire to connect with
> > each other... these are the things that lead us and become more 
> > important than our individuality.  Those who put their own
> > personal agendas first work to destroy the unity, structure, and
> > meaning of what a rave is, in favor of anarchy.
> 
> Maybe my personal agenda is to dance!  The unity you talk of is not
> enforced by a hierarchy: we've all been to totally vibeless parties
> where people's agenda was "project a 'tude" despite best intentions
> of the people throwing the gig.  I've also seen people having amazing
> fun at parties thrown by "in-it-for-the-money" promoters.
> 
isee anarchism as working to balance the individual and collective 
needs.  when i go to a rave i definitly feel the collectivity, but i'm 
still an individual with my own individual needs and personal dance floor 
experiences.age. > 
> You are correct: calling oneself an "anarchist" doesn't really say anything.
> What will you do once the boys in blue go away?  (I think I've asked this
> before.)
> 
well, one could always say "social anarchist..." or techno pagan 
anarchist witch! :)

and when the boys in blue go away, will the boys in blue inside ourselves 
be gone?  i think then i'll dance and feast and work cooperatively :)

love and @,
monicat

i very much respect 
and understand
your point.

along with it
what about my freedom to
not smell the aweful smell
that crawled up my nose
because the works
were fired so close (in) the crowd?
what about my freedom to
enjoy the party
without my worries
of fire
injury
and the man?
what about the freedom of those
(not me)
who do not like fireworks?

again, i respect and see your point.
i like it.
another replying to your missive
mentioned parties for 
every kind of dancer
perhaps
parties with fireworks
can be announced beforehand
so one can choose
whether to go
or not.

another point brought up by another
is the guy was drunk
and another person wrote
drunk people should not operate
fire works.
i agree.
because i have seen
fingers blown off
by irrisponsability.

and i am not saying this is universal
but some of the people i see drunk
at parties
are some of the same people
too wasted
to dance
or be 
and many behavior
that is rediculous
stupid
hurting
demeaning
and ugly.
it seems that the only people i notice
that behave in ways i would not like to approach
are the drunk people.
actually,
i would prefer parties
without alcohol use (voluntary).
i know this may infringe on rights
but if people were a bit more responsible 
with their use
i wouldn't feel this way.

responsible drug use
of any drug
is vital
for a good scene
good vibe
and good life.

love to all... throcka

   Another hot weekend in store: tonight is supposed to be the last Pure
   Space (in 111 Minna instead of Sound Factory); Friday, try Progress
   (can't be rained out at Big Heart City) or the ingeniously-named party
   at 111 Minna. Also, outdoors will be Frequency 8. Then Saturday, both
   Kundalini and Organic have good lineups plus Megatripolis presents the
   next installment of their parties... Finally, Sunset is supposed to be
   weekly now, and Bulletproof's boat party also takes off Sunday.
   
						-Derek

                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun 22 23:45:45 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id XAA22158; Thu, 22 Jun 1995 23:45:45 -0700
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id XAA22153; Thu, 22 Jun 1995 23:45:43 -0700
Received: from DialupEudora by netcom.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id XAA03498; Thu, 22 Jun 1995 23:44:45 -0700
Message-Id: <199506230644.XAA03498@netcom.netcom.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 23:49:01 -0800
To: SF Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
From: throb@netcom.com (Rob Oliver)
Subject: Re: MOBY
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Just a quick note on MOBY at the Trocadero
>
>His opening act - didn't enjoy them.  They we a thrash metal type
>band from the UK.  What were they thinking when they signed them
>up to tour with MOBY.

That was Sensor, a "thrash, speed metal, funk" band as described by my
friend, who works at Polydor (sp?) and who got us into the show via the
label's guest list. They've got a song that's played on Live 105.

Don't you think that at least a couple of Moby's soungs sounded speed
metalish? And, Moby even got a mosh pit going a couple of times! (Before
the show I  told my friend that it was okay to move up in front of the
stage since people that listen to Moby don't mosh. Oops! Maybe it was the
Sensor fans. :) )

>MOBY - Hmmm.  He was ok, nothing interesting.  His cover of
>a Doors tune drove me out of the Troc.  Not really the $13
>at the door, but that is why we have disposable incomes.

The Doors? I thought that was a Led Zepelin cover, not to mention his
covers of  Lynard Skynard (Sweet Home Alabama), Prince (didn't specifically
recognize it), and Jimi Hendrix (Purple Haze, of course). JH was mentioned
in the SoCal Raves post about the Moby show down there, so I knew what to
expect. Yeah, he's a sucko guitarist, but I found it amusing. He said that
he was trying to "open" our minds, since San Franciscans have a narrow view
(I guess of what to expect from him). A interesting statement in comparison
to the lead singer in Sensor saying what a great town this is, since all
the great music comes here (implying diversity as well as richness in my
mind).

I'm a former drummer, so I got off on all the percussion and drum solos
(two drummers!). He seemed to be making a statement, perhaps in reaction to
all the criticism of his exclusively using his DAT last year. He would put
the mike away from his face when the voice sample was played, and he
"wrote" a live piece at the end. I thought I saw him once play his keyboard
out of sync from what I heard, but he could have been inputting something.
Oh, and you gotta love his standing up on the stunt keyboard, hands and
head raised slowly up to heaven! 8)

I thought his "disco" songs (as he called them) went off with really high
energy, and made up for the other experimental (hee, hee) stuff. I'd say it
would been worth $13, but no more.

Rob

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jun 23 00:44:23 1995

Received: from lightning.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id AAA25582; Fri, 23 Jun 1995 00:44:21 -0700
Received: by lightning.berkeley.edu
	(5.65c/IDA-1.4.4.1-DomainOS) id AA12040; Fri, 23 Jun 1995 00:44:08 -0700
Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 00:44:05 -0700 (PDT)
From: Starchild <rrose@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
X-Sender: rrose@lightning.berkeley.edu
To: Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: fireworks
In-Reply-To: <199506211519.IAA03722@nexsys.nexsys.net>

On Wed, 21 Jun 1995, Geoff White wrote:

> Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 08:19:52 -0700
> From: Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: Re: fireworks
> 
> > Wouldn't it be nice if we lived in a society where we had the freedom to 
> > do what we want as long as we didn't hurt anyone else?  I for one believe 
> > in change and am optimistic we may eventually get there.  But it won't 
> > happen through self-censorship.  It *will* happen through enough people 
> > taking a stand for freedom.  Let the fireworks begin!
> > 
> > 				*** Starchild ***
> 
> The other problem I have with these fireworks is the guys that usually set them
> off have more investment in being seen as Promytheous rather than giving
> the crowd a need fireworks display, so they set them off right next to the crown
> where more than once I've seen the fireworks burn somebodies backpack or
> land on someone's head.  Also if you are drunk or dosed YOU SHOULD NOT BE
> OPERATING FIREWORKS plain and simple.  If we were at the beach and someone
> who knew what they were doing wanted to put on a display and shot them up in a
> responsible manner I'd be less negative about it but the bottom line is that
> almost all of the fireworks experiences I have had at parties in the last
> 3 years have ended in  either something catching on fire or sending up
> a locator flare for the Police (Pt. Richmond in '93 as an example).

Geoff, I hear what you are saying.  Clearly with fireworks as with 
anything else, care should be taken so as to ensure the safety of users and 
those nearby who might be affected.  I did not mean to imply in my 
previous post above that ravers should just do whatever they feel like 
without taking these factors into consideration.  The original message I 
was responding to did not object to fireworks based on safety concerns, 
but said that they should not be used lest it give the cops an excuse to 
bust parties, and it was this sentiment I was addressing.

I might add that I have personally seen fireworks lit many times at 
parties, and never personally witnessed them causing a problem, so it is 
certainly possible for them to be used in a positive manner.  I still 
remember at my very first rave, the Toon Town on New Year's Eve three and 
a half years ago, someone lighting off some large cone-type fireworks 
that emitted showers of sparks in at least a five foot radius.  Mind you, 
this was *inside* a fairly crowded building.  Everyone I saw seemed to 
really enjoy and appreciate this spontaneous act of anarchy and 
celebration.  Each time a device was set off, a circle would form around 
it, with people dancing in and around the showers of white falling 
sparks, kind of like the breakdance circles being discussed on sfraves, 
only without the attitude or competitive flavor those circles sometimes 
have.  I found it quite beautiful, and it increased my enjoyment of an 
evening that already stands out in my memory as one of the most 
incredible nights of my life.  This use of fireworks may not have been 
*entirely* safe, but then few things are.  Certainly they are less 
dangerous overall than drug use, and probably no more objectionable to 
the powers that be.

				*** Starchild ***
______________________________________________________________________________
	"Censorship is an infectious disease.  Permitting censorship on *any*
	 expression sets the stage for attacks on all expression that is
	 artistically and/or politically controversial.  The creative 
	 spirit must be free.  When it is not, society suffers."

		-from an American Civil Liberties Union briefing paper on 
	 	 artistic freedom.

of COOL people on the planet, anyway the upcoming convergence of 
science and art will surely progress.
Hypgnosis is the catalyst to Global Webtrance i tell ya. 
I think this is gonna be one o dem times when ya ask yourself
"Is it gonna be worth READING any further" but hey, there's always
Dark Forces or DOOM man, and anyway, its gonna be 200 years before 
anyone takes  us seriously and then it will be dealt with by social scientists 
and engineers, not for us to wonder why, just to suffer?
"If Shamanism is gonna be where its at, so what happens for the next 199 years?"
Hey, gimme a break man, i'm still busy with the script yaknow,
but i should have it all clocked by Saturday Nite an i'll be up and running with
fresh power cells at the NEXUS RAVE on Saturday nite..and we will
be hosting a CyberSafari from San Francisco right here in
Cape Town South Africa.
And here is some CyberSafari News from David Dei at
our Virtual Rondavel in San Francisco....

The Truly Amazing Confirmed List:

A Picturetel 4000 system on both ends connected via ISDN (Integrated
Services Digital Network), with crew supplied by Picturetel

An original Buckminster Fuller Fly Eye Dome for our Safari Command at Fort
Mason, SF

Telkom support of our SA ISDN connections.

Aztec South Africa support of a CuSeeMe link (Deon Botha has agreed to lug
his apple quadra into the Woodstock venue to demo CuSeeMe before the cyber
illiterati).

The Well, Sausalito, the place where the internet was invented , has
supplied us with two ISDN accounts onto the Internet, as well as agreeing
to reflect CUseeMe transmissions.

Headware (Paul Rousouw) is setting up an 5DT dataglove to trigger MIDI
signals - probably the roland synth sitting in our module - Michael Mantra
of Tranquil Technology Music wants to compose real time ambience with Paul.
Also me, Schwann, doin some cyberart live on-line at the CyberSafari.
Just visit IRC and  mssg me on 'Schwann' Saturday nite GMT,
or try #rave  

Documentary coverage of the Cybersafari by Big World Cinema with input from
African Connections, SF.

Endorsment by President Carter for our electronic petition for
international conflict resolution and non-violence. This petition will be
launched from our booth in SF, onto the Internet.

I do believe we have critical mass. What we will be doing over the next
couple of days, is fine-tuning our technical support and finalising the
program line-up - all you internet prima donnas will have ample time to wash
your virtual hair.

> I might add that I have personally seen fireworks lit many times at 
> parties, and never personally witnessed them causing a problem, so it is 
> certainly possible for them to be used in a positive manner.  I still 
> remember at my very first rave, the Toon Town on New Year's Eve three and 
> a half years ago, someone lighting off some large cone-type fireworks 
> that emitted showers of sparks in at least a five foot radius.  Mind you, 
> this was *inside* a fairly crowded building.  Everyone I saw seemed to 
> really enjoy and appreciate this spontaneous act of anarchy and 
> celebration.  Each time a device was set off, a circle would form around 
> it, with people dancing in and around the showers of white falling 
> sparks, kind of like the breakdance circles being discussed on sfraves,


I was at that Toon Town as well, the place was packed with maybe 7000 people.
Imagine the loss of life if the place had caught on fire and there was
a stampede to the door.



 
> only without the attitude or competitive flavor those circles sometimes 
> have.  I found it quite beautiful, and it increased my enjoyment of an 
> evening that already stands out in my memory as one of the most 
> incredible nights of my life.  This use of fireworks may not have been 
> *entirely* safe, but then few things are.  Certainly they are less 
> dangerous overall than drug use, and probably no more objectionable to 
> the powers that be.

NO they are far more dangerous than drug use, if you OD or if your drunk
and you drive maybe you kill yourself and perhapse a few other people
by crashing into them, the fire that was started by a fool with fireworks
two years ago at let freedom rave had the potential to kill or injure
dozens of people, you had to be there to realize how fast the fire spread
and got out of control, it was literally one of the miracles of the
rave scene (coupled with the fact that there was lots of bottled water lying 
around and some sober people acted quickly) that a tragedy was avoided.
Don't get me wrong, I _love_ fireworks, I have friends that put on major
displays with their fathers at 4th of july, under the right conditions with
back up systems so that if something goes wrong the emergency can be handled
they are OK but I don't think a "OH gee, I'm sorry" cuts it when your
in the hospital with second degree burns on your scalp cuz some stupid person
wants to set fireworks off in your vicinity and doesn't warn you. 



> 
> 				*** Starchild ***
> ______________________________________________________________________________
> 	"Censorship is an infectious disease.  Permitting censorship on *any*
> 	 expression sets the stage for attacks on all expression that is
> 	 artistically and/or politically controversial.  The creative 
> 	 spirit must be free.  When it is not, society suffers."

I personally believe that people have the right to keep and bear arms, but that
doesn't mean they should bring them to raves and shoot them off in the air.
(some people do this as an expression of celebration) call this censorship?
Perhapse, but I also believe "AN IT HARM NONE, do what thou wilt", fireworks,
guns and other items that have the capability of injuring loads of people at
one time should not be operated in crowds by drunk or dosed people, period.

On Thu, 22 Jun 1995, Rob Oliver wrote:

> That was Sensor, a "thrash, speed metal, funk" band as described by my
> friend, who works at Polydor (sp?) and who got us into the show via the
> label's guest list. They've got a song that's played on Live 105.

i would describe Senser as more of a (fundamentally) hiphop band, with 
a metal *and* a techno edge. they've got two vocalists, one male, who 
raps his vocals, and one female, who sings and raps occasionally  some of 
the beats in their tracks are very electronic...they've been around 
for awhile (from scotland); check 'the key' for a *killer* track, they 
had another single remixed by J Saul Kane (aka Depth Charge) which was 
pretty wicked. their sound falls in a few different categories but 
their tastes are right on. i believe the main vocalist did some vocal work 
with Trans-Global Underground as well...

mikebee

> 
> "Anarchism"?  Sounds like an attempt to legitimize the concept of
> anarchy as a practical (i.e. "good") thing.  To say that ravers
> are participating in anarchy because they just happen to be doing
> what they want to anyway  renders the term meaningless to me.
> Look at that school of fish, swimming in perfect formation, what
> anarchy!  

i'm saying that renegades are organized ANARCHICALLY - meaning that there 
is no one giving orders, no one getting paid, everything is done 
voluntarily - someone may be "coordinating" but that does not mean they 
are a boss or superior.  lots of thing are organized anarchically but are 
just not defined as such.

this is also A LOT different than a school of fish.  fish swim together 
by instinct.  do we organize renegades by instinct?  and even if we do 
gather together non-hierarchically by instinct (maybe?), we often still 
have to 
overcome hell of state/patricarchal/etc. conditioning to learn to work 
together.> >

but anyway...
i hope everyone has a wonderful weekend!  i'm off to the woods!!! (yes, 
i'm actually leaving sf - and gettiing beyond berkeley! can it be true?!)
and if you're interested, don't forget the free mumia torchlight march on 
monday at 7:30 at u.n. plaza.

:)

To: Monique Ho <myho@ucdavis.edu>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: A word of cautio/Re: Thanks
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Peace Sister!

I'm glad you had a great time, remember though, this scene isn't really
about drugs, but about life and the pursuit of happiness in the warm flow
of music and friends.  The drugs?  Well, whether or not you do them, it's
important to remember that they are not the driving force.

You might want to strive to the positive on the forefront of your email,
and the drug stuff off-line.

I say this with this in mind:  A young raver died recently after taking
MDMA and his father posted on SF Raves.  It was sad.  I can't shake this
feeling that he might continue to read the stuff here to try and vilify his
feelings toward raving.  I wanted to tell him that I was sorry and that the
scene really wasn't about drugs, but I didn't.  If he does read the list,
then maybe we can convince him of our intentions.  If not, it's still a bad
idea to post blatently about drugs.

Just some words to think about.  Again, I'm glad you managed to have fun
even though you got burned the first time.

Out!

Tony

Precedence: bulk

schwann-cyber-shaemon spouts:
> The Well, Sausalito, the place where the internet was invented , has

Uh. Excuse me, but this is *BULLSHIT*. The Well, if anything, is a
late-comer to the internet, though they certainly were an important and
early UUCP hub beginning in the early/mid eighties; however, UUCP and
USENET does not equate to INTERNET.

Reminds me too much of Netscape Communication's publicist for Marc
Andreesen -- they claim he singlehandledly invented the internet, world
wide web, and mosaic, even though he prolly couldn't program his way
out of a paper bag if his life depended on it. I really don't see why
people need to lie about this sort of thing -- it's quite disrespectful
of the multitudes of unnamed and generally unknown scientists and
engineers that labor in obscurity and relative poverty...

Other than that, it sounds like an interesting event. I'd like to see a
video-wall link-up where each wall holds the projection seen from a
camera at a remote site; meanwhile, the remote site sees the view from
the wall where they're being projected. Might get some real 
interesting infinite-space-across-the-world video feedback as you see
images from your wall projected on the other side of the earth, and
back again...

With that said, I will go back to work...

-- Niels.

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 13:21:53 -0700
From: michael h david <mdavid01@ccsf.cc.ca.us>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Thoughts on Ravings place in society
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	Does anyone here really think we are going to change peoples attitudes towards
Raving by doing nothing? If the police tape a demonstration and you happen to be organnizing you should be prepared and WILLING to deal with the outcome.  If the general
public saw us standing up openly defending our rights at the expense of our person I
believe we would command more respect. Why dont we have more events benifitting
the enviroment, feeding the hungry, and generally passing our energy into 
positive channels. People would take notice. God knows if we collected canned food
donations at the door of most parties there would be quite a bit of food for people.

I dont organize myself but it sure seems like a lot of us are college students and
even more of us do this as a purly extra curricular activity.  Dont we have 
plenty of resources available to create real positive change.  Maybe I'm
all wrong and our collective apathy will lead to our demise but I would be really
proud to contribute to a party whose sole cause was charitable.

Sometimes the self interests and egotism in raving really makes me sad.

P.S.-If you want to flame me send it to my mailbox or if you are involved in
     a charitable cause let me know.

					-Sometimes Disenchanted
					-MikeD
					-mdavid01@hills.ccsf.cc.ca.us
