In a message dated 95-06-23 13:48:46 EDT, you write:

>Who was the DJ with the shirt that was lit up with white lights, in the 
>basement- He was fantastic! 

I heard that was Talla 2XLC...he definitely won the fashion award for the
night, whoever it was!

I thought the night was a really good opportunity for me to hear DJs and
music that simply do not get heard in the bay area. The stuff upstairs in the
main room was commercial happy hardcore crap, but it was interesting to hear
what is the dominant style in europe, and the music in the smaller downstairs
room was rather boring for me too (fast mainstream/minimal). Jeff Mills (whom
I took a picture of for a fan), though a bit far removed in his playing from
the UR stuff he's written, kept things changing and chaotic, shuffling
records one after the other. Joey Beltram was pretty noisy at times (good),
taking more of a mixer's approach than a DJ's, and Blake Baxter was a bit
more conventional, playing fuller tracks and keeping a standard 8 bar layout
throughout, though BB was the only person the whole night to play a track
that wasn't a 4x4 beat. No, wait, scratch that, the guy who played last down
there played some "funky breakbeat" track for a second. All in all, the music
down there wasn't much of a surprise if you've ever heard Derrick Carter or
Mystic Bill play. 

An important night for the well-rounded dance music fan and/or historian, but
I don't think it really laid out the variety of techno available these days.
It was essential for me to hear what the people who have made the music that
has influenced me (and a lot of you sfravers out there) all these years (this
is speaking of the Tresor room). I did not even mind paying $10 to get in.

Did the gardening club ever happen there? How about the "American DJ" room
(you know, Markie Mark, Jon Williams, etc.)? I could find neither.

.eh

In a message dated 95-06-22 03:22:13 EDT, you write:

>  I haven't been reading much mail lately, but this whole Orb thread 
>caught my eyes.  I just wanted to make a few comments on it, since it is 
>getting a bit out of hand.

<cut here>

>  o Personally I'm not suprised at all the flames and various comments the
>    show caused.  It was so intense, you just HAD to talk about it. I 
>    know I've been talking about it for days now.  

Um, my perspective on how the show went had more to do with the variety of
musics that the Orb have put out since their first couple. I felt the
performance focused on the Blue Room/Little Fluffy Clouds aesthetic while
underreprestenting the more experimental and ambient excursions that have
characterized their later releases and projects. Alex Paterson has said in
interviews that they've moved beyond the DJ and rockstar traps that were
figures of their first tours, but you wouldn't have been able to tell from
seeing them last Friday. The "Lucky Saddle" quote and the Juno Reactor track
were nice surprises, though.

>  o Finally I'm suprised people aren't freaked out at the direction SF is 
>    heading in.  3.5 years ago I went to a rave at the Warfield. It was
>    all ages and went all night. 1.5 years ago I went to the Orb there.
>    If the ushers saw you without a 21+ bracelet on after 2am, you
>    were kicked out.  Now, June 1995, they had to stop the whole show,
>    turn the lights on, and check everyone for a handstamp, essentialy
>    ending the party at 2.

The Orb haven't played longer than they played here in any other city.

>    This is getting ridiculous people.  The current trend is not a good one
>    and if people don't start taking notice, soon all our rights will
>    be gone.  It happened in England, and it could happen here.  It would
>    not suprise me if in 5 years there were even more anti-dancing laws 
>    on the books.

Underagers have not been allowed to stay up past 2 in SF for a while now. I
look at it as an underhanded curfew law rather than a paranoid "anti-dancing"
force. Why don't those who live in SF who are concerned take a more active
approch to the problem than talking about how much it sucks while they watch
the kids getting hustled out of the venue?

.eh

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jun 23 14:43:48 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA06798; Fri, 23 Jun 1995 14:43:48 -0700
Received: from uclink.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA06791; Fri, 23 Jun 1995 14:43:44 -0700
Received: by uclink.berkeley.edu (8.6.10/1.33(web)-OV4)
	id OAA18504; Fri, 23 Jun 1995 14:43:43 -0700
Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 14:43:41 -0700 (PDT)
From: Matthew James Plunkett <plunkett@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Freaky Chakra vs. Single Cell Orchestra
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9506231418.B17040-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Went to Eighth House last night, at the Cat's bar and 
grill on Folsom.  It was five dollars.  This place is 
really interesting; some times I've been there and 
there's a contingent of Harley riders in the front 
room, and a club crowd in the back.  It can 
really draw an interesting mix of people.

When we got there, there was a live ambient 
performance.  Unfortunately, I didn't catch their 
name, but if anyone knows I'd love to know.  Really 
interesting synthesized sounds with some live vocals 
sung on top.  There were some nice visuals also, they 
seemed to be videotape but went really well with the 
music.  As part of the performance, Faith, Charity, 
and Hope (dressed in white toga-like gown thingies) 
mingled with the audience, spreading their goodwill.  
I think I might have been baptized into their 
religion.  (If you organize, can you get 1st amendment 
protection for taking drugs?  ;)  )  They stopped 
playing about midnight.

The second show was billed as "Freaky Chakra vs. 
Single Cell Orchestra".  My guess from this name was 
that it might be a little like the old-time dueling 
piano shows from years ago.  (Turned out to be not far 
off!)

About fifteen minutes later the music started in the 
back room.  The two blue women that everyone had 
noticed come in earlier began a short performance by 
dancing and throwing around some flaming batons . . .  
this started the crowd moving all at once!  The fire 
marshall would have had a cow.  The room heated up 
instantly as everyone started to _move_.  I was a 
little confused at the start since I could see a 
couple of the Sunset people (Solar & Loren??) in the 
mix room upstairs, but the music sounded live.  It had 
that unmistakable percussion sound of Freaky, a 
complex beat compelling me to dance.  The musicians 
turned out to be up in front, and they were mixing 
back and forth.  The two artists were talking back and 
forth at times; I was told that they hadn't even 
practiced very much, but they made it seem _so_ well 
thought out!  The songs mixed very well into each 
other.  I was really impressed with how well they 
worked together to make some amazing music, and would 
love to hear a tape of the music again.  I don't know 
the music of SCO very well, but nearly all the stuff 
Daum was playing sounded new.  Quite a treat!  I don't 
think that there was a point longer than a few seconds 
when both weren't playing something.  There were some 
incredible sounds being made last night, and the 
energy was really nice to feel.  Lots of smiles 
around, and loud applause when they were done.

If anyone in SoCal is reading this, a must-see for 
Saturday night down there!!

Altogether a very nice evening.

Take care,
Matt

> that behave in ways i would not like to approach
> are the drunk people.
> actually,
> i would prefer parties
> without alcohol use (voluntary).
> i know this may infringe on rights
> but if people were a bit more responsible 
> with their use

> 
> responsible drug use
> of any drug
> is vital
> for a good scene
> good vibe
> and good life.
> 
> love to all... throcka

Dear throcka,

	I feel as you do on many of the points above.  I too have often 
noticed that parties where there is a lot of alcohol consumption tend not 
to be good parties.  I think the key here, as you hinted, is responsible 
use of freedoms, so others (like yourself) won't feel inclined to get rid 
of them.
	As I basically said before, safety is another issue, and drunk 
people operating fireworks is generally not a good idea.  Certainly, as 
Maui said, the venue of Sunset with lots of dry grass might not have been 
a wise place to light off a device.  These concerns are legitimate 
"self-policing" (to use another's term) matters, and are not censorship.  
Self-censorship involves responding to actual or feared societal or official 
disapproval, and it is this doing of the cops' dirty work for them that I 
object to.
	While others should respect your presence as much as possible, it 
is also up to you to (politely) let them know if they are doing something 
that bothers you (i.e. lighting a firework off too close and assaulting 
your nose with the smell), so they can refrain from further disturbing 
you or an agreeable compromise can be reached.  Respectfully, no one can 
stop you from worrying, nor is that anyone's responsibility but yours.  
People can always find something to worry about, right or wrong.  
Likewise someone who simply *doesn't like* fireworks, shouldn't be able 
to suppress them, just as someone offended by the words of another 
shouldn't be able to censor their speech.  In a free society, free speech 
and free expression necessarily take precedence over the "right" not to 
be offended, unless we're talking libel or actual injury.
	A good solution here, as both you and Lee Fogel touched on, is to 
have different parties for people who enjoy different ways of partying.  
That's free market (dare I say it) capitalism at work.  :)
(Wait, wait -- let me get my flame suit on!!)

	Love to friends & family,

					*** Starchild ***
______________________________________________________________________________
"Having the right to do something doesn't make doing it right."
				-syndicated columnist William Safire
______________________________________________________________________________

> Went to Eighth House last night, at the Cat's bar and 
> grill on Folsom.  It was five dollars.  This place is 
> really interesting; some times I've been there and 
> there's a contingent of Harley riders in the front 
> room, and a club crowd in the back.  It can 
> really draw an interesting mix of people.

Philip, aka theta-blip, who runs the 8th house, is a transplant
from the Seattle Goth scene. He's had some success over the past
year mixing in some of that serious gloom with SF techno/trance
events.  Like the punks, anarchists, h/zippies and break dancers
amongst us, he's glommed on to the vitality of raving in a bid
to instill new life into some tire attitudes.  Now people who wear
black and don't like to smile can go out and have fun too.  :)

> When we got there, there was a live ambient 
> performance.  Unfortunately, I didn't catch their name.

Me neither, but yes, I thought they were very good.

>   As part of the performance, Faith, Charity, 
> and Hope (dressed in white toga-like gown thingies) 
> mingled with the audience, spreading their goodwill.  

Turned out to be an interesting evening of ritual and performance.
Most of the people seemed to be into it.

> The second show was billed as "Freaky Chakra vs. 
> Single Cell Orchestra".  My guess from this name was 
> that it might be a little like the old-time dueling 
> piano shows from years ago.  (Turned out to be not far 
> off!)

These guys were my reason for being there.  A live techno
performance by 2 of SF's hottest talents.  No DATs or computers,
lots of improvisation and live mixing of sequences.  

> About fifteen minutes later the music started in the 
> back room.  The two blue women that everyone had 
> noticed come in earlier began a short performance by 
> dancing and throwing around some flaming batons . . .  

Weren't these 2 naked blue firedancers at some other show recently?
Did some country sent them over as part of the UN celebrations?

> little confused at the start since I could see a 
> couple of the Sunset people (Solar & Loren??) in the 
> mix room upstairs, but the music sounded live.

Galen and Lorien were just playing around with the lights.  Solar
had just finished spinning a nice "gothy" trance set up there.

>  they made it seem _so_ well 
> thought out!  The songs mixed very well into each 
> other.  I was really impressed with how well they 
> worked together to make some amazing music,

They did a great job, especially considering that one of their
main keyboards had crashed just before the show.  Pretty cool to
see Miguel (Single Cell Orch.)  reroute MIDI and audio cables
*during* the set.  If you watched their interactions, it was
apparant that they screwed up a lot of things, but it still sounded
pretty good to me.  They would have played a lot longer if Daum
(freaky C.) hadn't just erased 1/3 of his MIDI disk material by mistake.
After 45 minutes, they were done and Daum waved his hands saying that
they didn't have any more material for an encore.  Nevertheless,
they gave into our demands and managed to improvise a really good 
10 minute piece for us.  I'm not a big fan of live techno, but
this show turned out to be a lot of fun.

Lee

Subject: 13 moon calendar (was Re: Brothers and Sisters )
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 23 Jun 95 16:31:38 PDT."
             <Chameleon.4.01.1.950623163555.ameba@ameba.ameba.com> 
Date: Fri, 23 Jun 95 16:56:45 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> desperately seeking 13 moon software, help us discover 
> the dement-ion of time.
>      It's not a projection of architectural space.

Wasn't the "original" babylonian and the hebrew calendar based on 13
months? Only to be supplanted with a completely illogical 12 month calendar
by Christians that thought the number 13 was evil?  (but leap years and
leap seconds and months of different lengths and crazed regularity was
"good").

Well, if you can run the GNU emacs program (you're on netcom, so you can),
type Alt-X calendar and issue some of the following commands. You can
toggle around in Islamic, Hebrew, Mayan, as well as the good ol' Gregorian
(as in bonking your self over the head with a 2x4 while chanting ave maria)
calendar.

If you delve into the sources
netcom:/usr/local/lib/emacs/19.19/lisp/calendar.el, you'll also note some
interesting background info:

;; This collection of functions implements a calendar window.  It
;; generates a calendar for the current month, together with the previous
;; and coming months, or for any other three-month period.  The calendar
;; can be scrolled forward and backward in the window to show months in
;; the past or future; the cursor can move forward and backward by days,
;; weeks, or months, making it possible, for instance, to jump to the
;; date a specified number of days, weeks, or months from the date under
;; the cursor.  The user can display a list of holidays and other notable
;; days for the period shown; the notable days can be marked on the
;; calendar, if desired.  The user can also specify that dates having
;; corresponding diary entries (in a file that the user specifies) be
;; marked; the diary entries for any date can be viewed in a separate
;; window.  The diary and the notable days can be viewed independently of
;; the calendar.  Dates can be translated from the (usual) Gregorian
;; calendar to the day of the year/days remaining in year, to the ISO
;; commercial calendar, to the Julian (old style) calendar, to the Hebrew
;; calendar, to the Islamic calendar, to the French Revolutionary calendar,
;; to the Mayan calendar, and to the astronomical (Julian) day number.
;; When floating point is available, times of sunrise/sunset can be displayed,
;; as can the phases of the moon.  Appointment notification for diary entries
;; is available.

;; The following files are part of the calendar/diary code:

;;       diary.el, diary-ins.el        Diary functions
;;       holidays.el                   Holiday functions
;;       cal-french.el                 French Revolutionary calendar
;;       cal-mayan.el                  Mayan calendars
;;       cal-dst.el                    Daylight savings time rules
;;       solar.el                      Sunrise/sunset, equinoxes/solstices
;;       lunar.el                      Phases of the moon
;;       appt.el                       Appointment notification

;; Comments, corrections, and improvements should be sent to
;;  Edward M. Reingold               Department of Computer Science
;;  (217) 333-6733                   University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
;;  reingold@cs.uiuc.edu             1304 West Springfield Avenue
;;                                   Urbana, Illinois 61801

;; GNU Emacs users too numerous to list pointed out a variety of problems
;; with earlier forms of the `infinite' sliding calendar and suggested some
;; of the features included in this package.  Especially significant in this
;; regard was the suggestion of mark-diary-entries and view-diary-entries,
;; together ideas for their implementation, by
;;  Michael S. Littman		     Cognitive Science Research Group
;;  (201) 829-5155                   Bell Communications Research
;;  mlittman@wind.bellcore.com       445 South St. Box 1961 (2L-331)
;;                                   Morristown, NJ  07960

;; The algorithms for the Hebrew calendar are those of the Rambam (Rabbi Moses
;; Maimonides), from his Mishneh Torah, as implemented by
;;  Nachum Dershowitz                Department of Computer Science
;;  (217) 333-4219                   University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
;;  nachum@cs.uiuc.edu               1304 West Springfield Avenue
;;                                   Urbana, Illinois 61801

;; Technical details of all the calendrical calculations can be found in

;; ``Calendrical Calculations'' by Nachum Dershowitz and Edward M. Reingold,
;; Software--Practice and Experience, Volume 20, Number 9 (September, 1990),
;; pages 899-928.  ``Calendrical Calculations, Part II: Three Historical
;; Calendars'' by E. M. Reingold,  N. Dershowitz, and S. M. Clamen,
;; Software--Practice and Experience, Volume 23, Number 4 (April, 1993),
;; pages 383-404.

;; Hard copies of these two papers can be obtained by sending email to
;; reingold@cs.uiuc.edu with the SUBJECT "send-paper-cal" (no quotes) and
;; the message BODY containing your mailing address (snail).

--------------------
Here's the "help-on-mode" info for emacs calendar mode (C-h m):
--------------------

Calendar Mode:
A major mode for the calendar window.

The commands for cursor movement are:

       C-f  one day forward           C-b  one day backward
       C-n  one week forward          C-p  one week backward
       M-}  one month forward       M-{  one month backward
       C-x ]  one year forward        C-x [  one year backward
       C-a  beginning of week         C-e  end of week
       M-a  beginning of month      M-e  end of month
       M-<  beginning of year       M->  end of year

       g d  go to date

       g j  go to Julian date         g a  go to astronomical (Julian) day number
       g h  go to Hebrew date         g i  go to Islamic date
       g c  go to ISO date            g f  go to French Revolutionary date

       g m l  go to Mayan Long Count date
       g m n h  go to next occurrence of Mayan Haab date
       g m p h  go to previous occurrence of Mayan Haab date
       g m n t  go to next occurrence of Mayan Tzolkin date
       g m p t  go to previous occurrence of Mayan Tzolkin date
       g m n c  go to next occurrence of Mayan Calendar Round date
       g m p c  go to previous occurrence of Mayan Calendar Round date

You can mark a date in the calendar and switch the point and mark:

       C-@  mark date                 C-x C-x  exchange point and mark

You can determine the number of days (inclusive) between the point and mark by

       M-=  count days in the region

The commands for calendar movement are:

       C-x >  scroll one month right   C-x <  scroll one month left
       M-v  scroll 3 months right    C-v  scroll 3 months left
       .  display current month        o  display another month

Whenever it makes sense, the above commands take prefix arguments that
multiply their affect.  For convenience, the digit keys and the minus sign
are bound to digit-argument, so they need not be prefixed with ESC.

If the calendar window somehow becomes corrupted, it can be regenerated with

       C-c C-l  redraw the calendar

The following commands deal with holidays and other notable days:

       h  give holidays for the date specified by the cursor
       x  mark notable days
       u  unmark dates
       a  display notable days

The command M-x holidays causes the notable dates for the current month, and
the preceding and succeeding months, to be displayed, independently of the
calendar.

The following commands control the diary:

       m  mark diary entries          u  unmark dates
       d  display diary entries       s  show all diary entries
       M-x print-diary-entries  print diary entries

Displaying the diary entries causes the diary entries from the diary-file
(for the date indicated by the cursor in the calendar window) to be
displayed in another window.  This function takes an integer argument that
specifies the number of days of calendar entries to be displayed, starting
with the date indicated by the cursor.

The command M-x print-diary-entries prints the diary buffer (as it appears)
on the line printer.

The command M-x diary causes the diary entries for the current date to be
displayed, independently of the calendar.  The number of days of entries is
governed by number-of-diary-entries.

The format of the entries in the diary file is described in the
documentation string for the variable diary-file.

When diary entries are in view in the window, they can be edited.  It is
important to keep in mind that the buffer displayed contains the entire
diary file, but with portions of it concealed from view.  This means, for
instance, that the forward-char command can put the cursor at what appears
to be the end of the line, but what is in reality the middle of some
concealed line.  BE CAREFUL WHEN EDITING THE DIARY ENTRIES! (Inserting
additional lines or adding/deleting characters in the middle of a visible
line will not cause problems; watch out for end-of-line, however--it may
put you at the end of a concealed line far from where the cursor appears to
be!)  BEFORE EDITING THE DIARY IT IS BEST TO DISPLAY THE ENTIRE FILE WITH
show-all-diary-entries.  BE SURE TO WRITE THE FILE BEFORE EXITING FROM THE
CALENDAR.

The following commands assist in making diary entries:

       i d  insert a diary entry for the selected date
       i w  insert a diary entry for the selected day of the week
       i m  insert a diary entry for the selected day of the month
       i y  insert a diary entry for the selected day of the year
       i b  insert a diary entry for the block days between point and mark
       i a  insert an anniversary diary entry for the selected date
       i c  insert a cyclic diary entry

There are corresponding commands to assist in making Hebrew- or Islamic-date
diary entries:

       i h d  insert a diary entry for the Hebrew date corresponding
                to the selected date
       i h m  insert a diary entry for the day of the Hebrew month
                corresponding to the selected day
       i h y  insert a diary entry for the day of the Hebrew year
                corresponding to the selected day
       i i d  insert a diary entry for the Islamic date corresponding
                to the selected date
       i i m  insert a diary entry for the day of the Islamic month
                corresponding to the selected day
       i i y  insert a diary entry for the day of the Islamic year
                corresponding to the selected day

All of the diary entry commands make nonmarking entries when given a prefix
argument; with no prefix argument, the diary entries are marking.

The day number in the year and the number of days remaining in the year can be
determined by

       p d  show day number and the number of days remaining in the year

Equivalent dates on the ISO commercial, Julian, Hebrew, Islamic, French
Revolutionary, and Mayan calendars can be determined by

       p c  show equivalent date on the ISO commercial calendar
       p j  show equivalent date on the Julian calendar
       p h  show equivalent date on the Hebrew calendar
       p i  show equivalent date on the Islamic calendar
       p f  show equivalent date on the French Revolutionary calendar
       p m  show equivalent date on the Mayan calendar

The astronomical (Julian) day number of a date is found with

       p a  show equivalent astronomical (Julian) day number

To find the times of sunrise and sunset and lunar phases use

       S  show times of sunrise and sunset
       M  show times of quarters of the moon

The times given will be at latitude `solar-latitude', longitude
`solar-longitude' in time zone `solar-time-zone'.  These variables, and the
variables `solar-location-name', `solar-standard-time-zone-name',
`solar-daylight-time-zone-name', `solar-daylight-savings-starts',
`solar-daylight-savings-ends', `calendar-daylight-time-offset',
and `calendar-daylight-savings-switchover-time' should be set for
your location.

To exit from the calendar use

       q  exit from calendar

The variable `view-diary-entries-initially', whose default is nil, can be
set to to t cause diary entries for the current date will be displayed in
another window when the calendar is first displayed, if the current date is
visible.  The variable `number-of-diary-entries' controls number of days of
diary entries that will be displayed initially or with the command M-x
diary.  For example, if the default value 1 is used, then only the current
day's diary entries will be displayed.  If the value 2 is used, both the
current day's and the next day's entries will be displayed.  The value can
also be a vector: If the value is [0 2 2 2 2 4 1] then no diary entries
will be displayed on Sunday, the current date's and the next day's diary
entries will be displayed Monday through Thursday, Friday through Monday's
entries will be displayed on Friday, while on Saturday only that day's
entries will be displayed.

The variable `view-calendar-holidays-initially' can be set to t to cause the
holidays for the current three month period will be displayed on entry to the
calendar.  The holidays are displayed in another window.

The variable `mark-diary-entries-in-calendar' can be set to t to cause any
dates visible with calendar entries to be marked with the symbol specified by
the variable `diary-entry-marker', normally a plus sign.

The variable `calendar-load-hook', whose default value is nil, is list of
functions to be called when the calendar is first loaded.

The variable `initial-calendar-window-hook', whose default value is nil, is
list of functions to be called when the calendar window is first opened.  The
functions invoked are called after the calendar window is opened, but once
opened is never called again.  Leaving the calendar with the `q' command and
reentering it will cause these functions to be called again.

The variable `today-visible-calendar-hook', whose default value is nil, is the
list of functions called after the calendar buffer has been prepared with the
calendar when the current date is visible in the window.  This can be used,
for example, to replace today's date with asterisks; a function
calendar-star-date is included for this purpose: (setq
today-visible-calendar-hook 'calendar-star-date) It could also be used to mark
the current date with `*'; a function is also provided for this: (setq
today-visible-calendar-hook 'calendar-mark-today)

The variable `today-invisible-calendar-hook', whose default value is nil, is
the list of functions called after the calendar buffer has been prepared with
the calendar when the current date is not visible in the window.

The variable `diary-display-hook' is the list of functions called after the
diary buffer is prepared.  The default value simply displays the diary file
using selective-display to conceal irrelevant diary entries.  An alternative
function `fancy-diary-display' is provided that, when used as the
`diary-display-hook', causes a noneditable buffer to be prepared with a neatly
organized day-by-day listing of relevant diary entries, together with any
known holidays.  The inclusion of the holidays slows this fancy display of the
diary; to speed it up, set the variable `holidays-in-diary-buffer' to nil.

The variable `print-diary-entries-hook' is the list of functions called after
a temporary buffer is prepared with the diary entries currently visible in the
diary buffer.  The default value of this hook adds a heading (composed from
the diary buffer's mode line), does the printing with the command lpr-buffer,
and kills the temporary buffer.  Other uses might include, for example,
rearranging the lines into order by day and time.

The Gregorian calendar is assumed.

--------------------

=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =

From: nobrand@teleport.com (nobrand)
Newsgroups: alt.music.orb
Subject: Report PDX show 6/19
Date: 20 Jun 1995 07:31:25 GMT
Organization: Teleport - Portland's Public Access (503) 220-1016
Lines: 26
Message-ID: <nobrand-2006950036090001@ip-pdx4-10.teleport.com>
NNTP-Posting-Host: ip-pdx4-10.teleport.com
X-Newsreader: Value-Added NewsWatcher 2.0b20.0+

   Just came back from the show.  I wanted to get an idea of what others
had to say about the show.  I think I was expecting a bit much, or
something.  Not that I didn't enjoy myself, but I had expected to see a
little more than lights and turntables.  

   I was amazed with the lights, though.  WOW!  Some time went into that. 
there were some really high points to it.  I am sure there still are. 
It's still going as I type this.  I'm sure it should go for quite some
time.  Probably, I would suspect, til 3 or 4 or even after.  

   I have never seen anyone get into playing a mixing table like this
guy.  You would have sworn that he was playing guitar for like, one of
those jumpy up and down rock bands!  hmmm.

  I think I was expecting to see more cool gear.  2600's, Moogs, maybe a
20 foot wide Polyfusion, I don't know.  There was not ONE keyboard to be
seen.  Oh, well.

   I've seen DJ's spin Orb sets before, and the lights were the only REAL
thing that set this apart from a DJ'ed set. All the lights were behind
them, too, so you couldn't even make out their faces.

   I did manage to get a couple of shirts.  I like the blue one the best 
:)


Brian

Dera All;

> Philip, aka theta-blip, who runs the 8th house, is a transplant
> from the Seattle Goth scene. He's had some success over the past
> year mixing in some of that serious gloom with SF techno/trance
> events.  Like the punks, anarchists, h/zippies and break dancers
> amongst us, he's glommed on to the vitality of raving in a bid
> to instill new life into some tire attitudes.  Now people who wear
> black and don't like to smile can go out and have fun too.  :)

	The goth scene is much more than mentioned above, it not about a
bad attitudes and sneering at people. It's a direct projection of all the
death, violence, fear & the constant threat of global & regional NBC(Nuclear,
Biological & Chemical) warfare that prevails on our TV's, Street's, &
Homes. My opinion follows; its societies way of saying that death & 
descruction are here to stay, better make friends with them. I think many 
of us at one point in our lives found either the music of people like 
Killing Joke, Cabert Voltaire, Sister's of Mercy, Fad Gadget, Bauhaus  ..etc 
comforting and interesting. It took the sting out of what we saw, & read 
about the our worlds atrosities. If you don't agree with me fine, but ask 
yourself; if you listened to or listen to this music, whats on your mind 
when your listening, what are you feeling inside. I maybe wrong as I 
otfen am, but I don't think I'll be too far away.


		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian Darkness, LMT/EE/CET
		(510)-530-6452 CT Active Voice & Fax
	     (800)-590-4993 CT Active Voice Mail & Pager

		Internet:		brianv@liberty.com
	     Alt. Internet:		brianvan@liberty.com

			"The message is LOVE"

> early UUCP hub beginning in the early/mid eighties; however, UUCP and
> USENET does not equate to INTERNET.
>

> Andreesen -- they claim he singlehandledly invented the internet, world
> wide web, and mosaic, even though he prolly couldn't program his way
> out of a paper bag if his life depended on it. I really don't see why

Checking over my last week of mail I noticed that some people have been 
wondering who Tristan is and what he looks like.  First of all, I am not 
Kevin Keiper; I merely use his account.  He is my room-mate and is one 
of my best friends and is a really nice mild mannered guy; unlike me who
is an obnoxious little shit (right?).
    He go's out a lot more then I do because he likes nightclubs 
and I don't (except may be 1015 on Friday night).  I, Tristan, am 6ft 2 
1/2" tall, weigh 180 pounds and have long brown hair.  I am ussually 
found at Sunset parties sitting down right next to the speaker smoking pot.
If anybody wants to ever come by for a smoke, and I love debating me, 
they can catch me their every Sunday for the rest of the Summer.
Love Tristan.

Dear All;

	I was at Organic lastnight which was at the Troc, as I was 
sitting there rolling my brains out like never before. I noticed a camera 
crew hangin around the Herbal X tables, so I walked up and asked them who 
they where with; they said MTV. Oh I said, they said they wanted to do a 
story on Herbal X and the SF Rave scene, I told them not to waist their 
time with the Herbal X thing, it's all hype, and most people that I've 
talked to say it gives them a 3 day hangover, which is excessive to me. 
So they actually liked what I had to say and interviewed me, so if you 
see me on MTV(I serious doubt it), saying do the real thing, meaning 
don't use the Herbal stuff, use the chemical stuff, that's me.

	But in general, they are to say the least very curious, so be 
prepaired to one large CCD eye shine in on our scene. The club 
owners/promoters love MTV's unsolisted attention, if they mention the club 
on MTV, that club gets nationwide promo's., and everyone, everywhere 
else, said's this is the place to go in SF for da Techno.

	In general Allison seemed interested, will be subscibing to our 
list, if she can fiqure out how to do it, hehe :). They spent most of the 
night at the club, which I thought was nice, they seemed to really want 
to get a flavor for the SF scene, my spies tell me they where at DV8 the 
other night, and where headed back to NEw York this morning.

	Thats the facts; my opinion; the music industry needs something 
new to talk about, you can only say so much about Courtney Love. The 
potential is that a part of our scene will be brought into the main 
stream, which I feel kinda sucks, but that's what happens. It's happened to 
every music scene I've ever been apart of, it took Punk about 10 years 
but they finally & unfortuately got there. There is one exception Gothic 
never made it.

	Organic by the way was great, overcrowded, no AC in site, but fun 
never the less. The Troc has a killer light show, fog so thick you can't 
see your belly button, and a great sound system. They need more furiture 
though, a lot more. Security seemed mellow, less a few well handled, and 
well needed interventions.

	The SF scene is a funny thing, just when you thing you know 
everyone, you can go to an event, and find out that you only know a 
handful of people. This was my 1st Organic since arriving here 6 months ago.

	The #-Report, my informents tell me that 2 major indenpent 
suppliers got busted this week. Be careful people the man is heavaily 
funded, staffed by educated rightous people, very heavivally equiped, 
and always on. A simple saying I remember growing up that has kept me 
safe, whenever I get lazy, or careless I say this to myself "Better safe 
than sorry", and it seems to have worked for me. 

	On the other hand there is some killer # out there, stuff that 
makes me reminis, about the # in Florida, which on and average puts the 
stuff here in SF to shame. Well thats all for me, thats enough!!

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian Darkness, LMT/EE/CET
		(510)-530-6452 CT Active Voice & Fax
	     (800)-590-4993 CT Active Voice Mail & Pager

		Internet:		brianv@liberty.com
	     Alt. Internet:		brianvan@liberty.com

			"The message is LOVE"

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk

> The 
>potential is that a part of our scene will be brought into the main 
>stream, which I feel kinda sucks, but that's what happens. It's happened to 
>every music scene I've ever been apart of, it took Punk about 10 years 
>but they finally & unfortuately got there. There is one exception Gothic 
>never made it.

Depends on how "hard core" your gothic is. What about the Cure or
Depeche Mode? Perhaps these bands are gothic-lite (e.g. they're more
accessible/mainstream than, say, Bauhaus), but they're certainly
somewhat doom-and-gloom oriented, and they're popular too.

Also, I recently saw the movie "The Crow" on Video, and that was a
goth-wet dream if I ever saw one. The fact that you have "gothic"
themes in a widely advertized mainstream movie implies it ain't
underground.

Seems like just about everything "makes it" eventually... I'm looking
forward to the day when technology/media increases the rate of
dissemination to the point where everything is simultaneously "retro"
and "avant garde".

PS: I think people are fooling themselves to think that "rave" hasn't
"made it" when "techno" is the background music for TV commercials
(e.g. the Pirelli one) and music for models to sachay (sp?) down the
runway on TV "fashion" specials ... And this techno-mainstreaming has
happened a lot faster than 60's rock-anthems have made it into TV
commercials (e.g. Janis Joplin's "Mercedes Benz" song, etc.).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

> 	"kill the poor"

I was working on a design, listening to the radio, and for dummy text 
I typically type in whatever lyrics I happen to hear playing... this 
time it turned out to be "Kill, kill, kill, kill the poor" . I didn't 
think much of it and sent the sample pages out. bad move. big, somber 
corporate  meeting to discuss "Alissa's insubordinate behavior". As I 
tried to explain my innocence in the situation, I found that these 
people do not consider it appropriate to listen to music while 
working! yikes! no wonder they're so grumpy all the time!

OB Rave: my dummy text is much less lyric-oriented

Howdy-dowdy all....

I'd have to say that F-8 has been one of the most intimate-underground raves
that i've been to in a bit. some times it's nice to get back to the roots of
searching, wnadering and almost-getting-your-neck broke while accentally
falling off a cliff while searching for the spot.  The DJ sets were pretty
tight, and although the dance floor was basiclly nil (all sand), it was worth
it.
I'd like to say hi-di ho to the Djs and fellow ravers who extended thier
friendship while my crew couldnt make it  (i was the one dancin' off the
rocks by the speakers), sorry names always escape me..  

THe naked guys running around was pretty trippy too....

	Well, I've been reading SFRaves for a while now and finally have
time to add my 2 cents.  I figured this would be a pretty appropriate
first posting for me because if there's one thing I could ever associate
with as much as the rave scene it's Goth.  


> Darkness on Goth,
> 
> > It took the sting out of what we saw, & read
> > about the our worlds atrosities. If you don't agree with me fine, but ask
> > yourself; if you listened to or listen to this music, whats on your mind
> > when your listening, what are you feeling inside.

And then Sir Dave spake thusly:
> 
> I never felt 'comforted' by this music.
> 

It's funny, because I would have to agree with both of you.  I guess what
I've gotten out of Gothic music, and what I still get out of Gothic music,
is this.  Sometimes when I'm feeling down, like _really_ down, I'll light
a lot of candles, turn off the lights, pop in Some Girls Wander By
Mistake, lay on the floor and just listen.  When I'm done listening, I
feel a lot better.  I think it's because the music is really cathartic in
a way.  Sure, it's dark and sometimes violent, but that's just the way
that those singers/songwriters express their feelings.  It doesn't make me
more depressed; in fact, it's almost cleansing, like you can get out all
your agression and negative feelings while listening to it.

> cheers,
> Dave
> 
> 

						-Jake

Dear All;

	Reality check; the Internet was started in WW2; and we owe it
unfortuately to the necessities of war; and was started by the defense
department, so they could link all there systems together, Being such a
wonderful idea, it spread into the commerical markets and is where it is
today; and where it will continue to grow, until its absolutely required
for even the most basic of services, like mail, electric, phone ..etc I'm
personnal looking forward to the day, when all my mail gets sent to me
instanteously and doesn't take 5 days to go from coast to coast, as well
as a cashless society. 

	It was not created by a bunch of peace loving hippies, scientist,
or engineers, it was created for war, by weapons systems engineers, hard
fuckin core people, I should know I used to be one. 

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian Darkness, LMT/EE/CET

On 25 Jun 95 at 16:17, Brian Darkness wrote:
> 	Reality check; the Internet was started in WW2; and we owe it
> unfortuately to the necessities of war; and was started by the defense
> department, so they could link all there systems together, Being such a

re-reality check:  Computers did not even exist until the mid 50's.
There would not have been much to network "in WW2". 

The theme of your point is correct, though:  what is now the internet
was originally started as a defense project.  Most internet histories
trace back to a backbone network called ARPAnet, intended to link
computers at universities (the most prevalent location of large
configurations, mostly from ARPA/DARPA grants) and government sites.   
That was during the late 60's.

Anyone interested in a fairly accurate chronicle of the computer
industry, including the beginnings of the internet, should watch
ACM's "The Machine that Changed the World" series.  It runs on PBS
from time to time.

OBRAVE:  I was at 1015 Folsom last friday & had a great time.  The
first DJ (Tracy?) was a lot of fun.  Whoever came on next was boring,
I thought, to the point where I spent the next few hours dancing in
the 70's disco room!  Met a lot of folks but didn't bump into any
SFravers this time.  For saturday night, we went to F/X in downtown
San Jose.  The caveman dude was there, but not dancing.  We'll be 
back at 1015 next friday..

Allan

-- 
Allan Schaffer                                             aschaffe@sgi.com

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Frequency 8 Kicks!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     Went with a couple of friends to Frequency 8 on Friday and wanted to 
     let you know that these boys know how to do a party right.  With all 
     their bases covered, there's no excuse for it not to go off.  The way 
     they've set theirselves up, I have to say that it's pure love that 
     drives them to do this.  Hauling equipment is tedious, but turning 
     people on to music is even better and they know how to do it all.  
     
     Getting to the site was a journey in itself enlisting trust of 
     whomever brought a flashlight--but once there, it takes a while to 
     take it all in.  I remember starting to walk around the entire "set-up 
     space" several times but _never_ making it all around.  It was just 
     too good and enticing to make it all around--for me at least.  
     
     From the people, to the space, to the music, it was all good.  The 
     lighting they brought in complimented the natural lighting from the 
     stars and the reflection from the ocean.  It was wonderful to discover 
     the site and people's faces as the morning light came with the 
     sunrise.  By the time the sun was up, so were we in every imaginable 
     way!  Talk about afterglows, my friends and I were floating in our 
     celestial bodies all the way to the Sunset party on Sunday, which I 
     had to leave at around 4:30 p.m...another good party ready to go 
     off--which btw is gaining a rep of the place to be even w/some o'da 
     hardcores.
     
     The music at Frequency 8 was more trance but that's what you expect 
     when you go on a "Cybertrance Journey", right?  Though the number of 
     us was relatively small, the vibe was great, and as Adam Fostous (sp?) 
     said (I finally met him!), the smile factor was there too.  I'll save 
     the ratings to Adam ;) (Hey, Adam, do we get a hugometer, too?)
     
     In any case, I just want to recommend a wonderful Friday gig that's 
     inexpensive and has alot of heart in the right place.  A promoter 
     friend of mine was reinspired by what we felt grooving there Friday 
     night/Saturday morning.  Check it out and understand why I'm giving 
     these boys applause.
     
     Have a great week and enjoy the sunshine!
     
     Love, 
     Diane

On Sun, 25 Jun 1995, Brian Darkness wrote:

Regarding the Internet,

> for even the most basic of services, like mail, electric, phone ..etc I'm
> personnal looking forward to the day, when all my mail gets sent to me
> instanteously and doesn't take 5 days to go from coast to coast, as well
> as a cashless society. 

Not me! For an interesting perspective on a cashless society, read "The 
Handmaid's Tale," a story by Margaret Atwood set in the not-too-distant 
future. Everyone gets paid and makes purchases electronically using a debit 
card. Fundamentalist Christians take over the government, and they 
successfully eradicate civil rights by simply 
shutting down the financial accounts of those they don't like (namely women).
Very frightening, and very plausible, unfortunately.  Also, there was 
something floating around the net recently about some guy who didn't 
believe in credit and tried to buy a car with cash (roughly $40K). Not 
only was he unable to buy the car, but he was investigated by 
authorities, who suspected he was a drug dealer (he wasn't).

Call me paranoid, but I think the government has enough info about me and 
my purchasing habits without its tracking my cash purchases too.

Now for the rave-related part,

Does anyone know how to reach Greg, late of Japan, brother to Bill (of 
Bill and Gabby)? I forgot to get a phone number last week at Sunset.

Also, do any of you sfrave oldtimers know where I can get a copy of the 
sharp/flat tape? It is one of a set of four tapes put together by Bob 
Ramsted from an sfraves event in 1993 (?). I loaned my copy out and never 
saw it again.

Thanks for any help.

Peace,
Kathryn

it was a mediocre Sunset 

the crowd seemed younger than usual.  either it
was or there was a lack of older folks.  this results
in a nice parade of cute, oh, nevermind ...  it makes a party
more one-dimensional.  i'd like to see a special Grandma Sunset
where everyone brings their oldest family or friends

the vibe was borderline 'burnt out' and
dancing was a bit incoherent.  the 'pigpen' style
dust was fun the first time.  usually i like super 
housey house, but that park begged for something
a little dirtier.

of course, this is all relative - 
galen's birthday party had me tapping my toes all week.

and it's official - "wading" is the hip new sport of the 90's.
i don't really get how it's scored but it sure is aesthetically
pleasing ...

Dave

 > Exactly. I still do the same thing.
> Whenever I feel completely *hopeless* I put on Disintegration and 
> light the candles. The music does comfort me, and even uplifts me. 
> I always feel better after I spend time in the dark.
> It's like a wierd type of soul purification. :)
> Ironically, Raves are kind of the same thing-- but the music is a bit 
> different. :)

>       alex_c@scs.unr.edu  |    you can get away with"

Not even a little looney - at least not by SFRaves standards :)

Interesting about Raves ... how many other people are into both
ambient/techno and gothic?  I'm just wondering, but I would assume it's
quite a few people.  I guess it is similar, in a sense - although I
couldn't see myself putting on Autechre in a candle lit room and thinking
a lot of black thoughts. Although I guess it would work in a _completely_
dark room thinking lots of weird thoughts.  In any case, I think the
feeling I get from rave music is a lot more of a feeling of timelessness
than anything else.  I think it is cathartic, as well, but not such a
violent, all-consuming catharsis.
	Guess it depends on the mood I'm in.

Hi All,
If you want to track what's happening in the US political arena as it
relates to the internet and technology you should get the Cyberwire
Dispatch.  Brock Meeks does an excellent job chronicling the antics
of our governing bodies.  He publishes maybe once every couple of weeks
(depends on Congress, etc.) so it isn't going to overflow your in box. 
Definitely worth reading.

To subscribe, send an email to:
    majordomo@cyberwerks.com

In the body of the email type:
    subscribe cwd-1 <your email address>

That should be it.

Enjoy,

Bradley

Hi.  My name is Sho.  I'm moving to the Bay Area in August
to work at General Magic.  Some of you know me from vrave.
...or if you've been out to the midwest, you may have heard
me spin ...or maybe you've seen my name on a flyer or two.
In any case, hi.

I'm currently trying to find housing.  It's not critical
that I find housmates who are in the scene, but I thought
that it might be nice to live with people who won't look at
me funny and ask questions like "what is that crap you're
listning to?  doesn't it have any words?"  Well, actually,
I'm not 100% sure if I want housemates at all!  But I guess
my feeling is that I'm a pretty social person and that it
would be nice to have people around.

So, if anyone out there is looking for another person to
live with starting in August, let me know.  I'm looking at
either palo alto or somewhere in/around SF proper.  

*crossing my fingers*

-Sho

this info has to be redistributed to if you are into that kind of thing,

set pec-list conceal end

in the body of the message. this machine only accepts connections to a

From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>

        San FranDisco Ravers List <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Internet Bill of Rights
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950626094007.20856A-100000@crl.crl.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950626160929.9534B-100000@liberty.liberty.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

	Kathryn has brought up a very good point. If we as a world & a
free society want to embrace this technology, which can & will change our
lives to a degree much greater than the TV, or may the automobile did.
Than the Internet must be protected by its own Bill of Rights. Keep in
mine I'm talking about a future where there's total world wide digital
connectivity to a much greater degree than at present, and a
computer/modem a standard piece of household furture, in almost every
home, sorta like Johnny Neumonic Technology, less the really unbelievable
stuff, A Right would be something like that no citzen can ever be 
totally locked out, restricted yes, but never totally locked out. Again 
I'm talking about a society where the most basic of necessities are 
access through the internet, regular mail, banking, public utillites ...etc

	Many of the people in power will be relucted to give americans 
more rights, in fact many feel we have to many. If this comes to be, as I 
think it will, there will come a time; like NOW, to start addvocating for 
the rights, electing politians that agree with them; and going out and 
protesting if necessary. THe groundwork laid over the next 20 years will 
impack into the furture, mainly our children, and their children.

	Sounds like an ATT commerical huh, but I believe it to be true. 
Sitting here as an engineer, I just see it coming, plane as day. No one 
own's the internet, yet, so the way I look at it it's public property, no 
negatives implied. So we the users the public own it, meaning that the 
internet is very provider, every accout ...etc from the main frames, & phone 
lines to the most modest of dumb terminals. The future is my 
responsibilty, I hope you think so to.

	Kathryn, I also image that as time goes on, this debate will grow 
to possibily rivaling that abortion, and will devide many a kind people. 
How much of this new techology to we want in our lives, in our homes?, are 
there sufficent checks & balances, is there a guarentee of privacy, or at 
least a reasonable assurance? why not just keep going on the way we 
are(not). Tuff questions?

	Please post all flames privatly, thank you, and remember its just
my opinion :), I not sitting here writing legaslation, save that for Bill 
& Newt.

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian Darkness, LMT/EE/CET
		(510)-530-6452 CT Active Voice & Fax
	     (800)-590-4993 CT Active Voice Mail & Pager

		Internet:		brianv@liberty.com
	     Alt. Internet:		brianvan@liberty.com

			"The message is LOVE"

On Sun, 25 Jun 1995, Brian Darkness wrote:

> Dear All
>
> 	Thats the facts; my opinion; the music industry needs something 
> new to talk about, you can only say so much about Courtney Love. The 
> potential is that a part of our scene will be brought into the main 
> stream, which I feel kinda sucks, but that's what happens. It's happened to 
> every music scene I've ever been apart of, it took Punk about 10 years 
> but they finally & unfortuately got there. There is one exception Gothic 
> never made it.

...and straight-edge, and Riot Grrrl ((although those are more cultural/ 
fashion movements than a musical genre)) and ska... for now.

Remember, corporate media exists by exploiting existing forms of youth 
culture and repacking them for mass consumption. One of the reasons being 
that if left with only their own creativity to work with the best that they 
can come up with is Full House and David Hasselhoff. It's so much easier 
to find something that already works on an underground ((less-overground ?)) 
level and rip that off. When flannel and Doc's stop selling, wallet 
chains, Vans, and LeBrets will be found in the "in" section of Rolling 
Stone's 1996 fashion tips ...if they aren't already. 

But when all's said and done, and Arron Spelling is ambulance chasing after 
the next big thing, all the people who invested time and work into their 
respective projects should still be there...in one form or another. 
They are one of the basic reasons why it works in the first place. 

I just stole that sermon from Eddie Blunt.

Bolger

KE>ken@macshasta.com

More information is found at

HTTP://www.loc.gov


SG

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jun 27 02:16:55 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id CAA08587; Tue, 27 Jun 1995 02:16:55 -0700
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id CAA08582; Tue, 27 Jun 1995 02:16:52 -0700
Received: from [198.93.4.214] (sr-tty4-ppp.well.com [198.93.4.214]) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id CAA00611; Tue, 27 Jun 1995 02:16:41 -0700

Date: Tue, 28 Jun 1994 02:18:16 +1000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: Yet another raving weekend
Cc: ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yet another raving weekend
==========================

After the Full moon rave Monday night,   and the Solstice on Wednesday,
I felt like I really needed to get out again,   so according to the SFR
calendar....

   Friday, June 23rd - Frequency 8 - from the Forest to the Fields
   A CyberTrance Journey with Cyr, MysterE and MARS. $2 donation
   requested. Map Point open from 11:30 to 1:30. 415.541.5019

This entry,  from the trusty SFR calendar attracted me because it was
outside,  and DJ Mars was spinning.   Mars plays some really good
trance,  and when I first heard him at Atomica,  he was playing even
harder trance.   Although,  when I returned from Oz,   I notice he has
slowed down by quite a few BPM's.   Some of his music selections are
played in the Australian scene,  are very melodic,  and incredibly
trancy.

Another factor that really made me select this one,  was that it was
outside,  and in Marin county,  where I live.

I call the info line,  and discover it to be very close to Stinson
Beach,  and with a heat wave coming on,   I wanted to be as close to the
Pacific Ocean as I can get,  so I figured this would be a good one.

The Map point had a rather narrow window,   so I waited as long as
possible or my friend Craig to return,  but left without him.   I arrive
at 1:30 am,  just as the map point was about to close.   The trail was
pointed out,   so down I went,  onto this isolated beach,   where I
heard this really good trance music.   I wandered around,   checking out
the area,   but not that many people were there,   but the vibe was
really great.

I estimated about 30 - 40 ppl showed up,  possibly more...  and it
wasn't long before I headed out to the dance area.   Dancing on sand
really wasn't that bad,   once I found the right spot near the speakers.

Mars eventually went on,  and literally spin my brains around in my
head.   Although the energy was low,   IE: slower than his normal BPM's,
Mars played a wonderful set,   except when he played Mr. Tambourine Man
by the Byrds.   I couldn't believe he would stick in such an "Out of
place" song,  but I headed for my blanket,   hoping that the music would
change.    Radion,  another friend with me,  came up and said "Lets go,
I'm really getting bored".   I said,  "lets wait and see what happens".
I keep trying to remember to ask Mars why he played it.

Eventually, the music changed,  and some more brain twisting beats
filled the still air.   It was unusually warm for being on the coast,
which is usually cold and foggy in the summer.

The air was amazingly clear,  and the star light was reflecting on the
ocean,  really made for some awesome visuals.

Although,  not that many people showed up,  this party was really great.
They had good trance,  a really good environment,  and it went on until
about 6:30 am,   well after daylight.

The surprising thing was how they got the generator and sound system
down the steep and rather treacherous hills,   but was well worth it for
a bust-free party.

After the party,  Radion and I went to Bolinas.   For those not familiar
with the area,   Bolinas's claim to fame is it's obscurity.   Those
living there have removed all signs pointing to Bolinas.   Its a small
beach town in Marin,  but with really hip people.   We arrive at 7 am,
and nothing was open,   except a lone worker in a restaurant who sold me
a cup of coffee.

We meet these really strange hippie types and get the lo-down on the
happenings in the area.   Then this truck pulls up and this lady gets
out,  and goes into the restaurant.   She immediately rushes out,
complaining she was assaulted when the worker kicked her out.   She was
in a really bad mood,  but apparently she knows everyone in town.

Radion and I decide to walk around the town via the beach,  and the
morning was incredibly warm and nice.   We made it back to the
restaurant for my traditional pancakes,   then head back down the hiway
through Muir Woods.   Ahhh!!  Just what I need,  a trek through Muir
woods to balance my body.    But as luck would have it,  the Double
Dipsea running race was coming through.   For those out of towners,  the
Dipsea is a run from Mill Valley to Stinson beach.   The Double Dipsea
was a run from Stinson to Mill Valley and BACK.   This is about 18 miles
through rugged hills and valleys,  over logs,  and under branches.
Also,  were the tour busses,   but I managed to find an isolated spot
devoid of people,  where I could stick my feet in the stream and
meditate.   WOW!!  It was really getting hot,  even down in Muir woods.

After about 45 minutes with nature,   I decided to head back to the car,
where Radion was sound asleep and headed back to Mill Valley.   When I
arrived it was blistering hot.   I headed down to the town square to
hang out with the locals,  until I got an idea.   I said "Anyone want to
go to "Three wells".    Everyone around me said YES!!!  lets go..  3
wells is a local secret spot where a water falls down in 3 small,  but
rather deep pools of very cold water.   It is a place where one goes to
get relief from the sizzling heat of a heat wave.   So,  all day
Saturday,   I did my best to stay cool.

That evening,   there were these parties scheduled...

   Saturday, June 24th - Kundalini
   DJs Markie Mark, Garth, Travis, Galen, Tony, Carlos. 415.337.4337
   510.944.7743

   Saturday, June 24th - Funky People Presents: e-Quality
   DJs Rick Preston, Dave Alga, Ryan Tapia and guests. Lasers by Kevin.
   1st 100 people get free cassettes. 408.993.3861 415.773.8916

   Saturday, June 24th - Organic: Tribute
   DJs Cesar (LA), Simon, Emma (DIY), Graeme, Jay-J, Mark Farina. In the
   dub attic: Professor Smith. 9pm-6am, $7, 520 4th St @ Bryant.
   415.266.8215

   Saturday, June 24th- Cyber-Safari Earth Cruise
   -Parallel University Virtual Command Center at Fort Mason
   -Megatripolis Cyber-Safari Party at Big Heart City (836 Mission)
   w/DJs Ethan, Mars, Theta Blip, Cyr and Alex. $8. See web page or call
   415.LAB.2323 for more info.

So,  I decided to go for Megatripolus Cyber-safari,  despite Kundalini's
recent popularity.   Mars Was spinning again,  so I could get more
trance,  and WOW!!  it was wonderful.  The attendance wasn't really that
good,   but the dancing room I had,  more than made up for it.   The
vibe was really good,  and the space (Big Heart City) was really great.

It was scheduled to go until 6 am but the owners decided to pull the
plug at 3 am.   They wouldn't even let the last song play to completion,
and it was one of the best songs Mars was playing.

After it was over,  I took Craig somewhere,  and headed over to Organic.
Organic was at the Troc,  a club famous for turning off the air
conditioner so they could sell more drinks.   It must have been 110
degrees in there,  as I was soaking wet just walking across the dance
floor to the chill area that was even hotter.   People were sitting on
the floor,  soaking wet,  fanning themselves.   About the coolest place
was the front entrance where the door would occasionally open,  letting
in some cool air.   I tried to dance,   but after an evening of good
acid trance,   I didn't enjoy it that much.  Graham was spinning house,
but I at least made an appearance,  saying hi to yet more people who
discovered I was back.

Also,  they were filming this for an MTV show to air sometime in Aug.
It focuses on Herbal Ecstasy and tries very hard to persuade people not
to take drugs.    Oooh!  What a false front they built.   Anyway,  the
Troc was decorated up in really funkey stuff,  all stuck on the walls.
Anyway,   the filming had stopped by the time I arrived (About 3:45 am).
I didn't stay long,   but met a lot of old friends I haven't seen since
I got back.   I left and hung out in SF until later,   then headed back
to 3 wells to sit under the waterfall to cool off.   The heat was very
oppressive,  and the waterfall really felt GREAT!!

Suddenly I realize that Sunset was on,  so I head home to record the
info line,  and learn of it's location and head out there.

It wasn't long before I found it,  and immediately set down my blanket
and started to dance.   As usual,  the very blissful music put me into a
wonderful trance state..  About 2 hours later,   I decide to check out
the area and walk around.   WOW!!  more people than I thought...   Lots
more!!   or in AusSpeak "Heaps more".   Anyway,  despite not sleeping
since Thursday evening,  I danced just about all the time.   It really
wasn't possible to just sit around,   so I kept my schmooze time really
down,  and even schmoosed while dancing.   Met a few more new SFRavers.

9 am finally rolled around,  and the signal for the last tune was given,
so I drop a friend back to SF,  and head for home with a big smile on my
face...   WOW!!   4 raves without sleep....  Yup!!  Summer is here...

Crunchman

	id AA01316; Tue, 27 Jun 95 09:18:19 PDT
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA24992; Tue, 27 Jun 95 09:18:18 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9506271618.AA24992@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: Light Family ritual
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 27 Jun 95 9:23:26 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


150 - 200 of us held hands in a large circle as Galen finished his
set on the longest day of the year.  30 yards away another train
rumbles by and we all cheer.  A few people start dancing in the center
of the circle and then we all charge in, flailing our arms, jumping up &
down, hugging, laughing.  Jason moves the music into the ambient realm and
after a few minutes we start to calm down to sit on the grass dance area.
We move to create a circular clearing and Claire places a firestick at its 
center.  

The Light Family Movement Solstice event was coming to a close.  I whisper
to my companion next to me, "I guess this is the ritual part." I wondered
what kind of slant would be imposed upon us.  A sermon, chants?  Would I have
to play audience to a drumming circle? (I had left my percussion implements 
in the car.)  For me, the rave itself, i.e. the communal dancing, *is* the
ritual.  What more do we need?

We waited to the choral strains of a familiar Global Communications tune.
The stars were coming out.  Most people were silent.  There were a few hoots
and minor displays of personal expression - not everyone was able to fully
let go of their self-focus for this special moment.  But most of us did.

After about 10 minutes, I realized that this *was* a special moment.  There 
was a message here for us that often gets lost on the midst of the party.
We were reflecting, meditating as a group, in simple reverence to our being 
together.  Nothing needed to be said; no symbols, no togas or naked blue
fire dancers.  We were all equal in acknowledging that there was something
important, even serious, about how strangers can come together as one and
feel fundamentally connected to each other.

Someone started playing a digeridoo, and then it was over.  We left the park
passing the three police vans that had just arrived to enforce the peace.

Lee
_______________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com

Typical!  In this society where every single second of every single day 
we are being told how to think, what to do, how to act, what rights we 
are allowed to have and which one's we are not.  And just when it looks 
like we, as a race, are going to be consumed by the evils of Western 
democracy along comes modern technology to save the day.  It created the 
internet, the internet is probably the only place in the world where 
there is true anarchy; where no-one tells one what to think or what not to 
do.  If used correctly, the internet could be responsable, and the 
catalyst for, revoloution.  It is truely one of the freeist thing's on 
this fair planet.  This might sound a bit romantic and nieve (so what?) 
but I really do truely believe this.
and this is why I got so depressed at reading Darknesses mail about the 
need for an internet bill of rights.  All a Bill of Rights does is say to 
the people under it: "yes, we will let you do this, and maybe that, but 
deffinatly not that."  It does not give us greater freedoms it merely 
serves to lull us into a false sense of secrurity so that the powers that 
be can carry on deceiving and lying to us.  Personally, I think that I 
am intelligent enough to be able to decide what I can and and what I can 
not with out a set of rules, or a bunch of men, telling me what to and 
how to think. Remember, the terms regulation suppression are exactly the 
same.
In short, the internet is true anarchy.  We can say anything and there is 
nobody to tell us otherwise.  If we had a bill of rights their is a 
danger that we would loose this.  What are you so scared of Brain?
Tristan.

I like Tristan's statement and agree w/ the sentiment. IMHO, there's no
need for an internet bill of rights because it should be 100% covered
by existing protections provided by the constitution and in particular
"freedom of speech." Any "special" internet bills will just be a way to
slowly regulate it, shut it down, and make it less easy to use for acts
of FREEDOM and SEDITION against oppressive governments. 

The reason why the gummint is running scared is precisely because the
internet, personal publishing, easy and potentially anonymous/secure
communications all allow us to maintain better vigil over our freedoms
and rights, which is  something which the US founding fathers sought
when they formed the US gummint. This of course runs contrary to the
actual practices of our government -- decisions being made behind
closed doors, with "national security" used as a front and a cover
story. That and lobbying/rulemaking done by a clique of moneyed,
well-connected insiders (political action commities, for example) that
attempt to shove laws through before the public finds out what is going
on. The internet cuts through all the guff, at least for the people
vigilant enough, and literate enough to know how to read. However, this
tool will only work for people that care, and are smart enough to
engage their critical abilities, or at least not to be swayed by
Goebbels-like emotion-rich/fact-starved oratory (e.g. Rush Limbaugh).
The price of freedom is eternal vigilance, a terminal/modem, and
$17.50/month to your internet provider.

One can say the same thing about the internet that Arlo Guthrie said
about his guitar: "THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS!" Lets open the floodgates
to all and *DISCUSS*, or *DEBATE*, or whatever. Make FLAMES not BOMBs!

--------------------

However, I do have one nit to pick (as usual) w/ tristan's post:

> am intelligent enough to be able to decide what I can and and what I can 
> not with out a set of rules, or a bunch of men, telling me what to and 
> how to think. Remember, the terms regulation suppression are exactly the 
> same.

Actually, it's not just a bunch of men. Can you say Dianne Feinstein, 
Ms.-internet-censorship-because-there's-crazy-internet-anarchists-out-there-
telling-people-how-to-build bombs? That and "we're doing it for the
children..." What a load of hooey.

D.F. is one person who I'll never vote for again... please consider her
recent record on these sorts of things the next time an election comes
up.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

>

>
>and i woke at 2.00 PM Sunday with a raging sound in my ears,
>was last night real?
>Hey, you may well ask.
>The VORTEX RAVE is over, and yeh, it was REAL man,
>It was like being back at the 'Paradiso Club' in Amsterdam in 1971, cept the

>dubious content, yeh, but we were all on 'One Mission' man, and to  those
>dedicated to delivering the electronic ecstasy to all the rest of us,
>a 'BIG THANK YOU' to Freddie, Paul, Ron and the Telkom technicians who
>ensured that the forward headspace was inhabited by positive signs,
>yeh, sooo much to tell ya, Paul set up Brain machines in a special room
>where mind altering frequencies were piped into minds already altered by the
>'mood occasion', then there were the video walls by Ron, hell, some of those
>light tunnels went on forever, morphing from one reality into another,
>blending, mixing, changing, sides all THAT there were TV and video crews
>roaming in and out of the zoned crowds and thanks to Rees and the boys
>for THAT one, yeh, we pumped Frisco with Rave al la AFRICA, cutting back to
>the on-line video conference every now and then for more live time
>mingling, and yeh, brothers and sisters across THAT ocean, we saw your LOVE
>man, There was the added excitement of having David Dei's sister as part of
>the video conference. She had not seen her brother for two years and was now
>checking him out live over an ISDN line,
>hey, it was a real BLAST man, and everyone was really WHIGGED 'n all, and
>there were jugglers with live fire that were doin some incredible things
>and all you could see were lasers and fireballs of real flame, double hectic
>man, oh, i nearly forgot the VR kits that they had set up where you could
>play HERETIC through a VR interface and people were goin off in all
>directions Guess that bout does it, oh, a big thanks to all those amazing
>girls in
>hot pants and long blonde hair cruisin and struttin,
>and we even went live on the I-NET for an hour
>when yours truly attempted to get on IRC and let em all know bout the
>fact that we really THERE, funny thing is though, no one would believe that
>i was typing directly from a rave and i s'pose that was the most
>disappointing part of the evening, still, i said i was gonna be doin it, and
>i did......and there's always next time, eh?
>so i might fold this column for a bit cos no one is PAYING me, and i know
>how some of those people felt last nite cos it was like WORK for them and no
>one was scanning the fact that we were busy CREATING out there, and so what
>we need are some entertainment $'s to start flowing, so c'mon all you suits
>out there, join us,
>This is Africa man,
>Its FUN man.....
>
>
>schwann-cyber-raver
>
>

       415 LAB 2323 - http://www.megatripolis.org/safari.html
                    Parallel University - Planet Earth Crew

At 8:47 PM 6/26/95, Derek Oliver wrote:
>On Mon, 26 Jun 1995, MIKE BOLGER wrote:

>> Remember, corporate media exists by exploiting existing forms of youth
>> culture and repacking them for mass consumption. One of the reasons being
>> that if left with only their own creativity to work with the best that they
>> can come up with is Full House and David Hasselhoff.
>It's so much easier
>> to find something that already works on an underground ((less-overground ?))
>> level and rip that off. When flannel and Doc's stop selling, wallet
>> chains, Vans, and LeBrets will be found in the "in" section of Rolling
>> Stone's 1996 fashion tips ...if they aren't already.
>>
>> But when all's said and done, and Arron Spelling is ambulance chasing after
>> the next big thing, all the people who invested time and work into their
>> respective projects should still be there...in one form or another.
>> They are one of the basic reasons why it works in the first place.
>>
>> I just stole that sermon from Eddie Blunt.
>>
>> Bolger

        Word! I think, though that one of the things that the 'rave' scene
has going for it is it's realization that it's not in the 'business' (i
know, i know, bad choice of words) in making something 'original' nor
'subversive' as punk was trying to do (that is, punk was making points
about originality being a sham, that anyone could do it, etc) and, if one
follows what the situationists have written about advanced capitalism,
commodity exchange and 'recuperation' [which was their term for the
capturing, repackaging a re-selling of 'rebellious' counter-culture
movements, ie: grunge wear (tm) (i've seen this, seriously!)].  Anyways,
that wasn't really a sentance but what i'm trying to say is that the only
way (according to the situationists in the 60's) that one could escape
recuperation was through detournement (roughly translated as: mischeivious
detour) which is taking ALREADY recuperated signs (such as corporate logos,
corporate music, etc) and recontextualizing them to serve an ironic
purpose, Negativland is a perfect example of this, as are those oldskool
"united colours of tripping" or "high" (instead of Tide) shirts...
        i think that the thing that enables 'rave' culture not to be
'recuperated' is that it's pretty amorphous, and it doesn't really have any
sort of agenda as other movements have had.  We're not really fighting
'against' anything, we just want to dance ;) and if we overthrow the ruling
order in the process then that's cool too ;)
        peace,
                brad

ps-->who's eddie blunt?
