CyberWire Dispatch // Copyright (c) 1995 //


Jacking in from the "Damn the Torpedoes" Port:

Washington, DC -- A posse of top House Republicans are riding into
Cyberspace wearing White Hats and riding a horse called the First
Amendment.  

Rep. Chris Cox (R-Calif.), chairman of the Republican Policy Committee, is
readying a bill that would prohibit the government from placing any
regulations on content in Cyberspace.  According to a draft of the bill
obtained by Dispatch, even the guerilla war on the First Amendment now
being waged in Statehouses throughout the nation would be thwarted.  Cox's
bill, which he plans to co-sponsor with Rep. Ron Wyden (D-Ore.) would
preempt state laws that now restrict content. 

Meanwhile, Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich has gone into full-scale
"Marshall Dillon" mode, assailing attempts by the Senate to curb
pornography on the Internet by means of the Exon/Coats amendment, which
passed as part of the Senate's telecommunications reform package.  
Gingrich, speaking Tuesday night (July 20) on his weekly "Progress Report"
cable program, said the Exon/Coats amendment was "very badly thought-out."

Civil libertarian groups have already blasted the Exon/Coats amendment,
calling it unconstitutional along several points.  The Electronic Frontier
Foundation and the Center for Democracy and Technology have issued detailed
section summaries of the bill.  Both rip into the amendment along legal
lines, carving out its huge constitutional flaws with the force of a chain
saw.

Gringrich, not short on candor himself, minced no words denouncing the the
Exon/Coats provision, calling it "a violation of free speech."  He said the
move by Exon would have "no real impact" and was merely a political ploy,
which would give all 84 Senators that supported the amendment "a good press
release back home."

Rep. Cox said government should "stay out" of trying to regulate the
electronic arena.  Instead, he favors industry solutions and guidelines.  
He said the Exon/Coats amendment, combined with the recent court case that
hammered Prodigy in a libel case, sends the message that online services
shouldn't even try to deal with objectionable material.  "What service is
going to want to risk trying to police [content] on their system?"  Cox
said, "if all they get in return is a lawsuit?"  

Cox is even opposed to the government mandating some kind of blocking or
filtering technology.  He wants a hands-off approach for fear that
government intrusion would only "act as a drag on progress."

Gingrich accused the Senate of punting on a "serious issue which is how do
you maintain right of free speech for adults while also protecting children
in a medium which is available to both."  His comments are ironic:  
During
the Senate debate on the telecom reform bill, Sen. James Exon (D-Neb.) 
said
that a proposed substitute amendment to his bill, offered by Sen. 
Patrick
Leahy (D-Vt.), was "nothing more than a punt."  Leahy's amendment would
have called on the Justice Department to first study the problem of
objectionable material on the Internet before rushing in with any
legislation.

The House is due to began debate on its own version of 
telecommunications
reform within the next few weeks.  The House bill has a version of the
Leahy amendment already in place.  There is currently no one offering 
an
Exon/Coats clone amendment.  But someone is almost certain to bring it 
up,
House congressional staffers say.  

What happens if the Cox-Gingrich posse runs into the Exon/Coats crowd?  
"As
Chairman of the Republication Policy Committee, I would vigorously 
fight
that," Cox said, setting the stage for the Cyberspace equivalent of the
shoot-out at the OK Corral.

Meeks out...

I know its off the subject a little but some things just need to be said.
Last night a couple of very beutiful ravers as well as my wife went to a
protest for Mumiam Abu Jamal who is schedualed to be executed in August. At
the protest a couple of people lit a dumpster on fire but that was the
extent of the disruption what followed was obcene to say the least.  The
police followed the protesters and then barred their exit. and started
beating people as well as arresting people.  My wife told me she was
watching the woman in front of her getting beaten by the cops and she
thought she was next. Luckily someone dragged her into a lawyers house just
to the side. The cops tried to follow and arrest the people in the house
but the owner/lawyer shouted out that the cops could not come in. So she
waited four hours as all of the deomonstraters were arrested and quite a
few were beaten. She saw someone with a video camera have it taken out of
their hand and smashed by a cop, then the cop beath the protester and
dragged him away. Police brutality is real. Those cops terrified and
arrested 300 people like it or not. It happened. I held my wife in my arms
as she wept with fear and frustration. ALso the papers made it look like
the protesters were violent and looking for trouble, but my wife told me
that before the cops tore into the crowd they had been chanting "peace,
police, peace". It did not stop them. This relates to raves because if
raves become big enough to be perceived as a threat the same thing will
happen to ravers that happened last night to the demonstrators. So I would
suggest that people educate themselves about the police.

LOVE,
GABE

PS-They is a protest tonight in the city to demand the realese of the
protesters at something called the epicenter in the city. Also you can call
the SF DA at (415) 553-1752 and tell them to release the prisoners.

of any interest and any response to this message will result in another bounce.
So don't bother.

From: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham)
Subject: BSP Length/Content
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi Everyone,
I am wondering how the rest of you feel about BSPs (blatant self promotions
a.k.a advertisements)?  Why do I ask?  It seems recently there have been a 
few BSPs sent to sfraves that are, well, excessive.  I am not against BSPs,
in general, because they usually have information that interests me.  But, 
it would be nice if people posting BSPs could maybe do the following:

    1)  Identify it as a BSP in the subject line - That way people 
        who don't like BSPs can just delete them.  An example might
        look like:
        	Subject:  BSP - It's My Party...

    2)  Make them short and sweet - Use only 4 maybe 5 lines max to
        tell use what you're doing, why you're doing it, where you
        are doing it, what DJs are playing, etc.

    3)  Tell us how to get more information - Include an email address 
        or web page address where we can obtain all the details *if*
	we are interested.

Maybe something like this is already the policy on this mailing list.  If
so, please pardon the use of the bandwidth.  Otherwise, can we come to some
agreement about what is appropriate and what is not?  In this way, we might
be able to avoid some ruffled feathers in the future.

Thanks,

Bradley

.sig

"Living on the other side of the world is not an excuse for ignorance"

bondsman.

> 
> I know its off the subject a little but some things just need to be said.
> Last night a couple of very beutiful ravers as well as my wife went to a
> protest for Mumiam Abu Jamal who is schedualed to be executed in August. At
> the protest a couple of people lit a dumpster on fire but that was the
> extent of the disruption what followed was obcene to say the least.  The
> police followed the protesters and then barred their exit. and started
> beating people as well as arresting people.  My wife told me she was
> watching the woman in front of her getting beaten by the cops and she
> thought she was next. Luckily someone dragged her into a lawyers house just
> to the side. The cops tried to follow and arrest the people in the house
> but the owner/lawyer shouted out that the cops could not come in. So she
> waited four hours as all of the deomonstraters were arrested and quite a
> few were beaten. She saw someone with a video camera have it taken out of
> their hand and smashed by a cop, then the cop beath the protester and
> dragged him away. Police brutality is real. Those cops terrified and
> arrested 300 people like it or not. It happened. I held my wife in my arms
> as she wept with fear and frustration. ALso the papers made it look like
> the protesters were violent and looking for trouble, but my wife told me
> that before the cops tore into the crowd they had been chanting "peace,
> police, peace". It did not stop them. This relates to raves because if
> raves become big enough to be perceived as a threat the same thing will
> happen to ravers that happened last night to the demonstrators. So I would
> suggest that people educate themselves about the police.
>

Namaste sfraves!

    After an incredible and beautifully intense year in India and 
Nepal, here I am, back home, back in the old U.S. of A, and back on the 
net.  Hopefully some of you still remember me, I was a member of sfraves for 
about 2 years, and had the privelege of playing at the very first Friends 
and Family and hosting another sfraves party at my apartment in Berkeley.
I spent far too much money on records in London on my way home, so I'm 
ready to jump back into the expensive hobby of "wannabe" dj.  I should 
soon be back on KALX 90.7fm Berkeley, teaming up with dj Minor to help 
this station become a kinder and gentler place for electronic music.  
Stay tuned for details...
     By the way, I was able to experience the Goa rave scene for X-mas 
and New Year's, and if I get motivated, I'll post a descriptive account- 
basically, it was disappointing music-wise (high nrg techno on DAT only), 
but you gotta love being on a tropical beach on the southwest coast of 
India surrounded by thousands of drugged and displaced Europeans.  Let me 
just say it was interesting...
     If anyone else has been to Goa in the past, I'd love to hear about 
your experiences (has Goa ever been mentioned on this list?).  Drop me a 
line...

Acid always,
Seth

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jun 28 00:48:53 1995

From: Peter Fogel <peterf@netcom.com>
Subject: new moon
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9506280013.A12105-0100000@netcom7>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Just got back from the new moon party.  If your thinking of going, you 
might want to wait a while and listen to the recording to see if its 
being relocated.
As I was still in the parking lot, a cop car pulled up with his spot 
light on us.  Asked if there was a party, and warned us about how 
dangerous it is there.  Said people get shot all the time, and as a 
matter of fact he got shot there last year.
We told him we were just going to hang out with some friends.  As we were 
standing there a couple more cop cars came.  The cop told us to go home, 
and that they were going to drive in and break up whatever was going on.
Hung around for a short while watching the cop cars drive around in the 
distance trying to find the party.  When I heard the bull horn and 
spotted another cop car entering the parking lot, I felt it was time to 
leave.
I guess its still possible they might have talked the cops into letting 
the party continue.  Oh well, guess I'll just wait til organic in the 
park to shake it up a bit.

:)
peter

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Frequency 8 Kicks!
Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 01:28:20 -0700

Message-Id: <kE87vwEOwW/f084yn@crl.com>

I agree, the Frequency 8 folks put on an AWESOME outdoor.

I'm am suitably impressed with the amount of heavy shit they dragged into
the forest a few weeks ago and onto the Red Rock beach last friday night.
Turntables, 4 speaker stacks, generator, lights, amps, etc.  Some of those
pieces take two people to manuever and its a narrow trail.

We aren't talking about any ordinary renegade here!!!

And the TRANCE, if you are a trance junkie like I am, is extremely fresh.
Frequence 8 is the bay area distributer for some german label, so at least I
know where I'm going to buy all my CD's from.  MARS made the point of saying
that it wasn't just any old trance, it was cosmic trance.  It's more melodic
and complex than Goan trance for example (though I like Goan).

The Red Rock sight was a dangerous walk EVEN WITH A FLASHLIGHT. Unlike the
forest rave, there was no full moon to illuminate the steep and windy trail.
IF YOU ARE A SERIOUS RAVER, ADD A PENLIGHT TO YOUR ESSENTIAL EQUIPAGE.  It's
stupid not to have a 'light.

Fortunately, no one fell to their deaths.  It certainly helped that the
stars were as thick as milk that night.  I hadn't seen stars that beautilful
since the new moon at goat rock, or maybe Burning Man '94.


Ciao,

PT

--
< Purple Tiger (ptiger@crl.com) >
     Kale and Eggplant pizza, that's something you don't see everyday.

On Tue, 27 Jun 1995, Gabe wrote:

> Hey everyone.
> 
> I was just hanging out thinking about MTV filming at Organic. I was
> wondering what people think about the effect this could have on the raves
> here. Personally it kinda scares me. Its hard for me to articulate it right
> now and I was just curious what other people would say.
> 
> Love,
> GABE
> 
> 
I seem to remember this sort of thing happening in 1992-93 as well - I think 
a couple parties were filmed for news shows, a documentary on LSD, 
maybe something on those crazy ravin' kids. Does anyone else recall this too?
My sense is that most party attendees pretty much ignored the media 
types, and pretty soon they went away (after filing fairly shallow and 
sensationalistic stories). I don't think there was much lingering effect 
on the scene, but then it wasn't the glorious MTV either...

Peace, and smile for the cameras :)
Kathryn

building on the hill. They probably immediately spotted something out of 
the ordinary (ie. more people than usual for this time of the night, 
walking in the shadows, *trying* to look inconscpicuous) and alerted the 
local police. I don't think we need to look much further.

From: blkadder@central.soma.net (Black Adder)
Subject: Re: BSP Length/Content
To: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham)
Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 11:42:21 -0700 (PDT)
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1835      

> 
> 
> Hi Everyone,
> I am wondering how the rest of you feel about BSPs (blatant self promotions
> a.k.a advertisements)?  Why do I ask?  It seems recently there have been a 
> few BSPs sent to sfraves that are, well, excessive.  I am not against BSPs,
> in general, because they usually have information that interests me.  But, 
> it would be nice if people posting BSPs could maybe do the following:
> 
>     1)  Identify it as a BSP in the subject line - That way people 
>         who don't like BSPs can just delete them.  An example might
>         look like:
>         	Subject:  BSP - It's My Party...
> 
>     2)  Make them short and sweet - Use only 4 maybe 5 lines max to
>         tell use what you're doing, why you're doing it, where you
>         are doing it, what DJs are playing, etc.
> 
>     3)  Tell us how to get more information - Include an email address 
>         or web page address where we can obtain all the details *if*
> 	we are interested.
> 
> Maybe something like this is already the policy on this mailing list.  If
> so, please pardon the use of the bandwidth.  Otherwise, can we come to some
> agreement about what is appropriate and what is not?  In this way, we might
> be able to avoid some ruffled feathers in the future.
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Bradley
> 
> .sig
> 
> "Living on the other side of the world is not an excuse for ignorance"

I think you are absolutely correct. I like to know when, who, and where I can
get more info, a format which virtually everyone I have seen post here has
adhered to, with one notable exception that I can think of.

Two and three page BSP's followed by glowing reviews forwarded from other
places by members of the production company amount to little more than 
electronic masturbation. 

                                                    Black Adder

Let me see if I have got this straight.  MTV are going to be filming at 
the Organic rave?  I wonder if Diasy Ferris (or what ever her name is, 
all those bimbos look alike to me) is going to be their and if some one 
would be good enough to spike her drink with LSD because she deffinatly 
needs to lighten up!
No wonder Organic got a permit so easily for this 
party.  And so, I take it, that people feel weired about MTV being their 
because they feel that it will be the beging of the end for rave music in 
just the same way that MTV brought about the beginging of the end of 
great soul/funk music.  Well you are absoloutly right.  And yes, we 
should all be wearing "MTV" sucks shirts.  But if it means that hard 
working people who are dedicated to the cause such as Mark and Tracy (to 
mane but a few) get the publicity and recognition they deserve because of 
it then I am all in favour of  it.
We do not need MTV.  All they understand is monery And comercialism and 
these have no place in rave culture.  But a lot of young people watch MTV 
and my motto has alwyas been start them young.  If by MTV filming the 
rave a bunch of people think "wow that's looks fun, I'd to to go to one 
of those rave thing's" then this is all well and good.  Remember: MTV has 
not ruined popular music but the money ascoiated with them, together with 
the ignorance of the average MTV viewer have.  People should make up 
their own minds and maybe them seeing it on TV may, I repeat may, act as 
a catalyst.  Having said that, however, it is probably just wishful 
thinking on my part.  Still, if it means that their is a chance of me 
chatting up that Daisy what-ever-her-name-is bird I'm all in favour of it.

See ya!
Tristan.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun 29 09:19:14 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA04754; Thu, 29 Jun 1995 09:19:14 -0700

Subject: Re: San Diego raves.
To: "JBARONE.US.ORACLE.COM" <JBARONE@us.oracle.com>
Cc: "sfraves* " <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, "Flux Television" <flux@netcom.com>
X-Mailer: Mail*Link SMTP-QM 3.0.2
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Reply to:   RE>San Diego raves.

John ..
When you're in San Diego, call the Static Line @ 619.685.8449, they usually mention all the cool underground things that are happening.  Also, stop by the San Diego (original) branch of Behind The Post Office which is downtown at the corner of  8th and G, they usually have tons of fliers.  Be sure to ask for a copy of the free "Mappy" map which they just put out with Bill from Oricom Technologies.  It lists every cool record and clothing store, cheap hipster restaraunt, etc, in downtown San Diego (there's more than you would think).
A couple of more things, after hours (2AM on) on Saturday night there's a pretty cool club called Romper Room which is at the corner of Sixth and Market.  It's always a lot of fun but it seems to be a little more happening on the alternating weeks when Mark E. Quark is DJing.  He's one of the best djs I've ever heard.  There's also a free thing in the park every Sunday afternoon that's lots of fun.
I used to throw underground parties in San Diego a long time ago so if you need any more info about anything, give me a call @ 415.626.6223.  

--------------------------------------

> all those bimbos look alike to me) is going to be their and if some one 
> would be good enough to spike her drink with LSD because she deffinatly 
> needs to lighten up!
> No wonder Organic got a permit so easily for this 
> party.  And so, I take it, that people feel weired about MTV being their 
> because they feel that it will be the beging of the end for rave music in 
> just the same way that MTV brought about the beginging of the end of 
> great soul/funk music.  Well you are absoloutly right.  And yes, we 
> should all be wearing "MTV" sucks shirts.  But if it means that hard 
> working people who are dedicated to the cause such as Mark and Tracy (to 
> mane but a few) get the publicity and recognition they deserve because of 
> it then I am all in favour of  it.
> We do not need MTV.  All they understand is monery And comercialism and 
> these have no place in rave culture.  But a lot of young people watch MTV 
> and my motto has alwyas been start them young.  If by MTV filming the 
> rave a bunch of people think "wow that's looks fun, I'd to to go to one 
> of those rave thing's" then this is all well and good.  Remember: MTV has 
> not ruined popular music but the money ascoiated with them, together with 
> the ignorance of the average MTV viewer have.  People should make up 
> their own minds and maybe them seeing it on TV may, I repeat may, act as 
> a catalyst.  Having said that, however, it is probably just wishful 
> thinking on my part.  Still, if it means that their is a chance of me 
> chatting up that Daisy what-ever-her-name-is bird I'm all in favour of it.
> 
> See ya!
> Tristan.
> 

IS THE WORLD COMING TO AN END?!?!?

For once I find myself in almost total agreeance with you Tristan.

The only thing I doubt is that MTV's piece would be in any way related
to reality, seeing how MTV likes to put a spin on their so-called "news", and
would probably do all the wonderful people in the scene much more of a 
disservice than a service.

Boo MTV.... Yea chatting up Daisy.... >:)

I have mixed feelings about the mtv thing.  I definitely don't think it 
has to be a bad thing.  I don't think we have to send them bad get out of 
here vibes while they are there.
I think they will only ruin the scene if we as a group allow ourselves to 
buy into their interpetation of it, should it be different from our 
understanding of it that makes it so special to us all.
The energy we have as a group can remain to be the shared joy that it 
is, if we continue to emphasize and share the vibe within ourselves and to 
each other. 
Yes, mtv can be a major distraction, like many other things are to the 
experience of the beautiful shared vibe.  Once we experience the vibe 
through our sharing, those distractions become secondary and can be part of 
the vibe.
I think listening to the incredible music, and sharing the feelings from 
the music will take me to a place where mtv won't be an annoying distraction.
With the help of the music, we can let our vibe continue in the future no 
matter what mtv does.  We always have the underground.

:)
peter

peter says:
>  I don't think we have to send them bad get out of 
> here vibes while they are there.

I agree, but then I also think we should be nice to cops when they come 
to check us out or even bust us.  Y'know, that silly PLUR thing.  Doesn't 
mean we should help them with their agenda. 

The Rave scene is already being exploited and commercialized - the Herbal E 
dealers come to mind as the most blatant.  Actually, MTV has been kinda slow 
in the rave exploitation department.  They probably haven't figured out how 
yet.  Ravers don't watch much TV.  MTV viewers who discover raves might
suddenly become bored with MTV.  But raves are too cool for MTV to dis.  What 
should MTV do?  I almost feel sorry for them.

Speaking of commercialism, we had a wonderful time at Freedom last year
despite it being a holiday weekend, permitted, aboveground, big, etc.
Just got the mailing; Galen & Doran have been added, Mark Farina
dropped.   They plan some kind of circle ceremony at sunset then music
from 9pm to 9am.  Also, and I quote:

"Organic food will be served all night, free water for the thirsty,
friends for the lonely,
ambientorganicjunglebuzzwordhybridinternetdemographicbandwagonbreakfast
for the hungry, what more could you ask for?"

That made me smile.  Martin parties have usually been good at straddling
the fence between big production commercialism and the vibey 
underground.  At the very least, we're gonna get Big Sound, Good DJs, 
and a legal outdoor location.  Janie & I hope to see you all there.

Lee

I think that wearing "MTV Sucks" t-shirts is knuckling under to the idea
of MTV as an all-powerful empire of taste, and gives them just as much
exposure as "MTV Rocks" shirts would.  Someone once said "There's no
such thing as negative publicity", and they're right.  Beavis and Butthead
show that MTV is not afraid to poke fun at itself, and unless EVERYONE at
the rave had one, they'll likely interview someone with the "Sucks" shirt,
quote them out of context, and make them look like an idiot.

The easiest way to guarantee non-exposure is to use lots of the Seven (or
eight, or whatever) words you can't use on TV.  The best way is to weird
them out so totally that they can't process you.  "Last time they set a
live goat on fire, and it was running around and bleating and shit, and
we tried to put it out with our smart drinks except they were all laced
with acid and it freaked out and bit me on the nipple.  Want to see the
scar?"

Or, just be honest.  The ultra-hip calculated cynicism of the MTV crowd
has a hard time dealing with love and unity without smirking.

And, my advice; some DONT'S.
1) DON'T talk about drugs.  If you're asked, say something like, "Well, 
that's why they have all the lights and posters and pretty stuff, so 
you don't have to take drugs to have a good time."  Or, "Television is
a drug, raving is an anti-drug."  Or, "Sure, but there are a lot more
fucked-up people in the average bar."  The last thing we need is a bunch
more naive kids trying to use raves as a place to score.

2) DON'T talk about locations used for underground stuff.  The Bonny Doon
disaster should teach us that lesson -- the scene will lose the location
permanently.

The more energy we spend fighting them, the more control they have over our
lives, just as if we were the mindless consumers we all deride.

// g

From: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham)
Subject: Re: mtv thing
To: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Lee wrote: 

>> Actually, MTV has been kinda slow in the rave exploitation department.
>> They probably haven't figured out how yet.

Yes, MTV has been kind of slow in picking up on raves.  That's because they
are still exploiting the spring break party in florida with the bikini
clad babes and the frat boys scene still.  Ugh.  Once that gets boring they'll
be on to something new.  BTW, since MTV's Real World (what garbage) is moving
from SF to London, they may try to work in a rave angle.  It might be a good
way to test market the salability of raves without making a big investment in 
a special production.  Never know, huh!!! 

>> MTV viewers who discover raves might suddenly become bored with MTV.

Sheesh, I got bored with MTV when I found out they played the same videos
over and over and over and over and over again.  Maybe it took me 1.5 days
to realize that (not nonstop viewing!).  But some people like seeing repeats.
That's why they get away with it.

>> But raves are too cool for MTV to dis.

Rule #2: Never dis what you can make money from.  Raves are just on the
waiting list for MTV and general commercialization.  Actually it's already
here.  Look at nickelodean, they use techno as the background music for 
many of their own ad spots.  You can even find it on non-cable stations, 
too.  Someday the international house of pancakes will fire that bonehead 
they currently use in their commercials and instead they'll use hungry 
ravers groovin to techno.  :>)  What an icky thought.

>> What should MTV do?  I almost feel sorry for them.

Rule #3:  Never feel sorry for a company.  It doesn't feel sorry for you
so why should you feel sorry for a company.  Not to mention the fact that
companies don't have feelings.  :>)  Anyway, I could never feel sorry for
the people at MTV because of their programming.  Look at the trash they 
air like Beavis and Butthead.  MTV promotes senseless violence, destruction 
of property, and illwill between people.  If you have ever seen MTV
international, you'll know that it is even worse.  Between video sets they 
play these shorts that are always violent, usually misogynous, and most of 
all pointless.  Most insulting is that they try to mitigate the impact of 
this rubbish by doing trendy public affairs specials (such as teenage sex,
aids, etc.).

In spite of all this, there's no need to be mean or rude to the MTV crew that
comes around.  That's detrimental to the image we are trying to promote.  We
just need to be confident and strong in order to keep evolving the scene in
the direction we, as caring participants, choose.  This way, we'll keep it 
from being corrupted or exploited by MTV and the others.

Peace and Positivity,

Bradley

.sig

"Rule #1:  Life's not fair"

>I think that wearing "MTV Sucks" t-shirts is knuckling under to the idea
>of MTV as an all-powerful empire of taste, and gives them just as much
>exposure as "MTV Rocks" shirts would.  Someone once said "There's no
>such thing as negative publicity", and they're right.  Beavis and Butthead
>show that MTV is not afraid to poke fun at itself, and unless EVERYONE at
>the rave had one, they'll likely interview someone with the "Sucks" shirt,
>quote them out of context, and make them look like an idiot.
>
>The easiest way to guarantee non-exposure is to use lots of the Seven (or
>eight, or whatever) words you can't use on TV.  The best way is to weird
>them out so totally that they can't process you.  "Last time they set a
>live goat on fire, and it was running around and bleating and shit, and
>we tried to put it out with our smart drinks except they were all laced
>with acid and it freaked out and bit me on the nipple.  Want to see the
>scar?"

You hit the nail on the head.

>Or, just be honest.  The ultra-hip calculated cynicism of the MTV crowd
>has a hard time dealing with love and unity without smirking.
>
>And, my advice; some DONT'S.
>1) DON'T talk about drugs.  If you're asked, say something like, "Well,
>that's why they have all the lights and posters and pretty stuff, so
>you don't have to take drugs to have a good time."  Or, "Television is
>a drug, raving is an anti-drug."  Or, "Sure, but there are a lot more
>fucked-up people in the average bar."  The last thing we need is a bunch
>more naive kids trying to use raves as a place to score.

I don't know about the drug thing.. Drugs never hurt the reputation of
rock-n-roll..

jon

Subject: This Week's SFR Calendar!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SF Raves)
Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 14:29:42 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves-calendar@hyperreal.com (SFR Calendar)

Precedence: bulk


   Each year, the Fourth of July brings fireworks, nationalism and
   massive parties. The Gathering returns for the 4th annual Freedom
   party with a good lineup and a guaranteed crowd. Nation is dropping
   some big names as well - Sasha, CJ Mackintosh and the Masters at Work.
   For a lot less dough, check out the free Organic in the park on
   Saturday, Sunset on Sunday, and the Frequency 8 picnic at Stinson 
   Beach on Tuesday.   Finally, Come-Unity should be large again - 
   this time, please arrive _after_ me, so I don't have to wait in line
   behind you ;-)
   

                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html
    
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, June 30th - All Together Now
   DJ Dan, Graeme, Tony, Das, and Keli. 415.281.9923 408.271.7104

   others. Golden Gate Park Bandshell, free.

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * the Global Party Network Buzzline - 415.568.1338
     * The Gruv Line - (415) 331-1583 Ext. GRUV(4788)
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA23030; Thu, 29 Jun 1995 14:32:57 -0700
Received: from ix7.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA23021; Thu, 29 Jun 1995 14:32:54 -0700
Received: from  by ix7.ix.netcom.com (8.6.12/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id OAA20640; Thu, 29 Jun 1995 14:31:18 -0700
Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 14:31:18 -0700
Message-Id: <199506292131.OAA20640@ix7.ix.netcom.com>
From: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham)
Subject: repetitive/redundant music (was re: mtv thing)
To: bmcgonig@pacific.abbotthpd.com (Brian McGonigle)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Brian wrote: 
>
>bradley sed :
>> 
>> Sheesh, I got bored with MTV when I found out they played the same videos
>> over and over and over and over and over again.
>
>
>Insert "music" for "videos" above and that's what many non-ravers say about 
us 
>
>:) 
>
>hugz
>
>

Hehehehe.  You're absolutely right about that.  But, that is truly
characteristic of the music industry, don't you think.  What about those
bands in the late 50's and early 60's (even the Beatles) who released 
several songs that were almost exactly the same.  If it weren't for some
changes in the words, they would be identical!  How could that be, especially
at a time when there were so many new areas of music to explore (not that 
there still aren't) and competition wasn't as intense.  After all, there 
weren't 10 million different people trying to write the next #1 song like 
we have now?  

Actually, this phenomenon pervades all segments of the music industry.  I
begin to can't count the number of modern rock or hip hop songs that are
simply a repackaging of earlier works.  105.3 FM in SF is playing a song 
about underwear or something that sounds exactly the same as that song 
called Creep that was released a couple of years ago.  I was going crazy a 
year or so ago when there was a big trend to cover 60's and 70's songs. 
Everyone was doing it.  After a while it got very old and seemed as though 
there was a severe lack of creativity and profound amount laziness (make 
big money with the minimum possible investment).  Fortunately this all comes 
in cycles!  I must say, though, it made me appreciate the fresh little jewels 
hidden amongst the recycled material even more. 

Basically, except for isolated cases of real innovation, everything is a
variation on a theme.  That's why we have coke, diet coke, caffiene free
coke, and caffiene free diet coke.  Now you can have all of the above in
both cans and the old style bottles.  :>)  

Bradley

.sig

"marketing, you gotta love it!"

So far my experience at the hands of Sfravers has been pretty unpleasant.

 A bad taste is left in my throat by those members of this community that
have gone out of their way to tarbrush and ignore reality instead direcingt
fear and loathing towards myself. The merest step or mistep is greeted with
the rabid glee of vultures wanting nothing more than to discredit the
internationalist posse in the rave movement. How for example, do I explain
to this cynical mindset that in Africa the average number of telephone
calls made per year is TEN (10) and that merely having conversation over
the internet with people from this forgotten continent is a miracle. People
like Mr Adder are so jaded by their smug west coast connectivity that they
are neither impressed nor surprised when I and a team of committed ravers
pulled off an interactive video link to a Rave in Woodstock, Cape Town. And
then they have the gumption to describe the entire event as a  mere
promotion, a mere money grabbing example of greed. COME ON - I don't think
anyone would go without sleep for days (pandering to different time zones)
to establish this connection for MONEY,, there are easier ways to make cash
- like simply hiring a massive venue in Oakland like Cool World or Funky
Techno.

These efforts at connecting the world in the face of great odds, seem
wasted when all we have to offer the expectant masses in the Southern
Hemishere, are the likes of Mr Adder and his clan of proto-punk would be
gothic ravers dancing in the mire of a miserable America. What on earth has
bitten you so hard that you cannot dream of fun beyond the inevitalbe norm
of 2 by 4 raving?

As anterro alli says " imagination death precedes loss of soul"

- david dei

       CyberSafari Earth Cruise - Africa & America Wiring
       415 LAB 2323 - http://www.megatripolis.org/safari.html
                    Parallel University - Planet Earth Crew
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun 29 16:33:51 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA29870; Thu, 29 Jun 1995 16:33:51 -0700
Received: from mail04.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA29844; Thu, 29 Jun 1995 16:33:46 -0700

	(1.37.109.11/16.2) id AA003048794; Thu, 29 Jun 1995 19:33:14 -0400
Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 19:33:14 -0400

Subject: The real mtv thing
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

In a message dated 95-06-29 13:57:13 EDT, you write:

>The Rave scene is already being exploited and commercialized - the Herbal E 
>dealers come to mind as the most blatant.  Actually, MTV has been kinda slow

>in the rave exploitation department.  They probably haven't figured out how 
>yet.

I'm just trying to figure out what level of "mainstream" people here are
trying to come to terms with. MTV has been documenting raves for at least 5
years. This is an important point, since MTV has been in the scene longer
than most of the hardcore, because they've been around filming and
interviewing all the while. Whether it was at the crappy clubs or talking to
the right people is besides the point because it's all part of the house
music scene, albeit focusing on the mainsteam aspects. This is what they do.
The angst I sense around here has little to do with corporate forces
permeating the scene and a lot to do with the ideas that a party you percieve
as being underground actually isn't, and that anyone interviewed would
invariably misrepresent the scene. The facts are that these are the people
going to these parties, and this is exactly what MTV is after. Even more
disgusting are the suggestions of excluding MTV from an open (?) scene and
rules of what (and what not) to talk about to the cameras.

The house scene has been stalled for quite awhile now but y'all been having
too much fun to notice MTV catching up. The underground part moved on long
ago - you don't see cameras interviewing Jeff Mills or scooping around at the
gardening club, fr'instance.

just my 2/5 of a bee

.eh

np: Biochip C./Kaori (Force Inc.)

hiya,
i'm from brisbane australia, and i'd like to follow up g's 
very clever suggestion with a few comments of my own.  (i subscribed to 
this list a few months ago).

On Thu, 29 Jun 1995, Grigsbeast wrote:

> The easiest way to guarantee non-exposure is to use lots of the Seven (or
> eight, or whatever) words you can't use on TV.  The best way is to weird
> them out so totally that they can't process you.  "Last time they set a
> live goat on fire, and it was running around and bleating and shit, and
> we tried to put it out with our smart drinks except they were all laced
> with acid and it freaked out and bit me on the nipple.  Want to see the
> scar?"

there's nothing more effective than a very black sense of humour and your 
suggestion above is an excellent example.  furthermore, you can all sit 
around and have a good laugh about it afterwards.  if you take MTV's 
presence very seriously then you're building up their importance.  
another very effective way of dealing with an annoying presence is to 
simply ignore it.  imagine being asked for an interview or comment and 
saying that you've never heard of MTV.  it is possible!!! ;-) or you're not 
aware of who the MTV "personality" is.  keep 'em guessing with mysterious, 
intriguing and spacey comments.

recently, in australia, there's been a lot of protests/outrage about the 
french government commencing nuclear tests again near tahiti in the 
pacific ocean.  the one protest which i thought was the most memorable 
was carried out by an australian commedian, andrew denton.  he organized 
a huge truck full of horse manure to dump its contents outside of the 
french embassy.  creative subversion always makes me sooo happy.

celestial journeys,
kathleen

> 
> So far my experience at the hands of Sfravers has been pretty unpleasant.

I believe that your unpleasant experiences are a direct result of your
actions and your statements:

No one has forced you to ally yourself with someone who claims to be the
"recognized authority" on the rave scene, and who believes that he
knows how the scene should be evolved.

No one has forced you to blithely ignore netiquette time and time again
with lengthly, off-sub postings to the point that you and Fraiser have been    threatened with censorship of your posts by BRIAN of all people, who 
rightfully loathes the concept or the burden of doing so.

No one has forced you to post multi-page BSP's, which contain fallacies
or outright lies in their content(since you all are obviously technically
savvy enough to pull off an ISDN link, then I find it difficult to believe
that those involved are unwittingly naieve enough to label the Well as
the birthplace of the Internet.)

No one has forced you to forward what are obviously biased, multi-page 
"reviews" of your gigs to this forum.

No one has forced you to respond to private e-mail in this public forum.

>  A bad taste is left in my throat by those members of this community that
> have gone out of their way to tarbrush and ignore reality instead direcingt
> fear and loathing towards myself. The merest step or mistep is greeted with
> the rabid glee of vultures wanting nothing more than to discredit the
> internationalist posse in the rave movement. How for example, do I explain
> to this cynical mindset that in Africa the average number of telephone
> calls made per year is TEN (10) and that merely having conversation over
> the internet with people from this forgotten continent is a miracle. People
> like Mr Adder are so jaded by their smug west coast connectivity that they
> are neither impressed nor surprised when I and a team of committed ravers
> pulled off an interactive video link to a Rave in Woodstock, Cape Town. And
> then they have the gumption to describe the entire event as a  mere
> promotion, a mere money grabbing example of greed. COME ON - I don't think
> anyone would go without sleep for days (pandering to different time zones)
> to establish this connection for MONEY,, there are easier ways to make cash
> - like simply hiring a massive venue in Oakland like Cool World or Funky
> Techno.

David, like it or not, we are not all out to get you. From day 1, I have 
NEVER seen you INTERACT with the flow of conversation, except in the thralls
of a flame war. What have we seen? Off-sub postings, BSP's, forwarded
"reviews," and copies of speeches. That is it. No more. When these are the 
ONLY posts that are seen, it becomes pretty obvious that you are using this 
mailing list as little more than free advertising and a political sounding 
board. You have desisted from the latter, for which I, and am sure others, are grateful. 

As far as being impressed by a link, I am not. Now here, I may be jaded, as
I work with computers and networks for a living. While the distances might
provide some difficulty, the formats and protocols are pretty much
standardized. 

In regards to Cool World at lest, I wouldn't go to one of their events
either.

> These efforts at connecting the world in the face of great odds, seem
> wasted when all we have to offer the expectant masses in the Southern
> Hemishere, are the likes of Mr Adder and his clan of proto-punk would be
> gothic ravers dancing in the mire of a miserable America. What on earth has
> bitten you so hard that you cannot dream of fun beyond the inevitalbe norm
> of 2 by 4 raving?

Well, don't you think it a little presumptious to offer me to anyone?

As I have said before if America is so miserable, go back from whence
you came. Since I know America is not miserable(although there are many
unpleasantries,) I can only assume that it is you that are miserable. I 
suggest seeking happiness within yourself. Worked for me.

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA05919; Thu, 29 Jun 1995 18:52:40 -0700

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Freedom (a poem)
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9506291810.A305-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I finally got a photocopy of this poem that was handed out at the June 
18th Sunset.  In light of Independance Day coming up and Freedom (the 
rave) - the poem has even more significance right now.  I had 
several requests to post it and I'm happy to share the inspirational words.

namaste,
Amy

---------------
|   _  ,/|    |
|  '\`o O'    |
|   =(_^_)=   |         Amy Starkey
|     |U|     |         sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu
|     | |     |      
---------------

***************************************************************************************

This poem is dedicated to this summer - which is the summer of freedom.  
It is time to celebrate being free and what it really means.  The fact 
that we are all here means we are already a step ahead of society.  
Everyone celebrate and help spread the feeling of freedom.  This is only 
the beginning of this poem, add whatever you like.
love to you all...
Freedom is to dance wherever, whenever
Freedom is to looke someone in the eyes and smile
Freedom is to moan in pure ecstasy
Freedom is to shout full of bursting, bubbling energy
Freedom is hugs without expectations
Freedom is to cry at beauty
Freedom is to question reality
Freedom is to have tears streaming down your face whil walking alone
Freedom is to love and raise your hands in the air and sing that lovely 
song, hum that tune, scream or be silent
Freedom has no need to compete
Freedom is to be
Freedom is about respecting yourself
Freedom gives everyone the right to create
Freedom is light
Freedom is loving yourself
Freedom is accepting faults
Freedom is to believe
Freedom is to imagine anything you please
Freedom is shouting "everyone is beautiful!"
Freedom is stating your mind
Freedom is dreaming
Freedom knows no limits

>No one has forced you to ally yourself with someone who claims to be the
>"recognized authority" on the rave scene, and who believes that he
>knows how the scene should be evolved.

Mr adder this is called free choice. I do not have a problem with your
choice of friends, or presume to choose them for you. Nor do I paint you
with another's karma.

>No one has forced you to blithely ignore netiquette time and time again
>with lengthly, off-sub postings to the point that you and Fraiser have been
>threatened with censorship of your posts by BRIAN of all people, who
>rightfully loathes the concept or the burden of doing so.

For some reason you lump me and Fraser together - fuck you, I do believe
Brian threatened me, and only me, and that consensus reached was that since
EVERYONE ELSE WAS EQUALLY GUILTY of Posting, that his actions could be
considered a wee bit prejudicial even if within the standing orders of the
forum.

>

>or outright lies in their content(since you all are obviously technically
>savvy enough to pull off an ISDN link, then I find it difficult to believe
>that those involved are unwittingly naieve enough to label the Well as
>the birthplace of the Internet.)


Fuck you yet again, Since I did not write this so-called "lie" but merely
pointed out that it was most certainly an easy mistake by Schwann in South
Africa. who can be easily forgiven since he is on the other side of the
world,
And I dispise the insinuation that we PLANNED this - It was a totally
personal response by Schwann, but then you probably watch MTV and cannot
tell the difference.

BTW We got the local telco in Cape Town to build us a digital exchange
specially for the occassion. MR Adder, you would be eaten for breakfast in
the third world. Get off your Perch and see that WE ARE NOT ALL JINGOISTIC
YANKEES nor care to be.

>No one has forced you to forward what are obviously biased, multi-page
>"reviews" of your gigs to this forum.


But its okay for Crunch in Australia or every other Sfraver to do likewise.
and Why NOT you little creep.
YOu would'nt know what freedom of speech was if it was tattooed on your
forehead.


>As far as being impressed by a link, I am not. Now here, I may be jaded, as
>I work with computers and networks for a living. While the distances might
>provide some difficulty, the formats and protocols are pretty much
>standardized.

Just goes to show what little you do know. There are at least 5 different
standards in the USA alone. and as far as ISDN goes, We got the FIRST EVER,
Group ISDN VIDEO CONFERENCE using  AN EXTERNAL site, FROM SF TO CT, ~South
Africa - and as mentioned had to install a digital exchange and a bridge
between the 64k and 56k standards amonst other amazing technical problems.
So FUCK your smugness amidst your lack of knowledge

and just to cover all bases: Bradley Graham rises to the attack with a
display of equal blindness and prejudice.

s for Africa being the forgotten continent, I am inclined to agree with you
>to a certain extent.  South Africa does not, however, exemplify the forgotten
>element.  I think maybe Congo or Angola or The Sudan may be more representative
>of the point you are trying to make.
>
>South Africa has been in the US public's eye for many years now.  I can
>remember very vividly driving down Mass. Ave in Washington, D.C. and seeing
>the huge demonstrations against Apartheid day after day in front of the
>South African Embassy.  US companies and citizens joined in the support of
>the the fight against Apartheid by ceasing to do business in South Africa,
>divesting themselves of South African related investments, boycotting, etc.
>This is much more than many countries and people did in other parts of the
>world.  For example, alot of British and German companies remained in South
>Africa during the sanction years.
>
>So, with South Africa in the press so much, it does strike people as jumping
>on the bandwagon.

Could you please bend over and remove the wedge named CYNICAL from your behind.
Number-One if we wanted to jump on a bandwagon, why do it ten years after
the fact?
Number-Two one of the main reasons for doing the link to SA is that it has
a RAVE posse, alive and well.
Number- Three - After removing the death penalty and enshrining every
persons right to life in the constituion, SA is the free-ist nation on
Earth, unlike this country which has the HIGHEST NUMBER OF PEOPLE
INCARCERATED,             above Iran or IRAQ, is about to ban virtual sex
between consenting adults and  execute a BLACK JOURNALIST (mumia abu Jamal)
whose only crime is being in the wrong place at the wrong time, and
writing a story on the BLACK PANTHERS.
FRANkly  I am appalled.

 I might have been more interested and open to the idea
>if you linked up, say, India, Nepal, or Bhutan.

Yes, and if we had also linked up Mars and Venus and the Pyramid of Giza.
Fuck you, you burnt out cynical sloth. I am sure the Emporer Nero would not
have been interested either. YOu are jaded, jaded and even more jaded.


>Furthermore, it isn't clear how your event benefited the South African people,

First, why should it?
Second, It did - we launched a modems for SA schools campaign
Three, why the fuck do you hold me to standards that EVEN YOU CANNOT hope
to match?

Okay, lets turn this around  and ask you all - When last did a SF rave
benefit the American-Indian??

Do you have any soul, any soul, any soul or are you jaded, jaded, jaded.

And thats my rant for the day.

Fraser,
	I don'tr think anyone on this list fears or loaths you, in fact
I believe for the most part, they are not really concerned with you at all.
I think the problem is that you are way too concerned with your own media
image and whether people percieve you as "the international rave guru"
that's cool with me, MTV is nosing around and I'm sure they have a sound bite
(or is that sound byte :) just waiting for you.  We here in SF have a
tradition when it comes to getting the facts straight, and the simple fact is
that many people labored hard and long to bring the Internet as we know it
into reality, the Well had as much to do with this as you did. folks are
just correcting you that's all, once again your error was that you were so
busy focusing on YOUR event and YOUR promotion that you neglected to pass
your promos past someone who could have caught your error before you made
a misstep.  Yes we here on SFRAVES are _very_ sensitive to HYPE whether it
comes from within the community or from without.


> The merest step or mistep is greeted with
> the rabid glee of vultures wanting nothing more than to discredit the
> internationalist posse in the rave movement. How for example, do I explain
> to this cynical mindset that in Africa the average number of telephone
> calls made per year is TEN (10) and that merely having conversation over
> the internet with people from this forgotten continent is a miracle.

All well and good, please bear in mind that before I was a raver I worked
for an organization called the Institute for Global Communications you
may have heard of one of our sister organizations in the UK called GreenNet.
The facts that you quote as far as I'm concerned are even more reason to
get the correct facts to people being exposed to the Internet for the first
time.  Actually South Africa has had an internet connection for at least 5
years but I think until the last year or two it was only 14.4.  IGC and its
associate organization The Association for Progressive Communications have
been working on wiring Africa for the last 10 years at least and it is a very
difficult job.  No one is discrediting the "internationalist posse" of the
rave movement, but maybe "one faction" of this posse forgets that there are
others who are silently working on several fronts as well.  Once again
you have drawn fire because of your sensationalism.



> People
> like Mr Adder are so jaded by their smug west coast connectivity that they
> are neither impressed nor surprised when I and a team of committed ravers
> pulled off an interactive video link to a Rave in Woodstock, Cape Town. And
> then they have the gumption to describe the entire event as a  mere
> promotion, a mere money grabbing example of greed. COME ON - I don't think
> anyone would go without sleep for days (pandering to different time zones)
> to establish this connection for MONEY,, there are easier ways to make cash
> - like simply hiring a massive venue in Oakland like Cool World or Funky
> Techno.

No Fraser I don't think you seek money, FAME is what you are after.

If you did these things than great, your actions should need no stroking
or hand applause, the people who's lives it touched know what you did and
how profound an action it was, don't worry about the nay sayers.  It's sort
of like House Music and parties in general, how do you express to someone
who has never been to a FMR, that feeling in the morning as the
sun is coming up at Bonnie Doon and you can see everyone's faces and you look
at eachother's eyes and everyone of you know a secret that is so precious 
and so dear but you can't  explain it to the person who has never been to a 
party they won't get it because it is pure experience, all you can do is lead
them to the party by way of your actions in life.


> 
> These efforts at connecting the world in the face of great odds, seem
> wasted when all we have to offer the expectant masses in the Southern
> Hemishere, are the likes of Mr Adder and his clan of proto-punk would be
> gothic ravers dancing in the mire of a miserable America. What on earth has
> bitten you so hard that you cannot dream of fun beyond the inevitalbe norm
> of 2 by 4 raving?

Fraser, If you are serious about linking the southern Hemisphere,
I can put you in contact with people who are very active on that front,
they can use all the help they can get.


	Lead by example.

Well, lemme fill you in...  Someone, call him person A, called person B a
"liar" for a post asserting that the Well invented the internet.  Person B
then flamed A back and then private flames were exchanged.  The list was
quiet until someone using A's account posted the private flames.  This is
the "blatant antagonism."

We have different styles and philosophies, but let's show a little
tolerance, please(hold the preaching and self-righteousness).  Some of us
see raves as a means to an end, others see it as an end in itself.  There is
no right or wrong.
That's how I see it anyways. 

I like to see people express themselves fully here, even the flames and
BSPs.  Whatever we write, it should be based on individual discretion and
not filtered by some unseen force.

Really, what would MTV think of this brouhaha?

Larry asks:
>  I wonder what the "Re: Blatant Antagonism in the face of..." posts are
> all about ....

Basically, it's about people being very wrapped up in their personal agendas.  

I'm constantly encouraged at how our differences become less significant 
when we find ourselves transcending our egos for a common love of music
and dance.  Perhaps if some of us participated more in the seemingly 
pointless act of raving for the sake of raving there would be a greater 
awareness of the underlying unity that connects us.  Then afterwards, we 
might not need to shout at each other in order to be heard. 

Sorry for wasting bandwith with such a boring post.  I'm *really* glad the
weekend is here. :)

Lee
_______________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com

THis is that flyer that i told y'all we were making up to attatch to
tickets for "rocket science" here on the 8th of july..thanks again for
everyone's inspirational words :)

this has the header "We are all connected"
____________________________
and do you know what connects us all?  On the net it's called
PLUR.  No, it's not a dishwasher detergent, it's an acronym that
stands for Peace, Love, Unity and Respect.  These are big words
and may be difficult to define but here are some ideas:
Peace: The calmness you find with those around you, and
also inside of yourself.  It's tough, we often have to work at it
but when you're at peace with others, with ourselves and with
our planet only good can come of it.
Love: The caring you feel for friends, for strangers, for
those in need and also for caring you show for yourself.  It's
symbiotic, it's about sharing whatever energy you put into
something will be returned to you!
Unity: This means we all share a lot of common things,
regardless of our age, gender, race, orientation, whatevah! We
are all human beings, we all need other people, & we're all in this
for the happiness experienced being around others.  Though we
may have differences, we all arise from the same source.
Respect: This may mean respect for others, their ideas,
their music, & their lives.  It's also respect for one's self; one's
body and the needs that it has (food, sleep).  Educating yourself
on the substances you ingest shows love and respect for your
body; passing on the knowledge to others shows respect and love
for your fellow person.
ecto@magnet.ca & spooky@magnet.ca
-------------------
this has the header "food for thought"
-------------------
Think about it... how many times have you  gone to a party,
waited in line for hours because the tickets were oversold, nearly
passed out when you got inside because it was overcrowded and
HOT, got pissed off because the sound (and the djs) sucked, and
ended up leaving at 3am when the cops came and closed the
party down? Now, we all know that accidents happen, but very
often problems occur when the promoters are unorganized and
concentrate more money on luxuries than on the essentials.
We decided to throw this event to offer party-goers something
that is a bit different; to expose people to different djs, different
stylesof music, but most of all to get us all together to HAVE
=46UN. English or french, black or white, 'oldskool' or 'newskool.'
This, for us, it what it's allabout: dancing to amazing music and
having fun together. Everything else is a bonus: the poster-sized,
full-colour flyers, the $500 clothes, the 10 zillion watt lasers,
the 16 zillion watts of lights, and the gallons of vicks=81.
We'd like to thank you for coming to our party and would like
your feedback, in whatever form (email, voicemail, in person,
smoke signals, etc.) as we DO care about what you think.
Remember, this scene is CONSUMER DRIVEN so, if you don't
like something, DON'T BUY INTO IT.  If you think a promoter is
wack (that includes us!) tell them and don't go to their parties.
They will either have to put on better productions or stop putting
them on altogether. Remember: YOU have the power to influence
the scene.
        thanks for your time, Keith, Ecto and Mateo
---------------------------
then the header says "Why are you here?" under which is...
---------------------------
There are many reasons to go to a party or to be a 'raver'; here
are some ideas that we got from all over via the internet:
"because we celebrate life and battle
because we are not satisfied
because it is up to us
because we love to sing and dance
because the pressure is upon us
because there are governments and borders and cops and courts
because the boundaries must be broken
because we are out of control
because they said we couldn't do it
because we feel like it" c/o Komotion International-San Francisco

"You can be anything you want here." -Penelope (Boston, USA)

"ACCEPTANCE! I luv that you can leave the shallowness of modern
social standards at the door and become part of the human family
again at a rave!" -Wendy (DC, USA)

"Raving should be a release of emotions, not a means of escaping
your inner feelings and fears.  Most of us fell in love with raving
because of the sense of community; we needed people to reach
out and touch us, but we didn't realize that what we needed to do
first was reach deep down inside and get in touch with our selves,
then we could spread the love.  At that point we would know
that the love is real; not just a reaction from E.
      We can only improve the scene if we improve ourselves first."
-'salami' (Toronto, Canada)
-----------------------------
well it wasn't done 100% perfect, there were things i wanted to fit in or
have changed but you know how it is working with people ;)
the other side of the paper is just the french translation which is pretty
important here as the francophone side is dissed a lot by the scene itself
which is very un-plury ;)
        hope ya'll like it...critical comments would be appreciated too!
                peace,
                        brad

Martin wanted me to pass along that there will be a sunset ceremony and
circle dance at Freedom around 8:45/9pm (whenever sunset occurs).
Immediately following this the music will begin. Doors will open at 7:30pm
and the party will continue to about 9am.

There will be two buses leaving from 5th and Folsom in SF - one at 9pm and
one at 1am. Free organic food and water will be served all night and you're
welcome to bring your own water in as well.

I'll be playing in the ambient tent from 5am - close. My goal is to inspire
ambient breakdancing at some point. =)

Other ambient/dub/jungle DJ's are Nick Philip, Malcolm and Rob. Dance DJ's
are Tony, Doran, Garth, Galen, Spun, Josh, and Jon Williams. Tickets are
$20.

More info: 415 905-9629 or 415 522-3994.

I'll also be spinning at Sunset on Sunday - 415 985-5264.

Joe

On Fri, 30 Jun 1995, Lee Fogel wrote:

> I'm constantly encouraged at how our differences become less significant 
> when we find ourselves transcending our egos for a common love of music
> and dance.  Perhaps if some of us participated more in the seemingly 
> pointless act of raving for the sake of raving there would be a greater 
> awareness of the underlying unity that connects us.  Then afterwards, we 
> might not need to shout at each other in order to be heard. 
 

The trancendence of the ego. Easier said than done, isn't it.

Personal agendas, self interests, personal (as well as generational) 
conditioning. All this prevents us from relating to each other in a true 
manner of openess and respect.

So why is it that we an allow ourselves to be controlled by agendas, 
interests, and conditioning? 

Is it because we are UNABLE to shed this weight of agendas and 
conditioning, or is there some UNDERLYING MOTIVE that prevents us from 
reaching beyond these barriers?

Personally, I feel we all are aware of the barries that exist 
within ourselves and between others, it's just that we've gone through 
years of denial, an unacceptance of the negative aspects within  
ourselves, if you will. 

So, do we continue to go through life with our internal barriers, 
creating external barriers, divisions, misunderstandings, labeling and 
what not?

Or do we CHOOSE to accept the RESPONSIBILITY for our negative 
aspects, and take steps to undo the effects of conditioning and self
serving motives?

I believe that's where these parties come into play.  ;)

I'm reading a book called "Human Energy Systems" (Jack Swarz). The unity 
which Lee mentions is actually an energy which connects everything in 
this universe. 

Our internal barriers prevents the acceptance of this unity, and 
therefore, the acceptance of ourselves and others. 

Through our events, I've discovered many aspects that have 
prevented me from relating to others in an unconditional manner.  

I think I've died a million times since my first party. Some deaths have 
been more painful than others, but it's all leading to a beautiful place: 

FREEDOM

Oh yeah, I'm supposed to be talking energy. 

Pg. 19 of Human Energy Systems
 
	"The key to the healthy utilization of energy is creative 
expression. The best protection against harmful influences and lower forms 
of energy is to radiate energy yourself. Do not hold back your 
capacities; be spontaneous and joyous in everything you do. Do not 
compare yourself with others and worry about whether your capacities are 
higher or lower than theirs; just do it for the sake of doing. Do not 
hold the energy back for fear that someone will not like what you do; 
just keep bringing the energy up and out. That is the best guarantee of a 
healthy body." 

Hell, that's only page 19. I got 150 more to go!


See you all out and about this weekend.

|)

Jonas

Why is MTV filming a rave?  They dont even play house music.

family grow?  If Organic goes off and MTV films it going off than that
